Text

Sense and Sensibility

by [Jane Austen]78-jane austen

( 1811 )

CHAPTER I.

[The family of [Dashwood]79-miss dashwood]206-the family of dashwood had long been settled in [Sussex]1-sussex . [[Their]206-the family of dashwood estate]207-their estate was large , and [[their]206-the family of dashwood residence]208-their residence was at [Norland Park]2-norland park , in the centre of [[their]206-the family of dashwood property]209-their property , where , for many generations , [they]206-the family of dashwood had lived in so respectable a manner as to engage the general good opinion of [[their]206-the family of dashwood surrounding acquaintance]210-their surrounding acquaintance . [The late owner of]211-the late owner of [this estate]212-this estate was [a single man , who lived to a very advanced age]213-a single man , who lived to a very advanced age , and who for many years of [his]211-the late owner of life , had [a constant companion and housekeeper in [[his]211-the late owner of sister]215-his sister]214-a constant companion and housekeeper in his sister . But [her]215-his sister death , which happened ten years before [his]211-the late owner of own , produced a great alteration in [[his]211-the late owner of home]216-his home ; for to supply [her]215-his sister loss , [he]211-the late owner of invited and received into [his]211-the late owner of house [the family of [[his]211-the late owner of nephew]218-his nephew [Mr. Henry Dashwood]80-mr. dashwood , [the legal inheritor of [the Norland estate]220-the norland estate]219-the legal inheritor of the norland estate]217-the family of his nephew mr. henry dashwood , the legal inheritor of the norland estate , and [the person to whom [he]211-the late owner of intended to bequeath [it]220-the norland estate]221-the person to whom he intended to bequeath it . In the society of [[his]211-the late owner of nephew]218-his nephew and [niece]223-niece , and [[their]224-their children]225-their children , [the old Gentleman]226-the old gentleman s days were comfortably spent . [His]211-the late owner of attachment to [them]224-their all increased . The constant attention of [Mr.]227-mr. and [Mrs. Henry Dashwood]81-mrs. henry dashwood to [his]211-the late owner of wishes , which proceeded not merely from interest , but from goodness of heart , gave [him]211-the late owner of every degree of solid comfort which [his]211-the late owner of age could receive ; and the cheerfulness of [the children]228-the children added a relish to [his]211-the late owner of existence .

By a former marriage , [Mr. Henry Dashwood]80-mr. dashwood had [one son]229-one son : by [[his]80-mr. dashwood present lady]230-his present lady , [three daughters]231-three daughters . [The son]232-the son , [a steady respectable young man]233-a steady respectable young man , was amply provided for by the fortune of [[his]232-the son mother]234-his mother , which had been large , and half of which devolved on [him]232-the son on [his]232-the son coming of age . By [his]232-the son own marriage , likewise , which happened soon afterwards , [he]232-the son added to [his]232-the son wealth . To [him]232-the son therefore the succession to [the Norland estate]220-the norland estate was not so really important as to [[his]232-the son sisters]236-his sisters ; for [their]236-his sisters fortune , independent of what might arise to [them]236-his sisters from [[their]236-his sisters father]237-their father s inheriting [that property]238-that property , could be but small . [[Their]236-his sisters mother]239-their mother had nothing , and [[their]236-his sisters father]237-their father only seven thousand pounds in [his]237-their father own disposal ; for the remaining moiety of [[his]232-the son first wife]241-his first wife s fortune was also secured to [[her]241-his first wife child]242-her child , and [he]232-the son had only a life - interest in it .

[The old gentleman]226-the old gentleman died : [his]232-the son will was read , and like almost every other will , gave as much disappointment as pleasure . [He]232-the son was neither so unjust , nor so ungrateful , as to leave [his]232-the son estate from [[his]232-the son nephew]218-his nephew ; but [he]232-the son left it to [him]218-his nephew on such terms as destroyed half the value of the bequest . [Mr. Dashwood]80-mr. dashwood had wished for it more for the sake of [[his]80-mr. dashwood wife]245-his wife and [daughters]246-daughters than for [himself]80-mr. dashwood or [[his]80-mr. dashwood son]247-his son ; but to [[his]80-mr. dashwood son]247-his son , and [[his]80-mr. dashwood son s son]249-his son s son , [a child of four years old]250-a child of four years old , it was secured , in such a way , as to leave to [himself]80-mr. dashwood no power of providing for those who were most dear to [him]80-mr. dashwood , and who most needed a provision by any charge on [the estate]251-the estate , or by any sale of [its]251-the estate valuable woods . The whole was tied up for the benefit of [this child]252-this child , who , in occasional visits with [[his]252-this child father]253-his father and [mother]254-mother at [Norland]3-norland , had so far gained on the affections of [[his]252-this child uncle]255-his uncle , by such attractions as are by no means unusual in [children of two or three years old]256-children of two or three years old ; an imperfect articulation , an earnest desire of having [his]252-this child own way , many cunning tricks , and a great deal of noise , as to outweigh all the value of all the attention which , for years , [he]80-mr. dashwood had received from [[his]80-mr. dashwood niece]257-his niece and [[her]257-his niece daughters]258-her daughters . [He]80-mr. dashwood meant not to be unkind , however , and , as a mark of [his]80-mr. dashwood affection for [the three girls]259-the three girls , [he]80-mr. dashwood left [them]259-the three girls a thousand pounds a - piece .

[Mr. Dashwood]80-mr. dashwood s disappointment was , at first , severe ; but [his]80-mr. dashwood temper was cheerful and sanguine ; and [he]80-mr. dashwood might reasonably hope to live many years , and by living economically , lay by a considerable sum from the produce of an estate already large , and capable of almost immediate improvement . But the fortune , which had been so tardy in coming , was [his]80-mr. dashwood only one twelvemonth . [He]80-mr. dashwood survived [[his]80-mr. dashwood uncle]255-his uncle no longer ; and ten thousand pounds , including the late legacies , was all that remained for [[his]80-mr. dashwood widow]261-his widow and [daughters]246-daughters .

[[His]80-mr. dashwood son]247-his son was sent for as soon as [his]247-his son danger was known , and to [him]247-his son [Mr. Dashwood]80-mr. dashwood recommended , with all the strength and urgency which illness could command , the interest of [[his]247-his son mother - in - law]264-his mother - in - law and [sisters]265-sisters .

[Mr. John Dashwood]82-mr. john dashwood had not the strong feelings of [the rest of [the family]267-the family]266-the rest of the family ; but [he]80-mr. dashwood was affected by a recommendation of such a nature at such a time , and [he]80-mr. dashwood promised to do every thing in [his]80-mr. dashwood power to make [them]266-the rest of the family comfortable . [[His]247-his son father]253-his father was rendered easy by such an assurance , and [Mr. John Dashwood]82-mr. john dashwood had then leisure to consider how much there might prudently be in [his]80-mr. dashwood power to do for [them]266-the rest of the family .

[He]80-mr. dashwood was not [an ill - disposed young man]269-an ill - disposed young man , unless to be rather cold hearted and rather selfish is to be ill - disposed : but [he]80-mr. dashwood was , in general , well respected ; for [he]80-mr. dashwood conducted [himself]80-mr. dashwood with propriety in the discharge of [his]80-mr. dashwood ordinary duties . Had [he]80-mr. dashwood married [a more amiable woman]270-a more amiable woman , [he]80-mr. dashwood might have been made still more respectable than [he]80-mr. dashwood was : [he]80-mr. dashwood might even have been made amiable [himself]80-mr. dashwood ; for [he]80-mr. dashwood was very young when [he]80-mr. dashwood married , and very fond of [[his]80-mr. dashwood wife]245-his wife . But [Mrs. John Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood was a strong caricature of [himself]80-mr. dashwood ; more narrow - minded and selfish .

When [he]80-mr. dashwood gave [his]80-mr. dashwood promise to [[his]80-mr. dashwood father]253-his father , [he]80-mr. dashwood meditated within [himself]80-mr. dashwood to increase the fortunes of [[his]80-mr. dashwood sisters]236-his sisters by the present of a thousand pounds a - piece . [He]80-mr. dashwood then really thought [himself]80-mr. dashwood equal to it . The prospect of four thousand a - year , in addition to [his]80-mr. dashwood present income , besides the remaining half of [[his]80-mr. dashwood own mother]274-his own mother s fortune , warmed [his]80-mr. dashwood heart , and made [him]80-mr. dashwood feel capable of generosity . " Yes , [he]253-his father would give [them]236-his sisters three thousand pounds : it would be liberal and handsome ! It would be enough to make [them]236-his sisters completely easy . Three thousand pounds ! [he]253-his father could spare so considerable a sum with little inconvenience . "[80-mr. dashwood] [He]80-mr. dashwood thought of it all day long , and for many days successively , and [he]80-mr. dashwood did not repent .

No sooner was [[his]80-mr. dashwood father]253-his father s funeral over , than [Mrs. John Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood , without sending any notice of [her]83-mrs. dashwood intention to [[her]83-mrs. dashwood mother - in - law]276-her mother - in - law , arrived with [[her]83-mrs. dashwood child]242-her child and [[their]278-their attendants]279-their attendants . [No one]280-no one could dispute [her]83-mrs. dashwood right to come ; [the house]281-the house was [[her]83-mrs. dashwood husband]282-her husband s from the moment of [[his]80-mr. dashwood father]253-his father s decease ; but the indelicacy of [her]83-mrs. dashwood conduct was so much the greater , and to [a woman in [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood]284-a woman in mrs. dashwood s situation , with only common feelings , must have been highly unpleasing ; but in _ [her]83-mrs. dashwood _ mind there was a sense of honor so keen , a generosity so romantic , that any offence of the kind , by whomsoever given or received , was to [her]83-mrs. dashwood a source of immovable disgust . [Mrs. John Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood had never been [a favourite with any of [[her]83-mrs. dashwood husband s family]286-her husband s family]285-a favourite with any of her husband s family ; but [she]83-mrs. dashwood had had no opportunity , till the present , of showing [them]286-her husband s family with how little attention to the comfort of [other people]287-other people [she]83-mrs. dashwood could act when occasion required it .

So acutely did [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood feel this ungracious behaviour , and so earnestly did [she]83-mrs. dashwood despise [[her]83-mrs. dashwood daughter - in - law]288-her daughter - in - law for it , that , on the arrival of [the latter]289-the latter , [she]83-mrs. dashwood would have quitted [the house]281-the house for ever , had not the entreaty of [[her]83-mrs. dashwood eldest girl]291-her eldest girl induced [her]83-mrs. dashwood first to reflect on the propriety of going , and [her]83-mrs. dashwood own tender love for all [[her]83-mrs. dashwood three children]292-her three children determined [her]83-mrs. dashwood afterwards to stay , and for [their]292-her three children sakes avoid a breach with [[their]292-her three children brother]293-their brother .

[Elinor]84-elinor , [this eldest daughter , whose advice was so effectual]294-this eldest daughter , whose advice was so effectual , possessed a strength of understanding , and coolness of judgment , which qualified [her]84-elinor , though only nineteen , to be [the counsellor of [[her]84-elinor mother]296-her mother]295-the counsellor of her mother , and enabled [her]84-elinor frequently to counteract , to the advantage of [them]292-her three children all , that eagerness of mind in [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood which must generally have led to imprudence . [She]84-elinor had an excellent heart ; [her]84-elinor disposition was affectionate , and [her]84-elinor feelings were strong ; but [she]84-elinor knew how to govern [them]297-them : it was a knowledge which [[her]84-elinor mother]296-her mother had yet to learn ; and which one of [[her]84-elinor sisters]299-her sisters had resolved never to be taught .

[Marianne]85-marianne s abilities were , in many respects , quite equal to [Elinor]84-elinor s. [She]85-marianne was sensible and clever ; but eager in everything : [her]85-marianne sorrows , [her]85-marianne joys , could have no moderation . [She]85-marianne was generous , amiable , interesting : [she]85-marianne was everything but prudent . The resemblance between [her]85-marianne and [[her]84-elinor mother]296-her mother was strikingly great .

[Elinor]84-elinor saw , with concern , the excess of [[her]84-elinor sister]301-her sister s sensibility ; but by [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood it was valued and cherished . [They]302-they encouraged [each other]303-each other now in the violence of [their]302-they affliction . The agony of grief which overpowered [them]302-they at first , was voluntarily renewed , was sought for , was created again and again . [They]302-they gave [themselves]302-they up wholly to [their]302-they sorrow , seeking increase of wretchedness in every reflection that could afford it , and resolved against ever admitting consolation in future . [Elinor]84-elinor , too , was deeply afflicted ; but still [she]84-elinor could struggle , [she]84-elinor could exert [herself]84-elinor . [She]84-elinor could consult with [[her]84-elinor brother]304-her brother , could receive [[her]84-elinor sister - in - law]305-her sister - in - law on [her]84-elinor arrival , and treat [her]84-elinor with proper attention ; and could strive to rouse [[her]84-elinor mother]296-her mother to similar exertion , and encourage [her]296-her mother to similar forbearance .

[Margaret]86-margaret , [the other sister]307-the other sister , was [a good - humored , well - disposed girl]308-a good - humored , well - disposed girl ; but as [she]86-margaret had already imbibed a good deal of [Marianne]85-marianne s romance , without having much of [her]86-margaret sense , [she]86-margaret did not , at thirteen , bid fair to equal [[her]86-margaret sisters]299-her sisters at a more advanced period of life .

CHAPTER II .

[Mrs. John Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood now installed [herself]83-mrs. dashwood [mistress of [Norland]3-norland]310-mistress of norland ; and [[her]83-mrs. dashwood mother]296-her mother and [sisters - in - law]312-sisters - in - law were degraded to the condition of [visitors]313-visitors . As such , however , [they]314-they were treated by [her]83-mrs. dashwood with quiet civility ; and by [[her]83-mrs. dashwood husband]282-her husband with as much kindness as [he]282-her husband could feel towards anybody beyond [himself]282-her husband , [[his]282-her husband wife]245-his wife , and [[their]317-their child]318-their child . [He]282-her husband really pressed [them]314-they , with some earnestness , to consider [Norland]3-norland as [[their]314-they home]319-their home ; and , as no plan appeared so eligible to [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood as remaining [there]320-there till [she]83-mrs. dashwood could accommodate [herself]83-mrs. dashwood with [a house in [the neighbourhood]322-the neighbourhood]321-a house in the neighbourhood , [his]282-her husband invitation was accepted .

A continuance in a place where everything reminded [her]83-mrs. dashwood of former delight , was exactly what suited [her]83-mrs. dashwood mind . In seasons of cheerfulness , no temper could be more cheerful than [hers]83-mrs. dashwood , or possess , in a greater degree , that sanguine expectation of happiness which is happiness itself . But in sorrow [she]83-mrs. dashwood must be equally carried away by [her]83-mrs. dashwood fancy , and as far beyond consolation as in pleasure [she]83-mrs. dashwood was beyond alloy .

[Mrs. John Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood did not at all approve of what [[her]83-mrs. dashwood husband]282-her husband intended to do for [[his]282-her husband sisters]236-his sisters . To take three thousand pounds from the fortune of [[their]325-their dear little boy]326-their dear little boy would be impoverishing [him]282-her husband to the most dreadful degree . [She]83-mrs. dashwood begged [him]282-her husband to think again on the subject . How could [he]282-her husband answer it to [himself]282-her husband to rob [[his]282-her husband child]327-his child , and [[his]282-her husband only child]328-his only child too , of so large a sum ? And what possible claim could [the Miss Dashwoods]87-the miss dashwoods , who were related to [him]282-her husband only by half blood , which [she]83-mrs. dashwood considered as no relationship at all , have on [his]282-her husband generosity to so large an amount . It was very well known that no affection was ever supposed to exist between [the children of [any man by different marriages]330-any man by different marriages]329-the children of any man by different marriages ; and why was [he]282-her husband to ruin [himself]282-her husband , and [[their]325-their poor little Harry]331-their poor little harry , by giving away all [his]282-her husband money to [[his]282-her husband half sisters]332-his half sisters ?

" It was [[my]282-her husband father]2665-my father s last request to [me]282-her husband , "[282-her husband] replied [[her]83-mrs. dashwood husband]282-her husband , " that [I]282-her husband should assist [[his]282-her husband widow]261-his widow and [daughters]246-daughters . "[282-her husband]

" [He]282-her husband did not know what [he]282-her husband was talking of , [I]282-her husband dare say ; ten to one but [he]282-her husband was light - headed at the time . Had [he]282-her husband been in [his]282-her husband right senses , [he]282-her husband could not have thought of such a thing as begging [you]83-mrs. dashwood to give away half [your]83-mrs. dashwood fortune from [[your]83-mrs. dashwood own child]2668-your own child . "[282-her husband]

" [He]282-her husband did not stipulate for any particular sum , [[my]282-her husband dear]2669-my dear [Fanny]88-fanny ; [he]282-her husband only requested [me]282-her husband , in general terms , to assist [them]246-daughters , and make [their]246-daughters situation more comfortable than it was in [his]282-her husband power to do . Perhaps it would have been as well if [he]282-her husband had left it wholly to [myself]282-her husband . [He]282-her husband could hardly suppose [I]282-her husband should neglect [them]246-daughters . But as [he]282-her husband required the promise , [I]282-her husband could not do less than give it ; at least [I]282-her husband thought so at the time . The promise , therefore , was given , and must be performed . Something must be done for [them]246-daughters whenever [they]246-daughters leave [Norland]3-norland and settle in [a new home]2670-a new home . "[282-her husband]

" Well , then , _ let _ something be done for [them]246-daughters ; but _ that _ something need not be three thousand pounds . Consider , "[334-she] [she]334-she added , " that when the money is once parted with , it never can return . [[Your]2671-your sisters]2672-your sisters will marry , and it will be gone for ever . If , indeed , it could be restored to [[our]2673-our poor little boy]2674-our poor little boy "[334-she]

" Why , to be sure , "[282-her husband] said [[her]334-she husband]282-her husband , very gravely , " that would make great difference . The time may come when [Harry]80-mr. dashwood will regret that so large a sum was parted with . If [he]80-mr. dashwood should have [a numerous family]2675-a numerous family , for instance , it would be a very convenient addition . "[282-her husband]

" To be sure it would . "[282-her husband]

" Perhaps , then , it would be better for [all parties]2676-all parties , if the sum were diminished one half . Five hundred pounds would be a prodigious increase to [their]246-daughters fortunes ! "[282-her husband]

" Oh ! beyond anything great ! What [brother on earth]2677-brother on earth would do half so much for [[his]2677-brother on earth sisters]236-his sisters , even if _ really _ [[his]2677-brother on earth sisters]236-his sisters ! And as it is only half blood ! But [you]282-her husband have such a generous spirit ! "[282-her husband]

" [I]282-her husband would not wish to do any thing mean , "[282-her husband] [he]282-her husband replied . " [One]2680-one had rather , on such occasions , do too much than too little . [No one]280-no one , at least , can think [I]282-her husband have not done enough for [them]246-daughters : even [themselves]246-daughters , [they]246-daughters can hardly expect more . "[282-her husband]

" There is no knowing what _ [they]246-daughters _ may expect , "[336-the lady] said [the lady]336-the lady , " but [we]2682-we are not to think of [their]246-daughters expectations : the question is , what [you]282-her husband can afford to do . "[336-the lady]

" Certainly and [I]282-her husband think [I]282-her husband may afford to give [them]246-daughters five hundred pounds a - piece . As it is , without any addition of [mine]282-her husband , [they]246-daughters will each have about three thousand pounds on [[their]246-daughters mother]239-their mother s death a very comfortable fortune for [any young woman]2684-any young woman . "[282-her husband]

" To be sure it is ; and , indeed , it strikes [me]336-the lady that [they]246-daughters can want no addition at all . [They]246-daughters will have ten thousand pounds divided amongst [them]246-daughters . If [they]246-daughters marry , [they]246-daughters will be sure of doing well , and if [they]246-daughters do not , [they]246-daughters may all live very comfortably together on the interest of ten thousand pounds . "[336-the lady]

" That is very true , and , therefore , [I]282-her husband do not know whether , upon the whole , it would not be more advisable to do something for [[their]246-daughters mother]239-their mother while [she]239-their mother lives , rather than for [them]246-daughters something of the annuity kind [I]282-her husband mean . [[My]282-her husband sisters]2686-my sisters would feel the good effects of it as well as [herself]239-their mother . A hundred a year would make [them]246-daughters all perfectly comfortable . "[282-her husband]

[[His]337-his wife]245-his wife hesitated a little , however , in giving [her]245-his wife consent to this plan .

" To be sure , "[245-his wife] said [she]245-his wife , " it is better than parting with fifteen hundred pounds at once . But , then , if [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood should live fifteen years [we]2687-we shall be completely taken in . "[245-his wife]

" Fifteen years ! [[my]336-the lady dear]2669-my dear [Fanny]88-fanny ; [her]83-mrs. dashwood life can not be worth half that purchase . "[336-the lady]

" Certainly not ; but if [you]2689-you observe , [people]2690-people always live for ever when there is an annuity to be paid [them]2690-people ; and [she]83-mrs. dashwood is very stout and healthy , and hardly forty . An annuity is a very serious business ; it comes over and over every year , and there is no getting rid of it . [You]2689-you are not aware of what [you]2689-you are doing . [I]245-his wife have known a great deal of the trouble of annuities ; for [[my]245-his wife mother]2691-my mother was clogged with the payment of three to [old superannuated servants]2692-old superannuated servants by [[my]245-his wife father]2665-my father s will , and it is amazing how disagreeable [she]2691-my mother found it . Twice every year these annuities were to be paid ; and then there was the trouble of getting it to [them]2690-people ; and then one of [them]2690-people was said to have died , and afterwards it turned out to be no such thing . [[My]245-his wife mother]2691-my mother was quite sick of it . [Her]2691-my mother income was not [her]2691-my mother own , [she]2691-my mother said , with such perpetual claims on it ; and it was the more unkind in [[my]245-his wife father]2665-my father , because , otherwise , the money would have been entirely at [[my]245-his wife mother]2691-my mother s disposal , without any restriction whatever . It has given [me]245-his wife such an abhorrence of annuities , that [I]245-his wife am sure [I]245-his wife would not pin [myself]245-his wife down to the payment of one for all [the world]2697-the world . "[245-his wife]

" It is certainly an unpleasant thing , "[80-mr. dashwood] replied [Mr. Dashwood]80-mr. dashwood , " to have those kind of yearly drains on one s income . One s fortune , as [[your]245-his wife mother]2698-your mother justly says , is _ not _ one s own . To be tied down to the regular payment of such a sum , on every rent day , is by no means desirable : it takes away one s independence . "[80-mr. dashwood]

" Undoubtedly ; and after all [you]245-his wife have no thanks for it . [They]2690-people think [themselves]2690-people secure , [you]245-his wife do no more than what is expected , and it raises no gratitude at all . If [I]336-the lady were [you]245-his wife , whatever [I]336-the lady did should be done at [my]336-the lady own discretion entirely . [I]336-the lady would not bind [myself]336-the lady to allow [them]2690-people any thing yearly . It may be very inconvenient some years to spare a hundred , or even fifty pounds from [our]2699-our own expenses . "[336-the lady]

" [I]80-mr. dashwood believe [you]245-his wife are right , [[my]80-mr. dashwood love]2700-my love ; it will be better that there should be no annuity in the case ; whatever [I]80-mr. dashwood may give [them]2690-people occasionally will be of far greater assistance than a yearly allowance , because [they]2690-people would only enlarge [their]2690-people style of living if [they]2690-people felt sure of a larger income , and would not be sixpence the richer for it at the end of the year . It will certainly be much the best way . A present of fifty pounds , now and then , will prevent [their]2690-people ever being distressed for money , and will , [I]80-mr. dashwood think , be amply discharging [my]80-mr. dashwood promise to [[my]80-mr. dashwood father]2665-my father . "[80-mr. dashwood]

" To be sure it will . Indeed , to say the truth , [I]336-the lady am convinced within [myself]336-the lady that [[your]245-his wife father]2702-your father had no idea of [your]245-his wife giving [them]2690-people any money at all . The assistance [he]2702-your father thought of , [I]336-the lady dare say , was only such as might be reasonably expected of [you]245-his wife ; for instance , such as looking out for [a comfortable small house for [them]2690-people , helping [them]2690-people to move [their]2690-people things]2703-a comfortable small house for them , helping them to move their things , and sending [them]2690-people presents of fish and game , and so forth , whenever they are in season . [I]336-the lady ll lay [my]336-the lady life that [he]2702-your father meant nothing farther ; indeed , it would be very strange and unreasonable if [he]2702-your father did . Do but consider , [[my]336-the lady dear]2669-my dear [Mr. Dashwood]80-mr. dashwood , how excessively comfortable [[your]245-his wife mother - in - law]2705-your mother - in - law and [[her]2705-your mother - in - law daughters]258-her daughters may live on the interest of seven thousand pounds , besides the thousand pounds belonging to [each of [the girls]2708-the girls]2707-each of the girls , which brings [them]2708-the girls in fifty pounds a year a - piece , and , of course , [they]2708-the girls will pay [[their]2708-the girls mother]239-their mother for [their]2708-the girls board out of it . Altogether , [they]2708-the girls will have five hundred a - year amongst [them]2708-the girls , and what on earth can [four women]2710-four women want for more than that ? [They]2708-the girls will live so cheap ! [Their]2708-the girls housekeeping will be nothing at all . [They]2708-the girls will have [no carriage]2711-no carriage , no horses , and hardly any [servants]2712-servants ; [they]2708-the girls will keep no company , and can have no expenses of any kind ! Only conceive how comfortable [they]2708-the girls will be ! Five hundred a year ! [I]336-the lady am sure [I]336-the lady can not imagine how [they]2708-the girls will spend half of it ; and as to [your]80-mr. dashwood giving [them]2708-the girls more , it is quite absurd to think of it . [They]2708-the girls will be much more able to give _ [you]80-mr. dashwood _ something . "[336-the lady]

" Upon [my]80-mr. dashwood word , "[80-mr. dashwood] said [Mr. Dashwood]80-mr. dashwood , " [I]80-mr. dashwood believe [you]80-mr. dashwood are perfectly right . [[My]80-mr. dashwood father]2665-my father certainly could mean nothing more by [his]2665-my father request to [me]80-mr. dashwood than what [you]80-mr. dashwood say . [I]80-mr. dashwood clearly understand it now , and [I]80-mr. dashwood will strictly fulfil [my]80-mr. dashwood engagement by such acts of assistance and kindness to [them]2708-the girls as [you]80-mr. dashwood have described . When [[my]80-mr. dashwood mother]2691-my mother removes into [another house]2715-another house [my]80-mr. dashwood services shall be readily given to accommodate [her]2691-my mother as far as [I]80-mr. dashwood can . Some little present of furniture too may be acceptable then . "[80-mr. dashwood]

" Certainly , "[83-mrs. dashwood] returned [Mrs. John Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood . " But , however , _ one _ thing must be considered . When [[your]80-mr. dashwood father]2702-your father and [mother]254-mother moved to [Norland]3-norland , though the furniture of [Stanhill]4-stanhill was sold , all the china , plate , and linen was saved , and is now left to [[your]80-mr. dashwood mother]2698-your mother . [[Her]2698-your mother house]2719-her house will therefore be almost completely fitted up as soon as [she]2698-your mother takes [it]2719-her house . "[83-mrs. dashwood]

" That is a material consideration undoubtedly . A valuable legacy indeed ! And yet some of the plate would have been a very pleasant addition to [our]2720-our own stock [here]2721-here . "[253-his father]

" Yes ; and the set of breakfast china is twice as handsome as what belongs to [this house]2722-this house . A great deal too handsome , in [my]83-mrs. dashwood opinion , for any place _ [they]2723-them _ can ever afford to live in . But , however , so it is . [[Your]80-mr. dashwood father]2702-your father thought only of _ [them]2723-them _ . And [I]83-mrs. dashwood must say this : that [you]80-mr. dashwood owe no particular gratitude to [him]2702-your father , nor attention to [his]2702-your father wishes ; for [we]2720-our very well know that if [he]2702-your father could , [he]2702-your father would have left almost everything in [the world]2697-the world to _ [them]2723-them _ . "[83-mrs. dashwood]

This argument was irresistible . It gave to [his]339-his intentions whatever of decision was wanting before ; and [he]339-his finally resolved , that it would be absolutely unnecessary , if not highly indecorous , to do more for [the widow and children of [[his]339-his father]253-his father]340-the widow and children of his father , than such kind of neighbourly acts as [[his]339-his own wife]342-his own wife pointed out .

CHAPTER III .

[Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood remained at [Norland]3-norland several months ; not from any disinclination to move when the sight of [every well known spot]343-every well known spot ceased to raise the violent emotion which it produced for a while ; for when [her]83-mrs. dashwood spirits began to revive , and [her]83-mrs. dashwood mind became capable of some other exertion than that of heightening its affliction by melancholy remembrances , [she]83-mrs. dashwood was impatient to be gone , and indefatigable in [her]83-mrs. dashwood inquiries for [a suitable dwelling in [the neighbourhood of [Norland]3-norland]345-the neighbourhood of norland]344-a suitable dwelling in the neighbourhood of norland ; for to remove far from [that beloved spot]346-that beloved spot was impossible . But [she]83-mrs. dashwood could hear of no situation that at once answered [her]83-mrs. dashwood notions of comfort and ease , and suited the prudence of [[her]83-mrs. dashwood eldest daughter]347-her eldest daughter , whose steadier judgment rejected [several houses]348-several houses as too large for [their]349-their income , which [[her]347-her eldest daughter mother]296-her mother would have approved .

[Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood had been informed by [[her]83-mrs. dashwood husband]282-her husband of the solemn promise on the part of [[his]282-her husband son]247-his son in [their]353-their favour , which gave comfort to [his]282-her husband last earthly reflections . [She]83-mrs. dashwood doubted the sincerity of this assurance no more than [he]282-her husband had doubted it [himself]282-her husband , and [she]83-mrs. dashwood thought of it for [[her]83-mrs. dashwood daughters]258-her daughters sake with satisfaction , though as for [herself]83-mrs. dashwood [she]83-mrs. dashwood was persuaded that a much smaller provision than 7000 would support [her]83-mrs. dashwood in affluence . For [[their]353-their brother]293-their brother s sake , too , for the sake of [his]293-their brother own heart , [she]83-mrs. dashwood rejoiced ; and [she]83-mrs. dashwood reproached [herself]83-mrs. dashwood for being unjust to [his]293-their brother merit before , in believing [him]293-their brother incapable of generosity . [His]293-their brother attentive behaviour to [herself]83-mrs. dashwood and [[his]293-their brother sisters]236-his sisters convinced [her]83-mrs. dashwood that [their]353-their welfare was dear to [him]293-their brother , and , for a long time , [she]83-mrs. dashwood firmly relied on the liberality of [his]293-their brother intentions .

The contempt which [she]83-mrs. dashwood had , very early in [their]353-their acquaintance , felt for [[her]83-mrs. dashwood daughter - in - law]288-her daughter - in - law , was very much increased by the farther knowledge of [her]83-mrs. dashwood character , which half a year s residence in [[her]83-mrs. dashwood family]358-her family afforded ; and perhaps in spite of every consideration of politeness or maternal affection on the side of [the former]359-the former , [the two ladies]360-the two ladies might have found it impossible to have lived together so long , had not a particular circumstance occurred to give still greater eligibility , according to the opinions of [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood , to [[her]83-mrs. dashwood daughters]258-her daughters continuance at [Norland]3-norland .

This circumstance was a growing attachment between [[her]83-mrs. dashwood eldest girl]291-her eldest girl and [the brother of [Mrs. John Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood]363-the brother of mrs. john dashwood , [a gentleman - like and pleasing young man , who was introduced to [their]353-their acquaintance soon after [[his]363-the brother of mrs. john dashwood sister]215-his sister s establishment at [Norland]3-norland , and who had since spent the greatest part of [his]363-the brother of mrs. john dashwood time [there]320-there]364-a gentleman - like and pleasing young man , who was introduced to their acquaintance soon after his sister s establishment at norland , and who had since spent the greatest part of his time there .

[Some mothers]367-some mothers might have encouraged the intimacy from motives of interest , for [Edward Ferrars]89-edward was [the eldest son of [a man who had died very rich]369-a man who had died very rich]368-the eldest son of a man who had died very rich ; and some might have repressed it from motives of prudence , for , except a trifling sum , the whole of [his]363-the brother of mrs. john dashwood fortune depended on the will of [[his]363-the brother of mrs. john dashwood mother]234-his mother . But [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood was alike uninfluenced by either consideration . It was enough for [her]83-mrs. dashwood that [he]363-the brother of mrs. john dashwood appeared to be amiable , that [he]363-the brother of mrs. john dashwood loved [[her]83-mrs. dashwood daughter]371-her daughter , and that [Elinor]84-elinor returned the partiality . It was contrary to every doctrine of [hers]83-mrs. dashwood that difference of fortune should keep [any couple asunder who were attracted by resemblance of disposition]372-any couple asunder who were attracted by resemblance of disposition ; and that [Elinor]84-elinor s merit should not be acknowledged by [every one who knew [her]84-elinor]373-every one who knew her , was to [her]84-elinor comprehension impossible .

[Edward Ferrars]89-edward was not recommended to [their]374-they good opinion by any peculiar graces of person or address . [He]89-edward was not handsome , and [his]89-edward manners required intimacy to make [them]374-they pleasing . [He]89-edward was too diffident to do justice to [himself]89-edward ; but when [his]89-edward natural shyness was overcome , [his]89-edward behaviour gave every indication of an open , affectionate heart . [His]89-edward understanding was good , and [his]89-edward education had given it solid improvement . But [he]89-edward was neither fitted by abilities nor disposition to answer the wishes of [[his]89-edward mother]234-his mother and sister , who longed to see [him]89-edward distinguished as [they]374-they hardly knew what . [They]374-they wanted [him]89-edward to make a fine figure in [the world]2697-the world in some manner or other . [[His]89-edward mother]234-his mother wished to interest [him]89-edward in political concerns , to get [him]89-edward into parliament , or to see [him]89-edward connected with [some of [the great men of the day]379-the great men of the day]378-some of the great men of the day . [Mrs. John Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood wished it likewise ; but in the mean while , till one of these superior blessings could be attained , it would have quieted [her]83-mrs. dashwood ambition to see [him]89-edward driving [a barouche]380-a barouche . But [Edward]89-edward had no turn for [great men]381-great men or barouches . All [his]89-edward wishes centered in domestic comfort and the quiet of private life . Fortunately [he]89-edward had [a younger brother]382-a younger brother who was more promising .

[Edward]89-edward had been staying several weeks in [the house]281-the house before [he]89-edward engaged much of [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood s attention ; for [she]83-mrs. dashwood was , at that time , in such affliction as rendered [her]83-mrs. dashwood careless of surrounding objects . [She]83-mrs. dashwood saw only that [he]89-edward was quiet and unobtrusive , and [she]83-mrs. dashwood liked [him]89-edward for it . [He]89-edward did not disturb the wretchedness of [her]83-mrs. dashwood mind by ill - timed conversation . [She]83-mrs. dashwood was first called to observe and approve [him]89-edward farther , by a reflection which [Elinor]84-elinor chanced one day to make on the difference between [him]89-edward and [[his]89-edward sister]215-his sister . It was a contrast which recommended [him]89-edward most forcibly to [[her]83-mrs. dashwood mother]296-her mother .

" It is enough , "[83-mrs. dashwood] said [she]83-mrs. dashwood ; " to say that [he]89-edward is unlike [Fanny]88-fanny is enough . It implies everything amiable . [I]83-mrs. dashwood love [him]89-edward already . "[83-mrs. dashwood]

" [I]84-elinor think [you]296-her mother will like [him]89-edward , "[84-elinor] said [Elinor]84-elinor , " when [you]296-her mother know more of [him]89-edward . "[84-elinor]

" Like [him]89-edward ! "[296-her mother] replied [[her]83-mrs. dashwood mother]296-her mother with a smile . " [I]296-her mother feel no sentiment of approbation inferior to love . "[296-her mother]

" [You]296-her mother may esteem [him]89-edward . "[84-elinor]

" [I]296-her mother have never yet known what it was to separate esteem and love . "[296-her mother]

[Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood now took pains to get acquainted with [him]387-his . [Her]83-mrs. dashwood manners were attaching , and soon banished [his]387-his reserve . [She]83-mrs. dashwood speedily comprehended all [his]387-his merits ; the persuasion of [his]387-his regard for [Elinor]84-elinor perhaps assisted [her]83-mrs. dashwood penetration ; but [she]83-mrs. dashwood really felt assured of [his]387-his worth : and even that quietness of manner , which militated against all [her]83-mrs. dashwood established ideas of what [a young man]388-a young man s address ought to be , was no longer uninteresting when [she]83-mrs. dashwood knew [his]387-his heart to be warm and [his]387-his temper affectionate .

No sooner did [she]83-mrs. dashwood perceive any symptom of love in [his]387-his behaviour to [Elinor]84-elinor , than [she]83-mrs. dashwood considered [their]389-we serious attachment as certain , and looked forward to [their]389-we marriage as rapidly approaching .

" In a few months , [[my]83-mrs. dashwood dear]2669-my dear [Marianne]85-marianne , "[83-mrs. dashwood] said [she]83-mrs. dashwood , " [Elinor]84-elinor will , in all probability be settled for life . [We]389-we shall miss [her]84-elinor ; but _ [she]84-elinor _ will be happy . "[83-mrs. dashwood]

" Oh ! [Mama]90-mama , how shall [we]389-we do without [her]84-elinor ? "[83-mrs. dashwood]

" [My]83-mrs. dashwood love , it will be scarcely a separation . [We]389-we shall live within a few miles of each other , and shall meet every day of [our]389-we lives . [You]85-marianne will gain [a brother]2727-a brother , [a real , affectionate brother]2728-a real , affectionate brother . [I]83-mrs. dashwood have the highest opinion in [the world]2697-the world of [Edward]89-edward s heart . But [you]85-marianne look grave , [Marianne]85-marianne ; do [you]85-marianne disapprove [[your]85-marianne sister]2730-your sister s choice ? "[83-mrs. dashwood]

" Perhaps , "[85-marianne] said [Marianne]85-marianne , " [I]85-marianne may consider it with some surprise . [Edward]89-edward is very amiable , and [I]85-marianne love [him]89-edward tenderly . But yet [he]89-edward is not [the kind of young man]2731-the kind of young man there is something wanting [his]89-edward figure is not striking ; it has none of that grace which [I]85-marianne should expect in [the man who could seriously attach [[my]85-marianne sister]2733-my sister]2732-the man who could seriously attach my sister . [His]89-edward eyes want all that spirit , that fire , which at once announce virtue and intelligence . And besides all this , [I]85-marianne am afraid , [Mama]90-mama , [he]89-edward has no real taste . [Music]91-music seems scarcely to attract [him]89-edward , and though [he]89-edward admires [Elinor]84-elinor s drawings very much , it is not the admiration of [a person who can understand [their]2735-their worth]2734-a person who can understand their worth . It is evident , in spite of [his]89-edward frequent attention to [her]84-elinor while [she]84-elinor draws , that in fact [he]89-edward knows nothing of the matter . [He]89-edward admires as [a lover]2736-a lover , not as [a connoisseur]2737-a connoisseur . To satisfy [me]85-marianne , [those characters]2738-those characters must be united . [I]85-marianne could not be happy with [a man whose taste did not in every point coincide with [my]85-marianne own]2739-a man whose taste did not in every point coincide with my own . [He]89-edward must enter into all [my]85-marianne feelings ; the same books , the same music must charm [us]2740-us both . Oh ! [mama]2741-mama , how spiritless , how tame was [Edward]89-edward s manner in reading to [us]2740-us last night ! [I]85-marianne felt for [[my]85-marianne sister]2733-my sister most severely . Yet [she]2733-my sister bore it with so much composure , [she]2733-my sister seemed scarcely to notice it . [I]85-marianne could hardly keep [my]85-marianne seat . To hear those beautiful lines which have frequently almost driven [me]85-marianne wild , pronounced with such impenetrable calmness , such dreadful indifference ! "[85-marianne]

" [He]89-edward would certainly have done more justice to simple and elegant prose . [I]83-mrs. dashwood thought so at the time ; but [you]85-marianne _ would _ give [him]89-edward [Cowper]92-cowper . "[83-mrs. dashwood]

" Nay , [Mama]90-mama , if [he]89-edward is not to be animated by [Cowper]92-cowper ! but [we]2740-us must allow for difference of taste . [Elinor]84-elinor has not [my]85-marianne feelings , and therefore [she]84-elinor may overlook it , and be happy with [him]89-edward . But it would have broke _ [my]85-marianne _ heart , had [I]85-marianne loved [him]89-edward , to hear [him]89-edward read with so little sensibility . [Mama]90-mama , the more [I]85-marianne know of [the world]2697-the world , the more am [I]85-marianne convinced that [I]85-marianne shall never see [a man whom [I]85-marianne can really love]2744-a man whom i can really love . [I]85-marianne require so much ! [He]89-edward must have all [Edward]89-edward s virtues , and [his]89-edward person and manners must ornament [his]89-edward goodness with every possible charm . "[85-marianne]

" Remember , [[my]83-mrs. dashwood love]2700-my love , that [you]2700-my love are not seventeen . It is yet too early in life to despair of such a happiness . Why should [you]2700-my love be less fortunate than [[your]2700-my love mother]2698-your mother ? CHAPTER IV .

" What a pity it is , [Elinor]84-elinor , "[85-marianne] said [Marianne]85-marianne , " that [Edward]89-edward should have no taste for drawing . "[85-marianne]

" No taste for drawing ! "[84-elinor] replied [Elinor]84-elinor , " why should [you]2700-my love think so ? [He]89-edward does not draw [himself]89-edward , indeed , but [he]89-edward has great pleasure in seeing the performances of [other people]287-other people , and [I]84-elinor assure [you]2700-my love [he]89-edward is by no means deficient in natural taste , though [he]89-edward has not had opportunities of improving it . Had [he]89-edward ever been in the way of learning , [I]84-elinor think [he]89-edward would have drawn very well . [He]89-edward distrusts [his]89-edward own judgment in such matters so much , that [he]89-edward is always unwilling to give [his]89-edward opinion on any picture ; but [he]89-edward has an innate propriety and simplicity of taste , which in general direct [him]89-edward perfectly right . "[84-elinor]

[Marianne]85-marianne was afraid of offending , and said no more on the subject ; but the kind of approbation which [Elinor]84-elinor described as excited in [him]390-his by the drawings of [other people]287-other people , was very far from that rapturous delight , which , in [her]85-marianne opinion , could alone be called taste . Yet , though smiling within [herself]85-marianne at the mistake , [she]85-marianne honoured [[her]85-marianne sister]301-her sister for that blind partiality to [Edward]89-edward which produced it .

" [I]84-elinor hope , [Marianne]85-marianne , "[84-elinor] continued [Elinor]84-elinor , " [you]85-marianne do not consider [him]390-his as deficient in general taste . Indeed , [I]84-elinor think [I]84-elinor may say that [you]85-marianne can not , for [your]85-marianne behaviour to [him]390-his is perfectly cordial , and if _ that _ were [your]85-marianne opinion , [I]84-elinor am sure [you]85-marianne could never be civil to [him]390-his . "[84-elinor]

[Marianne]85-marianne hardly knew what to say . [She]85-marianne would not wound the feelings of [[her]85-marianne sister]301-her sister on any account , and yet to say what [she]85-marianne did not believe was impossible . At length [she]85-marianne replied :

" Do not be offended , [Elinor]84-elinor , if [my]85-marianne praise of [him]390-his is not in every thing equal to [your]84-elinor sense of [his]390-his merits . [I]85-marianne have not had so many opportunities of estimating the minuter propensities of [his]390-his mind , [his]390-his inclinations and tastes , as [you]84-elinor have ; but [I]85-marianne have the highest opinion in [the world]2697-the world of [his]390-his goodness and sense . [I]85-marianne think [him]390-his every thing that is worthy and amiable . "[85-marianne]

" [I]84-elinor am sure , "[84-elinor] replied [Elinor]84-elinor , with a smile , " that [[his]390-his dearest friends]2750-his dearest friends could not be dissatisfied with such commendation as that . [I]84-elinor do not perceive how [you]85-marianne could express [yourself]85-marianne more warmly . "[84-elinor]

[Marianne]85-marianne was rejoiced to find [[her]85-marianne sister]301-her sister so easily pleased .

" Of [his]390-his sense and [his]390-his goodness , "[84-elinor] continued [Elinor]84-elinor , " [no one]280-no one can , [I]84-elinor think , be in doubt , who has seen [him]390-his often enough to engage [him]390-his in unreserved conversation . The excellence of [his]390-his understanding and [his]390-his principles can be concealed only by that shyness which too often keeps [him]390-his silent . [You]85-marianne know enough of [him]390-his to do justice to [his]390-his solid worth . But of [his]390-his minuter propensities , as [you]85-marianne call them [you]85-marianne have from peculiar circumstances been kept more ignorant than [myself]84-elinor . [He]390-his and [I]84-elinor have been at times thrown a good deal together , while [you]85-marianne have been wholly engrossed on the most affectionate principle by [[my]84-elinor mother]2691-my mother . [I]84-elinor have seen a great deal of [him]390-his , have studied [his]390-his sentiments and heard [his]390-his opinion on subjects of literature and taste ; and , upon the whole , [I]84-elinor venture to pronounce that [his]390-his mind is well - informed , enjoyment of books exceedingly great , [his]390-his imagination lively , [his]390-his observation just and correct , and [his]390-his taste delicate and pure . [His]390-his abilities in every respect improve as much upon acquaintance as [his]390-his manners and person . At first sight , [his]390-his address is certainly not striking ; and [[his]390-his person]2753-his person can hardly be called handsome , till the expression of [his]390-his eyes , which are uncommonly good , and the general sweetness of [his]390-his countenance , is perceived . At present , [I]84-elinor know [him]390-his so well , that [I]84-elinor think [him]390-his really handsome ; or at least , almost so . What say [you]84-elinor , [Marianne]85-marianne ? "[84-elinor]

" [I]395-i shall very soon think [him]390-his handsome , [Elinor]84-elinor , if [I]395-i do not now . When [you]84-elinor tell [me]395-i to love [him]390-his as [a brother]2727-a brother , [I]395-i shall no more see imperfection in [his]390-his face , than [I]395-i now do in [his]390-his heart . "[395-i]

[Elinor]84-elinor started at this declaration , and was sorry for the warmth [she]84-elinor had been betrayed into , in speaking of [him]395-i . [She]84-elinor felt that [Edward]89-edward stood very high in [her]84-elinor opinion . [She]84-elinor believed the regard to be mutual ; but [she]84-elinor required greater certainty of it to make [Marianne]85-marianne s conviction of [their]396-their attachment agreeable to [her]84-elinor . [She]84-elinor knew that what [Marianne]85-marianne and [[her]85-marianne mother]296-her mother conjectured one moment , [they]396-their believed the next that with [them]396-their , to wish was to hope , and to hope was to expect . [She]84-elinor tried to explain the real state of the case to [[her]84-elinor sister]301-her sister .

" [I]84-elinor do not attempt to deny , "[84-elinor] said [she]84-elinor , " that [I]84-elinor think very highly of [him]2755-his that [I]84-elinor greatly esteem , that [I]84-elinor like [him]2755-his . "[84-elinor]

[Marianne]85-marianne here burst forth with indignation

" Esteem [him]2755-his ! Like [him]2755-his ! Cold - hearted [Elinor]84-elinor ! Oh ! worse than cold - hearted ! Ashamed of being otherwise . Use those words again , and [I]85-marianne will leave [the room]2756-the room this moment . "[85-marianne]

[Elinor]84-elinor could not help laughing . " Excuse [me]84-elinor , "[84-elinor] said [she]84-elinor ; " and be assured that [I]84-elinor meant no offence to [you]84-elinor , by speaking , in so quiet a way , of [my]84-elinor own feelings . Believe them to be stronger than [I]84-elinor have declared ; believe [them]2757-them , in short , to be such as [his]2755-his merit , and the suspicion the hope of [his]2755-his affection for [me]84-elinor may warrant , without imprudence or folly . But farther than this [you]84-elinor must _ not _ believe . [I]84-elinor am by no means assured of [his]2755-his regard for [me]84-elinor . There are moments when the extent of it seems doubtful ; and till [his]2755-his sentiments are fully known , [you]84-elinor can not wonder at [my]84-elinor wishing to avoid any encouragement of [my]84-elinor own partiality , by believing or calling it more than it is . In [my]84-elinor heart [I]84-elinor feel little scarcely any doubt of [his]2755-his preference . But there are other points to be considered besides [his]2755-his inclination . [He]2755-his is very far from being independent . What [[his]2755-his mother]234-his mother really is [we]2759-we can not know ; but , from [Fanny]88-fanny s occasional mention of [her]88-fanny conduct and opinions , [we]2759-we have never been disposed to think [her]88-fanny amiable ; and [I]84-elinor am very much mistaken if [Edward]89-edward is not [himself]89-edward aware that there would be many difficulties in [his]89-edward way , if [he]89-edward were to wish to marry [a woman who had not either a great fortune or high rank]2760-a woman who had not either a great fortune or high rank . "[84-elinor]

[Marianne]85-marianne was astonished to find how much the imagination of [[her]85-marianne mother]296-her mother and [herself]85-marianne had outstripped the truth .

" And [you]89-edward really are not engaged to [him]89-edward ! "[85-marianne] said [she]85-marianne . " Yet it certainly soon will happen . But two advantages will proceed from this delay . _ [I]85-marianne _ shall not lose [you]89-edward so soon , and [Edward]89-edward will have greater opportunity of improving that natural taste for [your]89-edward favourite pursuit which must be so indispensably necessary to [your]89-edward future felicity . Oh ! if [he]89-edward should be so far stimulated by [your]89-edward genius as to learn to draw [himself]89-edward , how delightful it would be ! "[85-marianne]

[Elinor]84-elinor had given [her]84-elinor real opinion to [[her]84-elinor sister]301-her sister . [She]84-elinor could not consider [her]84-elinor partiality for [Edward]89-edward in so prosperous a state as [Marianne]85-marianne had believed it . There was , at times , a want of spirits about [him]89-edward which , if it did not denote indifference , spoke of something almost as unpromising . A doubt of [her]84-elinor regard , supposing [him]89-edward to feel it , need not give [him]89-edward more than inquietude . It would not be likely to produce that dejection of mind which frequently attended [him]89-edward . A more reasonable cause might be found in the dependent situation which forbade the indulgence of [his]89-edward affection . [She]84-elinor knew that [[his]89-edward mother]234-his mother neither behaved to [him]89-edward so as to make [[his]89-edward home]216-his home comfortable at present , nor to give [him]89-edward any assurance that [he]89-edward might form [a home for [himself]89-edward]403-a home for himself , without strictly attending to [her]84-elinor views for [his]89-edward aggrandizement . With such a knowledge as this , it was impossible for [Elinor]84-elinor to feel easy on the subject . [She]84-elinor was far from depending on that result of [his]89-edward preference of [her]84-elinor , which [[her]84-elinor mother]296-her mother and [sister]405-sister still considered as certain . Nay , the longer [they]406-they were together the more doubtful seemed the nature of [his]89-edward regard ; and sometimes , for a few painful minutes , [she]84-elinor believed it to be no more than friendship .

But , whatever might really be its limits , it was enough , when perceived by [[his]89-edward sister]215-his sister , to make [her]84-elinor uneasy , and at the same time , ( which was still more common , ) to make [her]84-elinor uncivil . [She]84-elinor took the first opportunity of affronting [[her]84-elinor mother - in - law]276-her mother - in - law on the occasion , talking to [her]84-elinor so expressively of [[her]84-elinor brother]304-her brother s great expectations , of [Mrs. Ferrars]93-lucy s resolution that both [[her]84-elinor sons]410-her sons should marry well , and of the danger attending [any young woman who attempted to _ draw]411-any young woman who attempted to _ draw [him]89-edward in ; _ that [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood could neither pretend to be unconscious , nor endeavor to be calm . [She]84-elinor gave [her]84-elinor an answer which marked [her]84-elinor contempt , and instantly left [the room]2756-the room , resolving that , whatever might be the inconvenience or expense of so sudden a removal , [[her]84-elinor beloved]413-her beloved [Elinor]84-elinor should not be exposed another week to such insinuations .

In this state of [her]84-elinor spirits , a letter was delivered to [her]84-elinor from the post , which contained a proposal particularly well timed . It was the offer of [a small house]414-a small house , on very easy terms , belonging to [a relation of [her]84-elinor own]415-a relation of her own , [a gentleman of consequence and property in [Devonshire]5-devonshire]416-a gentleman of consequence and property in devonshire . The letter was from [this gentleman]417-this gentleman [himself]417-this gentleman , and written in the true spirit of friendly accommodation . [He]417-this gentleman understood that [she]84-elinor was in need of [a dwelling]418-a dwelling ; and though [the house]281-the house [he]417-this gentleman now offered [her]84-elinor was merely [a cottage]420-a cottage , [he]417-this gentleman assured [her]84-elinor that everything should be done to [it]281-the house which [she]84-elinor might think necessary , if the situation pleased [her]84-elinor . [He]417-this gentleman earnestly pressed [her]84-elinor , after giving the particulars of [the house]281-the house and [garden]422-garden , to come with [[her]84-elinor daughters]258-her daughters to [Barton Park]6-barton park , [the place of [[his]417-this gentleman own residence]425-his own residence]424-the place of his own residence , from whence [she]84-elinor might judge , [herself]84-elinor , whether [Barton Cottage]7-barton cottage , for [the houses]426-the houses were in [the same parish]427-the same parish , could , by any alteration , be made comfortable to [her]84-elinor . [He]417-this gentleman seemed really anxious to accommodate [them]258-her daughters and the whole of [his]417-this gentleman letter was written in so friendly a style as could not fail of giving pleasure to [[his]417-this gentleman cousin]428-his cousin ; more especially at a moment when [she]84-elinor was suffering under the cold and unfeeling behaviour of [her]84-elinor nearer connections . [She]84-elinor needed no time for deliberation or inquiry . [Her]84-elinor resolution was formed as [she]84-elinor read . The situation of [Barton]8-barton , in [a county so far distant from [Sussex]1-sussex as [Devonshire]5-devonshire]429-a county so far distant from sussex as devonshire , which , but a few hours before , would have been a sufficient objection to outweigh every possible advantage belonging to [the place]430-the place , was now [its]430-the place first recommendation . To quit [the neighbourhood of Norland]345-the neighbourhood of norland was no longer an evil ; it was an object of desire ; it was a blessing , in comparison of the misery of continuing [[her]84-elinor daughter - in - law s guest]432-her daughter - in - law s guest ; and to remove for ever from [that beloved place]433-that beloved place would be less painful than to inhabit or visit [it]433-that beloved place while [such a woman]434-such a woman was [its mistress]435-its mistress . [She]84-elinor instantly wrote [Sir John Middleton]94-sir john [her]84-elinor acknowledgment of [his]94-sir john kindness , and [her]84-elinor acceptance of [his]94-sir john proposal ; and then hastened to show both letters to [[her]84-elinor daughters]258-her daughters , that [she]84-elinor might be secure of [their]258-her daughters approbation before [her]84-elinor answer were sent .

[Elinor]84-elinor had always thought it would be more prudent for [them]258-her daughters to settle at some distance from [Norland]3-norland , than immediately amongst [[their]258-her daughters present acquaintance]437-their present acquaintance . On _ that _ head , therefore , it was not for [her]84-elinor to oppose [[her]84-elinor mother]296-her mother s intention of removing into [Devonshire]5-devonshire . [The house]281-the house , too , as described by [Sir John]94-sir john , was on so simple a scale , and the rent so uncommonly moderate , as to leave [her]84-elinor no right of objection on either point ; and , therefore , though it was not a plan which brought any charm to [her]84-elinor fancy , though it was a removal from [the vicinity of [Norland]3-norland]440-the vicinity of norland beyond [her]84-elinor wishes , [she]84-elinor made no attempt to dissuade [[her]84-elinor mother]296-her mother from sending a letter of acquiescence .

CHAPTER V.

No sooner was [her]84-elinor answer dispatched , than [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood indulged [herself]83-mrs. dashwood in the pleasure of announcing to [[[her]83-mrs. dashwood son]442-her son - in - law and [[his]442-her son wife]245-his wife]443-her son - in - law and his wife that [she]83-mrs. dashwood was provided with [a house]445-a house , and should incommode [them]443-her son - in - law and his wife no longer than till every thing were ready for [her]83-mrs. dashwood inhabiting [it]445-a house . [They]443-her son - in - law and his wife heard [her]83-mrs. dashwood with surprise . [Mrs. John Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood said nothing ; but [[her]83-mrs. dashwood husband]282-her husband civilly hoped that [she]83-mrs. dashwood would not be settled far from [Norland]3-norland . [She]83-mrs. dashwood had great satisfaction in replying that [she]83-mrs. dashwood was going into [Devonshire]5-devonshire . [Edward]89-edward turned hastily towards [her]83-mrs. dashwood , on hearing this , and , in a voice of surprise and concern , which required no explanation to [her]83-mrs. dashwood , repeated , " [Devonshire]5-devonshire ! Are [you]83-mrs. dashwood , indeed , going [there]320-there ? So far from hence ! And to what part of it ? "[83-mrs. dashwood] [She]83-mrs. dashwood explained the situation . It was within four miles northward of [Exeter]9-exeter .

" [It]445-a house is but [a cottage]420-a cottage , "[83-mrs. dashwood] [she]83-mrs. dashwood continued , " but [I]83-mrs. dashwood hope to see [many of [[my]83-mrs. dashwood friends]2764-my friends in [it]445-a house]2763-many of my friends in it . [A room or two]2765-a room or two can easily be added ; and if [[my]83-mrs. dashwood friends]2764-my friends find no difficulty in travelling so far to see [me]83-mrs. dashwood , [I]83-mrs. dashwood am sure [I]83-mrs. dashwood will find none in accommodating [them]2764-my friends . "[83-mrs. dashwood]

[She]83-mrs. dashwood concluded with a very kind invitation to [Mr.]447-mr. and [Mrs. John Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood to visit [her]83-mrs. dashwood at [Barton]8-barton ; and to [Edward]89-edward [she]83-mrs. dashwood gave one with still greater affection . Though [her]83-mrs. dashwood late conversation with [[her]83-mrs. dashwood daughter - in - law]288-her daughter - in - law had made [her]83-mrs. dashwood resolve on remaining at [Norland]3-norland no longer than was unavoidable , it had not produced the smallest effect on [her]83-mrs. dashwood in that point to which it principally tended . To separate [Edward]89-edward and [Elinor]84-elinor was as far from being [her]83-mrs. dashwood object as ever ; and [she]83-mrs. dashwood wished to show [Mrs. John Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood , by this pointed invitation to [[her]83-mrs. dashwood brother]304-her brother , how totally [she]83-mrs. dashwood disregarded [her]83-mrs. dashwood disapprobation of the match .

[Mr. John Dashwood]82-mr. john dashwood told [[his]82-mr. john dashwood mother]234-his mother again and again how exceedingly sorry [he]82-mr. john dashwood was that [she]234-his mother had taken [a house at such a distance from [Norland]3-norland]451-a house at such a distance from norland as to prevent [his]82-mr. john dashwood being of any service to [her]234-his mother in removing [her]234-his mother furniture . [He]82-mr. john dashwood really felt conscientiously vexed on the occasion ; for the very exertion to which [he]82-mr. john dashwood had limited the performance of [his]82-mr. john dashwood promise to [[his]82-mr. john dashwood father]253-his father was by this arrangement rendered impracticable . The furniture was all sent around by water . It chiefly consisted of household linen , plate , china , and books , with a handsome pianoforte of [Marianne]85-marianne s. [Mrs. John Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood saw the packages depart with a sigh : [she]83-mrs. dashwood could not help feeling it hard that as [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood s income would be so trifling in comparison with [their]453-their own , [she]83-mrs. dashwood should have any handsome article of furniture .

[Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood took [the house]281-the house for a twelvemonth ; [it]281-the house was ready furnished , and [she]83-mrs. dashwood might have immediate possession . No difficulty arose on either side in the agreement ; and [she]83-mrs. dashwood waited only for the disposal of [her]83-mrs. dashwood effects at [Norland]3-norland , and to determine [[her]83-mrs. dashwood future household]455-her future household , before [she]83-mrs. dashwood set off for [the west]456-the west ; and this , as [she]83-mrs. dashwood was exceedingly rapid in the performance of everything that interested [her]83-mrs. dashwood , was soon done . The horses which were left [her]83-mrs. dashwood by [[her]83-mrs. dashwood husband]282-her husband had been sold soon after [his]282-her husband death , and an opportunity now offering of disposing of [her]83-mrs. dashwood carriage , [she]83-mrs. dashwood agreed to sell that likewise at the earnest advice of [[her]83-mrs. dashwood eldest daughter]347-her eldest daughter . For the comfort of [[her]83-mrs. dashwood children]459-her children , had [she]83-mrs. dashwood consulted only [her]83-mrs. dashwood own wishes , [she]83-mrs. dashwood would have kept it ; but the discretion of [Elinor]84-elinor prevailed . _ [Her]83-mrs. dashwood _ wisdom too limited the number of [[their]460-their servants]461-their servants to three ; [two maids]462-two maids and [a man]463-a man , with whom [they]460-their were speedily provided from amongst [those who had formed [[their]460-their establishment at [Norland]3-norland]465-their establishment at norland]464-those who had formed their establishment at norland .

[The man]466-the man and [one of [the maids]468-the maids]467-one of the maids were sent off immediately into [Devonshire]5-devonshire , to prepare [the house]281-the house for [[their]460-their mistress]470-their mistress s arrival ; for as [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton was entirely unknown to [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood , [she]95-lady middleton preferred going directly to [the cottage]471-the cottage to being [a visitor at [Barton Park]6-barton park]472-a visitor at barton park ; and [she]95-lady middleton relied so undoubtingly on [Sir John]94-sir john s description of [the house]281-the house , as to feel no curiosity to examine it [herself]95-lady middleton till [she]95-lady middleton entered [it]281-the house as [her]95-lady middleton own . [Her]95-lady middleton eagerness to be gone from [Norland]3-norland was preserved from diminution by the evident satisfaction of [[her]95-lady middleton daughter - in - law]288-her daughter - in - law in the prospect of [her]95-lady middleton removal ; a satisfaction which was but feebly attempted to be concealed under a cold invitation to [her]95-lady middleton to defer [her]95-lady middleton departure . Now was the time when [[her]95-lady middleton son]442-her son - in - law s promise to [[his]442-her son father]253-his father might with particular propriety be fulfilled . Since [he]253-his father had neglected to do it on first coming to [the estate]251-the estate , [their]478-their quitting [[his]253-his father house]479-his house might be looked on as the most suitable period for [its]479-his house accomplishment . But [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood began shortly to give over every hope of the kind , and to be convinced , from the general drift of [his]253-his father discourse , that [his]253-his father assistance extended no farther than [their]478-their maintenance for six months at [Norland]3-norland . [He]253-his father so frequently talked of the increasing expenses of housekeeping , and of the perpetual demands upon [his]253-his father purse , which [a man of any consequence in]480-a man of any consequence in [the world]2697-the world was beyond calculation exposed to , that [he]253-his father seemed rather to stand in need of more money [himself]253-his father than to have any design of giving money away .

In a very few weeks from the day which brought [Sir John Middleton]94-sir john s first letter to [Norland]3-norland , every thing was so far settled in [their]478-their future abode as to enable [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood and [[her]83-mrs. dashwood daughters]258-her daughters to begin [their]478-their journey .

Many were the tears shed by [them]478-their in [their]478-their last adieus to a place so much beloved . " Dear , [dear Norland]3-norland ! "[85-marianne] said [Marianne]85-marianne , as [she]85-marianne wandered alone before [the house]281-the house , on the last evening of [their]478-their being [there]320-there ; " when shall [I]85-marianne cease to regret [you]3-norland ! when learn to feel a home elsewhere ! Oh ! [happy house]2767-happy house , could [you]3-norland know what [I]85-marianne suffer in now viewing [you]3-norland from [this spot]2768-this spot , from whence perhaps [I]85-marianne may view [you]3-norland no more ! And [you]3-norland , [ye]3-norland well - known trees ! but [you]3-norland will continue the same . No leaf will decay because [we]485-they are removed , nor any branch become motionless although [we]485-they can observe [you]3-norland no longer ! No ; [you]3-norland will continue the same ; unconscious of the pleasure or the regret [you]3-norland occasion , and insensible of any change in those who walk under [your]3-norland shade ! But who will remain to enjoy [you]3-norland ? "[85-marianne]

CHAPTER VI .

The first part of [their]485-they journey was performed in too melancholy a disposition to be otherwise than tedious and unpleasant . But as [they]485-they drew towards the end of it , [their]485-they interest in the appearance of [a country which [they]485-they were to inhabit]486-a country which they were to inhabit overcame [their]485-they dejection , and a view of [Barton Valley]10-barton valley as [they]485-they entered [it]10-barton valley gave [them]485-they cheerfulness . [It]10-barton valley was [a pleasant fertile spot , well wooded , and rich in pasture]487-a pleasant fertile spot , well wooded , and rich in pasture . After winding along [it]10-barton valley for more than a mile , [they]485-they reached [[their]485-they own house]488-their own house . [A small green court]489-a small green court was the whole of [[its]488-their own house demesne]490-its demesne in front ; and a neat wicket gate admitted [them]485-they into [it]488-their own house .

As [a house]445-a house , [Barton Cottage]7-barton cottage , though small , was comfortable and compact ; but as [a cottage]420-a cottage [it]7-barton cottage was defective , for [the building]493-the building was regular , the roof was tiled , the window shutters were not painted green , nor were the walls covered with honeysuckles . [A narrow passage]494-a narrow passage led directly through [the house]281-the house into [the garden]496-the garden behind . On each side of the entrance was [a sitting room , about sixteen feet square]497-a sitting room , about sixteen feet square ; and beyond [them]497-a sitting room , about sixteen feet square were [the offices]498-the offices and the stairs . [Four bed - rooms]499-four bed - rooms and two garrets formed the rest of [the house]281-the house . [It]281-the house had not been built many years and was in good repair . In [comparison of [Norland]3-norland]501-comparison of norland , [it]281-the house was poor and small indeed ! but the tears which recollection called forth as [they]485-they entered [the house]281-the house were soon dried away . [They]485-they were cheered by the joy of [the servants]503-the servants on [their]485-they arrival , and [each]504-each for the sake of [the others]505-the others resolved to appear happy . It was very early in September ; the season was fine , and from first seeing [the place]430-the place under the advantage of good weather , [they]485-they received an impression in [its]281-the house favour which was of material service in recommending [it]281-the house to [their]485-they lasting approbation .

The situation of [the house]281-the house was good . [High hills]508-high hills rose immediately behind , and at no great distance on each side ; some of which were open downs , the others cultivated and woody . [The village of]509-the village of [Barton]8-barton was chiefly on [one of these hills]510-one of these hills , and formed a pleasant view from [the cottage]471-the cottage windows . The prospect in front was more extensive ; it commanded [the whole of [the valley]513-the valley]512-the whole of the valley , and reached into [the country beyond]514-the country beyond . [The hills which surrounded [the cottage]471-the cottage]515-the hills which surrounded the cottage terminated [the valley]513-the valley in that direction ; under another name , and in another course , [it]515-the hills which surrounded the cottage branched out again between [two of the steepest of them]518-two of the steepest of them .

With the size and furniture of [the house]281-the house [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood was upon the whole well satisfied ; for though [her]83-mrs. dashwood former style of life rendered many additions to the latter indispensable , yet to add and improve was a delight to [her]83-mrs. dashwood ; and [she]83-mrs. dashwood had at this time ready money enough to supply all that was wanted of greater elegance to [the apartments]520-the apartments . " As for [the house itself]2769-the house itself , to be sure , "[83-mrs. dashwood] said [she]83-mrs. dashwood , " [it]2769-the house itself is too small for [[our]2770-our family]2771-our family , but [we]2770-our will make [ourselves]2770-our tolerably comfortable for the present , as it is too late in the year for improvements . Perhaps in the spring , if [I]83-mrs. dashwood have plenty of money , as [I]83-mrs. dashwood dare say [I]83-mrs. dashwood shall , [we]2770-our may think about building . [These parlors]2772-these parlors are both too small for such parties of [[our]2770-our friends]2773-our friends as [I]83-mrs. dashwood hope to see often collected [here]2721-here ; and [I]83-mrs. dashwood have some thoughts of throwing the passage into one of them with perhaps a part of the other , and so leave the remainder of that other for an entrance ; this , with [a new drawing room which may be easily added , and a bed - chamber and garret above]2775-a new drawing room which may be easily added , and a bed - chamber and garret above , will make [it]2769-the house itself [a very snug little cottage]2776-a very snug little cottage . [I]83-mrs. dashwood could wish the stairs were handsome . But [one]2680-one must not expect every thing ; though [I]83-mrs. dashwood suppose it would be no difficult matter to widen them . [I]83-mrs. dashwood shall see how much [I]83-mrs. dashwood am before - hand with [the world]2697-the world in the spring , and [we]2779-we will plan [our]2779-we improvements accordingly . "[83-mrs. dashwood]

In the mean time , till all these alterations could be made from the savings of an income of five hundred a - year by [a woman who never saved in [her]521-a woman who never saved in her life life]521-a woman who never saved in her life , [they]522-their were wise enough to be contented with [the house]281-the house as [it]281-the house was ; and [each of [them]522-their]524-each of them was busy in arranging [their]522-their particular concerns , and endeavoring , by placing around [them]522-their books and other possessions , to form [themselves]522-their a [home]525-home . [Marianne]85-marianne s pianoforte was unpacked and properly disposed of ; and [Elinor]84-elinor s drawings were affixed to the walls of [[their]522-their sitting room]526-their sitting room .

In such employments as these [they]522-their were interrupted soon after breakfast the next day by the entrance of [[their]522-their landlord]527-their landlord , who called to welcome [them]522-their to [Barton]8-barton , and to offer [them]522-their every accommodation from [[his]527-their landlord own house]528-his own house and garden in which [theirs]522-their might at present be deficient . [Sir John Middleton]94-sir john was [a good looking man about forty]529-a good looking man about forty . [He]94-sir john had formerly visited at [Stanhill]4-stanhill , but it was too long for [[his]94-sir john young cousins]530-his young cousins to remember [him]94-sir john . [His]94-sir john countenance was thoroughly good - humoured ; and [his]94-sir john manners were as friendly as the style of [his]94-sir john letter . [Their]522-their arrival seemed to afford [him]94-sir john real satisfaction , and [their]522-their comfort to be an object of real solicitude to [him]94-sir john . [He]94-sir john said much of [his]94-sir john earnest desire of [their]522-their living in the most sociable terms with [[his]94-sir john family]531-his family , and pressed [them]522-their so cordially to dine at [Barton Park]6-barton park every day till [they]522-their were better settled at [home]525-home , that , though [his]94-sir john entreaties were carried to a point of perseverance beyond civility , [they]522-their could not give offence .
