[His]94-sir john kindness was not confined to words ; for within an hour after [he]94-sir john left [them]522-their , a large basket full of garden stuff and fruit arrived from [the park]533-the park , which was followed before the end of the day by a present of game . [He]94-sir john insisted , moreover , on conveying all [their]522-their letters to and from the post for [them]522-their , and would not be denied the satisfaction of sending [them]522-their [his]94-sir john newspaper every day .

[Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton had sent a very civil message by [him]94-sir john , denoting [her]95-lady middleton intention of waiting on [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood as soon as [she]95-lady middleton could be assured that [her]95-lady middleton visit would be no inconvenience ; and as this message was answered by an invitation equally polite , [[her]95-lady middleton ladyship]534-her ladyship was introduced to [them]522-their the next day .

[They]522-their were , of course , very anxious to see [a person on whom so much of [their]522-their comfort at [Barton]8-barton]535-a person on whom so much of their comfort at barton must depend ; and the elegance of [her]95-lady middleton appearance was favourable to [their]522-their wishes . [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton was not more than six or seven and twenty ; [her]95-lady middleton face was handsome , [her]95-lady middleton figure tall and striking , and [her]95-lady middleton address graceful . [Her]95-lady middleton manners had all the elegance which [[her]95-lady middleton husband]282-her husband s wanted . But [they]522-their would have been improved by some share of [his]282-her husband frankness and warmth ; and [her]95-lady middleton visit was long enough to detract something from [their]522-their first admiration , by showing that , though perfectly well - bred , [she]95-lady middleton was reserved , cold , and had nothing to say for [herself]95-lady middleton beyond the most common - place inquiry or remark .

Conversation however was not wanted , for [Sir John]94-sir john was very chatty , and [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton had taken the wise precaution of bringing with [her]95-lady middleton [[their]522-their eldest child]537-their eldest child , [a fine little boy about six years old]538-a fine little boy about six years old , by which means there was one subject always to be recurred to by [the ladies]539-the ladies in case of extremity , for [they]539-the ladies had to enquire [his]282-her husband name and age , admire [his]282-her husband beauty , and ask [him]282-her husband questions which [[his]282-her husband mother]234-his mother answered for [him]282-her husband , while [he]282-her husband hung about [her]95-lady middleton and held down [his]282-her husband head , to the great surprise of [[her]95-lady middleton ladyship]534-her ladyship , who wondered at [his]282-her husband being so shy before company , as [he]282-her husband could make noise enough at [home]525-home . On every formal visit [a child]543-a child ought to be of [the party]544-the party , by way of provision for discourse . In the present case it took up ten minutes to determine whether [the boy]545-the boy were most like [[his]545-the boy father]253-his father or [mother]254-mother , and in what particular [he]545-the boy resembled either , for of course every body differed , and [every body]548-every body was astonished at the opinion of [the others]505-the others .

An opportunity was soon to be given to the Dashwoods of debating on [the rest of [the children]228-the children]550-the rest of the children , as [Sir John]94-sir john would not leave [the house]281-the house without securing [their]228-the children promise of dining at [the park]533-the park the next day .

CHAPTER VII .

[Barton Park]6-barton park was about half a mile from [the cottage]471-the cottage . [The ladies]539-the ladies had passed near [it]6-barton park in [their]539-the ladies way along [the valley]513-the valley , but [it]6-barton park was screened from [their]539-the ladies view at [home]525-home by the projection of [a hill]558-a hill . [The house]281-the house was large and handsome ; and [the Middletons]97-the middletons lived in a style of equal hospitality and elegance . The former was for [Sir John]94-sir john s gratification , the latter for that of [[his]94-sir john lady]560-his lady . [They]228-the children were scarcely ever without [some friends]561-some friends staying with [them]228-the children in [the house]281-the house , and [they]228-the children kept more company of every kind than [any other family in [the neighbourhood]322-the neighbourhood]563-any other family in the neighbourhood . It was necessary to the happiness of [both]565-both ; for however dissimilar in temper and outward behaviour , [they]228-the children strongly resembled [each other]303-each other in that total want of talent and taste which confined [their]228-the children employments , unconnected with such as society produced , within a very narrow compass . [Sir John]94-sir john was [a sportsman]567-a sportsman , [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton [a mother]568-a mother . [He]94-sir john hunted and shot , and [she]95-lady middleton humoured [[her]95-lady middleton children]459-her children ; and these were [their]228-the children only resources . [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton had the advantage of being able to spoil [[her]95-lady middleton children]459-her children all the year round , while [Sir John]94-sir john s independent employments were in existence only half the time . Continual engagements at [home]525-home and abroad , however , supplied all the deficiencies of nature and education ; supported the good spirits of [Sir John]94-sir john , and gave exercise to the good breeding of [[his]94-sir john wife]245-his wife .

[Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton piqued [herself]95-lady middleton upon the elegance of [her]95-lady middleton table , and of all [her]95-lady middleton domestic arrangements ; and from this kind of vanity was [her]95-lady middleton greatest enjoyment in any of [their]573-their parties . But [Sir John]94-sir john s satisfaction in society was much more real ; [he]94-sir john delighted in collecting about [him]94-sir john [more young people than [[his]94-sir john house]479-his house would hold]574-more young people than his house would hold , and the noisier [they]574-more young people than his house would hold were the better was [he]94-sir john pleased . [He]94-sir john was a blessing to [all the juvenile part of [the neighbourhood]322-the neighbourhood]576-all the juvenile part of the neighbourhood , for in summer [he]94-sir john was for ever forming parties to eat cold ham and chicken out of doors , and in winter [his]94-sir john private balls were numerous enough for [any young lady who was not suffering under the unsatiable appetite of fifteen]578-any young lady who was not suffering under the unsatiable appetite of fifteen .

The arrival of [a new family]579-a new family in [the country]580-the country was always a matter of joy to [him]94-sir john , and in every point of view [he]94-sir john was charmed with [the inhabitants [he]94-sir john had now procured for [[his]94-sir john cottage at [Barton]8-barton]582-his cottage at barton]581-the inhabitants he had now procured for his cottage at barton . [The Miss Dashwoods]87-the miss dashwoods were young , pretty , and unaffected . It was enough to secure [his]94-sir john good opinion ; for to be unaffected was all that [a pretty girl]583-a pretty girl could want to make [her]583-a pretty girl mind as captivating as [[her]583-a pretty girl person]584-her person . The friendliness of [his]94-sir john disposition made [him]94-sir john happy in accommodating [those , whose situation might be considered , in comparison with the past , as unfortunate]585-those , whose situation might be considered , in comparison with the past , as unfortunate . In showing kindness to [[his]94-sir john cousins]586-his cousins therefore [he]94-sir john had the real satisfaction of a good heart ; and in settling [a family of females]587-a family of females only in [[his]94-sir john cottage]588-his cottage , [he]94-sir john had all the satisfaction of [a sportsman]567-a sportsman ; for [a sportsman]567-a sportsman , though [he]94-sir john esteems only those of [his]94-sir john sex who are [sportsmen]591-sportsmen likewise , is not often desirous of encouraging [their]586-his cousins taste by admitting [them]586-his cousins to [a residence within [[his]94-sir john own manor]593-his own manor]592-a residence within his own manor .

[Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood and [[her]83-mrs. dashwood daughters]258-her daughters were met at the door of [the house]281-the house by [Sir John]94-sir john , who welcomed [them]586-his cousins to [Barton Park]6-barton park with unaffected sincerity ; and as [he]94-sir john attended [them]586-his cousins to [the drawing room]596-the drawing room repeated to [the young ladies]597-the young ladies the concern which the same subject had drawn from [him]94-sir john the day before , at being unable to get [any smart young men]598-any smart young men to meet [them]586-his cousins . [They]597-the young ladies would see , [he]94-sir john said , [only one gentleman there besides [himself]94-sir john]599-only one gentleman there besides himself ; [a particular friend who was staying at [the park]533-the park , but who was neither very young nor very gay]600-a particular friend who was staying at the park , but who was neither very young nor very gay . [He]94-sir john hoped [they]597-the young ladies would all excuse the smallness of the party , and could assure [them]597-the young ladies it should never happen so again . [He]94-sir john had been to [several families]602-several families that morning in hopes of procuring [some addition to [their]602-several families number]603-some addition to their number , but it was moonlight and [every body]548-every body was full of engagements . [Luckily [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton s mother]605-luckily lady middleton s mother had arrived at [Barton]8-barton within the last hour , and as [she]605-luckily lady middleton s mother was [a very cheerful agreeable woman]606-a very cheerful agreeable woman , [he]94-sir john hoped [the young ladies]597-the young ladies would not find it so very dull as [they]597-the young ladies might imagine . [The young ladies]597-the young ladies , as well as [[their]597-the young ladies mother]239-their mother , were perfectly satisfied with having [two entire strangers of the party]610-two entire strangers of the party , and wished for no more .

[Mrs. Jennings]98-mrs. jennings , [[Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton s mother]611-lady middleton s mother , was [a good - humoured , merry , fat , elderly woman]612-a good - humoured , merry , fat , elderly woman , who talked a great deal , seemed very happy , and rather vulgar . [She]98-mrs. jennings was full of jokes and laughter , and before dinner was over had said many witty things on the subject of [lovers]613-lovers and [husbands]614-husbands ; hoped [they]597-the young ladies had not left [their]597-the young ladies hearts behind [them]597-the young ladies in [Sussex]1-sussex , and pretended to see [them]597-the young ladies blush whether [they]597-the young ladies did or not . [Marianne]85-marianne was vexed at it for [[her]85-marianne sister]301-her sister s sake , and turned [her]85-marianne eyes towards [Elinor]84-elinor to see how [she]84-elinor bore these attacks , with an earnestness which gave [Elinor]84-elinor far more pain than could arise from such common - place raillery as [Mrs. Jennings]98-mrs. jennings s.

[Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon , [the friend of [Sir John]617-sir john]616-the friend of sir john , seemed no more adapted by resemblance of manner to be [[his]99-colonel brandon friend]618-his friend , than [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton was to be [[his]99-colonel brandon wife]245-his wife , or [Mrs. Jennings]98-mrs. jennings to be [[Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton s mother]611-lady middleton s mother . [He]99-colonel brandon was silent and grave . [His]99-colonel brandon appearance however was not unpleasing , in spite of [his]99-colonel brandon being in the opinion of [Marianne]85-marianne and [Margaret]86-margaret [an absolute old bachelor]621-an absolute old bachelor , for [he]99-colonel brandon was on the wrong side of five and thirty ; but though [his]99-colonel brandon face was not handsome , [his]99-colonel brandon countenance was sensible , and [his]99-colonel brandon address was particularly gentlemanlike .

There was nothing in any of the party which could recommend [them]622-them as [[companions]623-companions to [the Dashwoods]87-the miss dashwoods]624-companions to the dashwoods ; but the cold insipidity of [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton was so particularly repulsive , that in comparison of it the gravity of [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon , and even the boisterous mirth of [Sir John]94-sir john and [[his]94-sir john mother - in - law]264-his mother - in - law was interesting . [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton seemed to be roused to enjoyment only by the entrance of [[her]95-lady middleton four noisy children]626-her four noisy children after dinner , who pulled [her]95-lady middleton about , tore [her]95-lady middleton clothes , and put an end to every kind of discourse except what related to [themselves]626-her four noisy children .

In the evening , as [Marianne]85-marianne was discovered to be musical , [she]85-marianne was invited to play . The instrument was unlocked , every body prepared to be charmed , and [Marianne]85-marianne , who sang very well , at [their]626-her four noisy children request went through the chief of the songs which [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton had brought into [the family]267-the family on [her]95-lady middleton marriage , and which perhaps had lain ever since in the same position on the pianoforte , for [[her]85-marianne ladyship]534-her ladyship had celebrated that event by giving up music , although by [[her]85-marianne mother]296-her mother s account , [she]85-marianne had played extremely well , and by [her]85-marianne own was very fond of it .

[Marianne]85-marianne s performance was highly applauded . [Sir John]94-sir john was loud in [his]94-sir john admiration at the end of every song , and as loud in [his]94-sir john conversation with [the others]505-the others while every song lasted . [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton frequently called [him]94-sir john to order , wondered how [any one]631-any one s attention could be diverted from music for a moment , and asked [Marianne]85-marianne to sing a particular song which [Marianne]85-marianne had just finished . [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon alone , of [all the party]632-all the party , heard [her]85-marianne without being in raptures . [He]99-colonel brandon paid [her]85-marianne only the compliment of attention ; and [she]85-marianne felt a respect for [him]99-colonel brandon on the occasion , which [the others]505-the others had reasonably forfeited by [their]505-the others shameless want of taste . [His]99-colonel brandon pleasure in music , though it amounted not to that ecstatic delight which alone could sympathize with [her]85-marianne own , was estimable when contrasted against the horrible insensibility of the others ; and [she]85-marianne was reasonable enough to allow that [a man of five and thirty]634-a man of five and thirty might well have outlived all acuteness of feeling and every exquisite power of enjoyment . [She]85-marianne was perfectly disposed to make every allowance for [the colonel]635-the colonel s advanced state of life which humanity required .

CHAPTER VIII .

[Mrs. Jennings]98-mrs. jennings was [a widow with an ample jointure]636-a widow with an ample jointure . [She]98-mrs. jennings had only [two daughters]637-two daughters , both of whom [she]98-mrs. jennings had lived to see respectably married , and [she]98-mrs. jennings had now therefore nothing to do but to marry [all the rest of [the world]2697-the world]638-all the rest of the world . In the promotion of this object [she]98-mrs. jennings was zealously active , as far as [her]98-mrs. jennings ability reached ; and missed no opportunity of projecting weddings among [all [the young people of]641-the young people of [her]98-mrs. jennings acquaintance]640-all the young people of her acquaintance . [She]98-mrs. jennings was remarkably quick in the discovery of attachments , and had enjoyed the advantage of raising the blushes and the vanity of [many a young lady]642-many a young lady by insinuations of [her]98-mrs. jennings power over [such a young man]643-such a young man ; and this kind of discernment enabled [her]98-mrs. jennings soon after [her]98-mrs. jennings arrival at [Barton]8-barton decisively to pronounce that [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon was very much in love with [Marianne Dashwood]85-marianne . [She]98-mrs. jennings rather suspected it to be so , on the very first evening of [their]644-them being together , from [his]99-colonel brandon listening so attentively while [she]98-mrs. jennings sang to [them]644-them ; and when the visit was returned by [the Middletons]97-the middletons dining at [the cottage]471-the cottage , the fact was ascertained by [his]99-colonel brandon listening to [her]98-mrs. jennings again . It must be so . [She]98-mrs. jennings was perfectly convinced of it . It would be an excellent match , for _ [he]99-colonel brandon _ was rich , and _ [she]98-mrs. jennings _ was handsome . [Mrs. Jennings]98-mrs. jennings had been anxious to see [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon well married , ever since [her]98-mrs. jennings connection with [Sir John]94-sir john first brought [him]99-colonel brandon to [her]98-mrs. jennings knowledge ; and [she]98-mrs. jennings was always anxious to get [a good husband]646-a good husband for [every pretty girl]647-every pretty girl .

The immediate advantage to [herself]98-mrs. jennings was by no means inconsiderable , for it supplied [her]98-mrs. jennings with endless jokes against [them]644-them both . At [the park]533-the park [she]98-mrs. jennings laughed at [the colonel]635-the colonel , and in [the cottage]471-the cottage at [Marianne]85-marianne . To the former [her]98-mrs. jennings raillery was probably , as far as it regarded only [himself]635-the colonel , perfectly indifferent ; but to the latter it was at first incomprehensible ; and when its object was understood , [she]98-mrs. jennings hardly knew whether most to laugh at its absurdity , or censure its impertinence , for [she]98-mrs. jennings considered it as an unfeeling reflection on [the colonel]635-the colonel s advanced years , and on [his]635-the colonel forlorn condition as [an old bachelor]652-an old bachelor .

[Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood , who could not think [a man five years younger than [herself]83-mrs. dashwood , so exceedingly ancient as [he]635-the colonel appeared to the youthful fancy of [[her]83-mrs. dashwood daughter]371-her daughter]653-a man five years younger than herself , so exceedingly ancient as he appeared to the youthful fancy of her daughter , ventured to clear [Mrs. Jennings]98-mrs. jennings from the probability of wishing to throw ridicule on [his]635-the colonel age .

" But at least , [Mama]90-mama , [you]90-mama can not deny the absurdity of the accusation , though [you]90-mama may not think it intentionally ill - natured . [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon is certainly younger than [Mrs. Jennings]98-mrs. jennings , but [he]99-colonel brandon is old enough to be _ [[my]653-a man five years younger than herself , so exceedingly ancient as he appeared to the youthful fancy of her daughter _ father]2780-my _ father ; and if [he]99-colonel brandon were ever animated enough to be in love , must have long outlived every sensation of the kind . It is too ridiculous ! When is [a man]463-a man to be safe from such wit , if age and infirmity will not protect [him]463-a man ? "[653-a man five years younger than herself , so exceedingly ancient as he appeared to the youthful fancy of her daughter]

" Infirmity ! "[84-elinor] said [Elinor]84-elinor , " do [you]90-mama call [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon infirm ? [I]84-elinor can easily suppose that [his]99-colonel brandon age may appear much greater to [you]90-mama than to [[my]84-elinor mother]2691-my mother ; but [you]90-mama can hardly deceive [yourself]90-mama as to [his]99-colonel brandon having the use of [his]99-colonel brandon limbs ! "[84-elinor]

" Did not [you]90-mama hear [him]99-colonel brandon complain of the rheumatism ? and is not that the commonest infirmity of declining life ? "[653-a man five years younger than herself , so exceedingly ancient as he appeared to the youthful fancy of her daughter]

" [[My]296-her mother dearest child]2783-my dearest child , "[296-her mother] said [[her]84-elinor mother]296-her mother , laughing , " at this rate [you]2783-my dearest child must be in continual terror of _ [my]296-her mother _ decay ; and it must seem to [you]2783-my dearest child a miracle that [my]296-her mother life has been extended to the advanced age of forty . "[296-her mother]

" [Mama]90-mama , [you]90-mama are not doing [me]653-a man five years younger than herself , so exceedingly ancient as he appeared to the youthful fancy of her daughter justice . [I]653-a man five years younger than herself , so exceedingly ancient as he appeared to the youthful fancy of her daughter know very well that [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon is not old enough to make [[his]99-colonel brandon friends]2784-his friends yet apprehensive of losing [him]99-colonel brandon in the course of nature . [He]99-colonel brandon may live twenty years longer . But thirty - five has nothing to do with matrimony . "[653-a man five years younger than herself , so exceedingly ancient as he appeared to the youthful fancy of her daughter]

" Perhaps , "[84-elinor] said [Elinor]84-elinor , " thirty - five and seventeen had better not have any thing to do with matrimony together . But if there should by any chance happen to be [a woman who is single at seven and twenty]2785-a woman who is single at seven and twenty , [I]84-elinor should not think [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon s being thirty - five any objection to [his]99-colonel brandon marrying _ [her]2785-a woman who is single at seven and twenty _ . "[84-elinor]

" [A woman of seven and twenty]2786-a woman of seven and twenty , "[85-marianne] said [Marianne]85-marianne , after pausing a moment , " can never hope to feel or inspire affection again , and if [her]2786-a woman of seven and twenty home be uncomfortable , or [her]2786-a woman of seven and twenty fortune small , [I]85-marianne can suppose that [she]2786-a woman of seven and twenty might bring [herself]2786-a woman of seven and twenty to submit to the offices of [a nurse]2787-a nurse , for the sake of the provision and security of [a wife]2788-a wife . In [his]99-colonel brandon marrying [such a woman]434-such a woman therefore there would be nothing unsuitable . It would be a compact of convenience , and [the world]2697-the world would be satisfied . In [my]85-marianne eyes it would be no marriage at all , but that would be nothing . To [me]85-marianne it would seem only a commercial exchange , in which each wished to be benefited at the expense of the other . "[85-marianne]

" It would be impossible , [I]84-elinor know , "[84-elinor] replied [Elinor]84-elinor , " to convince [you]85-marianne that [a woman of seven and twenty]2786-a woman of seven and twenty could feel for [a man of thirty - five anything near enough to love]2792-a man of thirty - five anything near enough to love , to make [him]99-colonel brandon [a desirable companion to [her]2786-a woman of seven and twenty]2793-a desirable companion to her . But [I]84-elinor must object to [your]85-marianne dooming [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon and [[his]99-colonel brandon wife]245-his wife to the constant confinement of [a sick chamber]2795-a sick chamber , merely because [he]99-colonel brandon chanced to complain yesterday ( a very cold damp day ) of a slight rheumatic feel in one of [his]99-colonel brandon shoulders . "[84-elinor]

" But [he]99-colonel brandon talked of flannel waistcoats , "[85-marianne] said [Marianne]85-marianne ; " and with [me]85-marianne a flannel waistcoat is invariably connected with aches , cramps , rheumatisms , and every species of ailment that can afflict [the old]2796-the old and the feeble . "[85-marianne]

" Had [he]99-colonel brandon been only in a violent fever , [you]85-marianne would not have despised [him]99-colonel brandon half so much . Confess , [Marianne]85-marianne , is not there something interesting to [you]85-marianne in the flushed cheek , hollow eye , and quick pulse of a fever ? "[85-marianne]

Soon after this , upon [Elinor]84-elinor s leaving [the room]2756-the room , " [Mama]90-mama , "[85-marianne] said [Marianne]85-marianne , " [I]85-marianne have an alarm on the subject of illness which [I]85-marianne can not conceal from [you]90-mama . [I]85-marianne am sure [Edward Ferrars]89-edward is not well . [We]2797-we have now been [here]2721-here almost a fortnight , and yet [he]99-colonel brandon does not come . Nothing but real indisposition could occasion this extraordinary delay . What else can detain [him]99-colonel brandon at [Norland]3-norland ? "[85-marianne]

" Had [you]85-marianne any idea of [his]99-colonel brandon coming so soon ? "[83-mrs. dashwood] said [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood . " _ [I]83-mrs. dashwood _ had none . On the contrary , if [I]83-mrs. dashwood have felt any anxiety at all on the subject , it has been in recollecting that [he]99-colonel brandon sometimes showed a want of pleasure and readiness in accepting [my]83-mrs. dashwood invitation , when [I]83-mrs. dashwood talked of [his]99-colonel brandon coming to [Barton]8-barton . Does [Elinor]84-elinor expect [him]99-colonel brandon already ? "[83-mrs. dashwood]

" [I]85-marianne have never mentioned it to [her]84-elinor , but of course [she]84-elinor must . "[85-marianne]

" [I]83-mrs. dashwood rather think [you]85-marianne are mistaken , for when [I]83-mrs. dashwood was talking to [her]84-elinor yesterday of getting a new grate for [the spare bedchamber]2799-the spare bedchamber , [she]84-elinor observed that there was no immediate hurry for it , as it was not likely that [the room]2756-the room would be wanted for some time . "[83-mrs. dashwood]

" How strange this is ! what can be the meaning of it ! But the whole of [their]2801-their behaviour to [each other]303-each other has been unaccountable ! How cold , how composed were [their]2801-their last adieus ! How languid [their]2801-their conversation the last evening of [their]2801-their being together ! In [Edward]89-edward s farewell there was no distinction between [Elinor]84-elinor and [me]85-marianne : it was the good wishes of [an affectionate brother]2803-an affectionate brother to both . Twice did [I]85-marianne leave [them]2801-their purposely together in the course of the last morning , and each time did [he]89-edward most unaccountably follow [me]85-marianne out of [the room]2756-the room . And [Elinor]84-elinor , in quitting [Norland]3-norland and [Edward]89-edward , cried not as [I]85-marianne did . Even now [her]84-elinor self - command is invariable . When is [she]84-elinor dejected or melancholy ? When does [she]84-elinor try to avoid society , or appear restless and dissatisfied in it ? "[85-marianne]

CHAPTER IX .

[The Dashwoods]87-the miss dashwoods were now settled at [Barton]8-barton with tolerable comfort to [themselves]87-the miss dashwoods . [The house]281-the house and [the garden]496-the garden , with all the objects surrounding [them]659-them , were now become familiar , and the ordinary pursuits which had given to [Norland]3-norland half its charms were engaged in again with far greater enjoyment than [Norland]3-norland had been able to afford , since the loss of [[their]659-them father]237-their father . [Sir John Middleton]94-sir john , who called on [them]659-them [every day for the first fortnight , and who was not in the habit of seeing much occupation at]661-every day for the first fortnight , and who was not in the habit of seeing much occupation at [home]525-home , could not conceal [his]94-sir john amazement on finding [them]659-them always employed .

[[Their]659-them visitors]663-their visitors , except [those from [Barton Park]6-barton park]664-those from barton park , were not many ; for , in spite of [Sir John]94-sir john s urgent entreaties that [they]659-them would mix more in [the neighbourhood]322-the neighbourhood , and repeated assurances of [his]94-sir john carriage being always at [their]659-them service , the independence of [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood s spirit overcame the wish of society for [[her]83-mrs. dashwood children]459-her children ; and [she]83-mrs. dashwood was resolute in declining to visit [any family beyond the distance of a walk]667-any family beyond the distance of a walk . There were but [few who could be so classed]668-few who could be so classed ; and it was not all of [them]668-few who could be so classed that were attainable . About a mile and a half from [the cottage]471-the cottage , along [the narrow winding valley of [Allenham]11-allenham]670-the narrow winding valley of allenham , which issued from [that of [Barton]8-barton]671-that of barton , as formerly described , [the girls]2708-the girls had , in one of [their]2708-the girls earliest walks , discovered [an ancient respectable looking mansion]673-an ancient respectable looking mansion which , by reminding [them]2708-the girls a little of [Norland]3-norland , interested [their]2708-the girls imagination and made [them]2708-the girls wish to be better acquainted with it . But [they]2708-the girls learnt , on enquiry , that [its possessor]674-its possessor , [an elderly lady of very good character]675-an elderly lady of very good character , was unfortunately too infirm to mix with [the world]2697-the world , and never stirred from [home]525-home .

[The whole country]678-the whole country about [them]2708-the girls abounded in beautiful walks . The high downs which invited [them]2708-the girls from almost every window of [the cottage]471-the cottage to seek the exquisite enjoyment of air on [their]2708-the girls summits , were a happy alternative when the dirt of [the valleys beneath]680-the valleys beneath shut up [their]2708-the girls superior beauties ; and towards one of [these hills]681-these hills did [Marianne]85-marianne and [Margaret]86-margaret one memorable morning direct [their]2708-the girls steps , attracted by the partial sunshine of a showery sky , and unable longer to bear the confinement which the settled rain of the two preceding days had occasioned . The weather was not tempting enough to draw [the two others]682-the two others from [their]2708-the girls pencil and [their]2708-the girls book , in spite of [Marianne]85-marianne s declaration that the day would be lastingly fair , and that every threatening cloud would be drawn off from [[their]2708-the girls hills]683-their hills ; and [the two girls]684-the two girls set off together .

[They]2708-the girls gaily ascended [the downs]685-the downs , rejoicing in [their]2708-the girls own penetration at every glimpse of blue sky ; and when [they]2708-the girls caught in [their]2708-the girls faces the animating gales of a high south - westerly wind , [they]2708-the girls pitied the fears which had prevented [[their]2708-the girls mother]239-their mother and [Elinor]84-elinor from sharing such delightful sensations .

" Is there a felicity in [the world]2697-the world , "[85-marianne] said [Marianne]85-marianne , " superior to this ? [Margaret]86-margaret , [we]2708-the girls will walk [here]2721-here at least two hours . "[85-marianne]

[Margaret]86-margaret agreed , and [they]2708-the girls pursued [their]2708-the girls way against the wind , resisting it with laughing delight for about twenty minutes longer , when suddenly the clouds united over [their]2708-the girls heads , and a driving rain set full in [their]2708-the girls face . Chagrined and surprised , [they]2708-the girls were obliged , though unwillingly , to turn back , for no shelter was nearer than [[their]2708-the girls own house]488-their own house . One consolation however remained for [them]2708-the girls , to which the exigence of the moment gave more than usual propriety , it was that of running with all possible speed down [the steep side of [the hill]689-the hill]688-the steep side of the hill which led immediately to [[their]2708-the girls garden gate]690-their garden gate .

[They]2708-the girls set off . [Marianne]85-marianne had at first the advantage , but a false step brought [her]85-marianne suddenly to the ground ; and [Margaret]86-margaret , unable to stop [herself]86-margaret to assist [her]85-marianne , was involuntarily hurried along , and reached the bottom in safety .

[A gentleman carrying a gun , with two pointers playing round [him]691-a gentleman carrying a gun , with two pointers playing round him]691-a gentleman carrying a gun , with two pointers playing round him , was passing up [the hill]689-the hill and within a few yards of [Marianne]85-marianne , when [her]85-marianne accident happened . [He]691-a gentleman carrying a gun , with two pointers playing round him put down [his]691-a gentleman carrying a gun , with two pointers playing round him gun and ran to [her]85-marianne assistance . [She]85-marianne had raised [herself]85-marianne from the ground , but [her]85-marianne foot had been twisted in [her]85-marianne fall , and [she]85-marianne was scarcely able to stand . [The gentleman]693-the gentleman offered [his]693-the gentleman services ; and perceiving that [her]85-marianne modesty declined what [her]85-marianne situation rendered necessary , took [her]85-marianne up in [his]693-the gentleman arms without farther delay , and carried [her]85-marianne down [the hill]689-the hill . Then passing through [the garden]496-the garden , the gate of which had been left open by [Margaret]86-margaret , [he]693-the gentleman bore [her]85-marianne directly into [the house]281-the house , whither [Margaret]86-margaret was just arrived , and quitted not [his]693-the gentleman hold till [he]693-the gentleman had seated [her]85-marianne in a chair in [the parlour]697-the parlour .

[Elinor]84-elinor and [[her]84-elinor mother]296-her mother rose up in amazement at [their]699-their entrance , and while the eyes of both were fixed on [him]693-the gentleman with an evident wonder and a secret admiration which equally sprung from [his]693-the gentleman appearance , [he]693-the gentleman apologized for [his]693-the gentleman intrusion by relating its cause , in a manner so frank and so graceful that [[his]693-the gentleman person]2753-his person , which was uncommonly handsome , received additional charms from [his]693-the gentleman voice and expression . Had [he]693-the gentleman been even old , ugly , and vulgar , the gratitude and kindness of [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood would have been secured by any act of attention to [[her]83-mrs. dashwood child]242-her child ; but the influence of youth , beauty , and elegance , gave an interest to the action which came home to [her]83-mrs. dashwood feelings .

[She]83-mrs. dashwood thanked [him]693-the gentleman again and again ; and , with a sweetness of address which always attended [her]83-mrs. dashwood , invited [him]693-the gentleman to be seated . But this [he]693-the gentleman declined , as [he]693-the gentleman was dirty and wet . [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood then begged to know to whom [she]83-mrs. dashwood was obliged . [His]693-the gentleman name , [he]693-the gentleman replied , was [Willoughby]101-willoughby , and [[his]693-the gentleman present home]702-his present home was at [Allenham]11-allenham , from whence [he]693-the gentleman hoped [she]83-mrs. dashwood would allow [him]693-the gentleman the honour of calling tomorrow to enquire after [Miss Dashwood]79-miss dashwood . The honour was readily granted , and [he]693-the gentleman then departed , to make [himself]693-the gentleman still more interesting , in the midst of a heavy rain .

[His]693-the gentleman manly beauty and more than common gracefulness were instantly the theme of general admiration , and the laugh which [his]693-the gentleman gallantry raised against [Marianne]85-marianne received particular spirit from [his]693-the gentleman exterior attractions . [Marianne]85-marianne [herself]85-marianne had seen less of [his]693-the gentleman person than the rest , for the confusion which crimsoned over [her]85-marianne face , on [his]693-the gentleman lifting [her]85-marianne up , had robbed [her]85-marianne of the power of regarding [him]693-the gentleman after [their]703-their entering [the house]281-the house . But [she]85-marianne had seen enough of [him]693-the gentleman to join in all the admiration of [the others]505-the others , and with an energy which always adorned [her]85-marianne praise . [His]693-the gentleman person and air were equal to what [her]85-marianne fancy had ever drawn for [the hero of a favourite story]706-the hero of a favourite story ; and in [his]693-the gentleman carrying [her]85-marianne into [the house]281-the house with so little previous formality , there was a rapidity of thought which particularly recommended the action to [her]85-marianne . Every circumstance belonging to [him]693-the gentleman was interesting . [His]693-the gentleman name was good , [[his]693-the gentleman residence]708-his residence was in [[their]703-their favourite village]709-their favourite village , and [she]85-marianne soon found out that of all manly dresses a shooting - jacket was the most becoming . [Her]85-marianne imagination was busy , [her]85-marianne reflections were pleasant , and the pain of a sprained ankle was disregarded .

[Sir John]94-sir john called on [them]703-their as soon as the next interval of fair weather that morning allowed [him]94-sir john to get out of doors ; and [Marianne]85-marianne s accident being related to [him]94-sir john , [he]94-sir john was eagerly asked whether [he]94-sir john knew [any gentleman of the name of [Willoughby]101-willoughby at [Allenham]11-allenham]710-any gentleman of the name of willoughby at allenham .

" [Willoughby]101-willoughby ! "[94-sir john] cried [Sir John]94-sir john ; " what , is _ [he]101-willoughby _ in [the country]580-the country ? That is good news however ; [I]94-sir john will ride over tomorrow , and ask [him]101-willoughby to dinner on Thursday . "[94-sir john]

" [You]94-sir john know [him]101-willoughby then , "[83-mrs. dashwood] said [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood .

" Know [him]101-willoughby ! to be sure [I]710-any gentleman of the name of willoughby at allenham do . Why , [he]101-willoughby is down [here]2721-here every year . "[710-any gentleman of the name of willoughby at allenham]

" And what sort of [a young man]388-a young man is [he]101-willoughby ? "[710-any gentleman of the name of willoughby at allenham]

" As good [a kind of fellow as ever lived]2810-a kind of fellow as ever lived , [I]710-any gentleman of the name of willoughby at allenham assure [you]94-sir john . [A very decent shot]2811-a very decent shot , and there is not [a bolder rider in [England]12-england]2812-a bolder rider in england . "[710-any gentleman of the name of willoughby at allenham]

" And is _ that _ all [you]94-sir john can say for [him]101-willoughby ? "[85-marianne] cried [Marianne]85-marianne , indignantly . " But what are [his]101-willoughby manners on more intimate acquaintance ? What [his]101-willoughby pursuits , [his]101-willoughby talents , and genius ? "[85-marianne]

[Sir John]94-sir john was rather puzzled .

" Upon [my]94-sir john soul , "[94-sir john] said [he]94-sir john , " [I]94-sir john do not know much about [him]101-willoughby as to all _ that _ . But [he]101-willoughby is [a pleasant , good humoured fellow]2813-a pleasant , good humoured fellow , and has got [the nicest little black bitch of a pointer [I]94-sir john ever saw]2814-the nicest little black bitch of a pointer i ever saw . Was [she]2814-the nicest little black bitch of a pointer i ever saw out with [him]101-willoughby today ? "[94-sir john]

But [Marianne]85-marianne could no more satisfy [him]94-sir john as to the colour of [Mr. Willoughby]101-willoughby s pointer , than [he]94-sir john could describe to [her]85-marianne the shades of [his]94-sir john mind .

" But who is [he]101-willoughby ? "[84-elinor] said [Elinor]84-elinor . " Where does [he]101-willoughby come from ? Has [he]101-willoughby [a house at [Allenham]11-allenham]2815-a house at allenham ? "[84-elinor]

On this point [Sir John]94-sir john could give more certain intelligence ; and [he]94-sir john told [them]711-you that [Mr. Willoughby]101-willoughby had no property of [his]101-willoughby own in [the country]580-the country ; that [he]101-willoughby resided [there]320-there only while [he]101-willoughby was visiting [the old lady at [Allenham Court]13-allenham court]714-the old lady at allenham court , to whom [he]101-willoughby was related , and whose possessions [he]101-willoughby was to inherit ; adding , " Yes , yes , [he]101-willoughby is very well worth catching [I]94-sir john can tell [you]711-you , [Miss Dashwood]79-miss dashwood ; [he]101-willoughby has [a pretty little estate of [his]101-willoughby own in [Somersetshire]14-somersetshire besides]2816-a pretty little estate of his own in somersetshire besides ; and if [I]94-sir john were [you]711-you , [I]94-sir john would not give [him]101-willoughby up to [[my]94-sir john younger sister]2817-my younger sister , in spite of all this tumbling down [hills]2818-hills . [Miss Marianne]85-marianne must not expect to have all [the men]2819-the men to [herself]85-marianne . [Brandon]99-colonel brandon will be jealous , if [she]85-marianne does not take care . "[94-sir john]

" [I]83-mrs. dashwood do not believe , "[83-mrs. dashwood] said [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood , with a good humoured smile , " that [Mr. Willoughby]101-willoughby will be incommoded by the attempts of [either of [_ [my]83-mrs. dashwood _ daughters]2821-_ my _ daughters]2820-either of _ my _ daughters towards what [you]711-you call _ catching [him]101-willoughby _ . It is not an employment to which [they]2821-_ my _ daughters have been brought up . [Men]2822-men are very safe with [us]2823-us , let [them]2822-men be ever so rich . [I]83-mrs. dashwood am glad to find , however , from what [you]94-sir john say , that [he]101-willoughby is [a respectable young man]2824-a respectable young man , and [one whose acquaintance will not be ineligible]2825-one whose acquaintance will not be ineligible . "[83-mrs. dashwood]

" [He]101-willoughby is as good a sort of fellow , [I]94-sir john believe , as ever lived , "[94-sir john] repeated [Sir John]94-sir john . " [I]94-sir john remember last Christmas at a little hop at [the park]533-the park , [he]101-willoughby danced from eight o clock till four , without once sitting down . "[94-sir john]

" Did [he]101-willoughby indeed ? "[85-marianne] cried [Marianne]85-marianne with sparkling eyes , " and with elegance , with spirit ? "[85-marianne]

" Yes ; and [he]101-willoughby was up again at eight to ride to covert . "[83-mrs. dashwood]

" That is what [I]85-marianne like ; that is what [a young man]388-a young man ought to be . Whatever be [his]388-a young man pursuits , [his]388-a young man eagerness in [them]2828-their should know no moderation , and leave [him]388-a young man no sense of fatigue . "[85-marianne]

" Aye , aye , [I]94-sir john see how it will be , "[94-sir john] said [Sir John]94-sir john , " [I]94-sir john see how it will be . [You]94-sir john will be setting [your]94-sir john cap at [him]101-willoughby now , and never think of poor [Brandon]99-colonel brandon . "[94-sir john]

" That is an expression , [Sir John]94-sir john , "[85-marianne] said [Marianne]85-marianne , warmly , " which [I]85-marianne particularly dislike . [I]85-marianne abhor every common - place phrase by which wit is intended ; and setting one s cap at [a man]463-a man , or making a conquest , are the most odious of all . [Their]2828-their tendency is gross and illiberal ; and if [their]2828-their construction could ever be deemed clever , time has long ago destroyed all its ingenuity . "[85-marianne]

[Sir John]94-sir john did not much understand this reproof ; but [he]94-sir john laughed as heartily as if [he]94-sir john did , and then replied ,

" Ay , [you]94-sir john will make conquests enough , [I]94-sir john dare say , one way or other . [Poor Brandon]102-poor brandon ! [he]99-colonel brandon is quite smitten already , and [he]99-colonel brandon is very well worth setting [your]94-sir john cap at , [I]94-sir john can tell [you]94-sir john , in spite of all this tumbling about and spraining of ankles . "[94-sir john]

CHAPTER X.

[Marianne]85-marianne s preserver , as [Margaret]86-margaret , with more elegance than precision , styled [Willoughby]101-willoughby , called at [the cottage]471-the cottage early the next morning to make [his]101-willoughby personal enquiries . [He]101-willoughby was received by [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood with more than politeness ; with a kindness which [Sir John]94-sir john s account of [him]101-willoughby and [her]83-mrs. dashwood own gratitude prompted ; and every thing that passed during the visit tended to assure [him]101-willoughby of the sense , elegance , mutual affection , and domestic comfort of [the family to whom accident had now introduced [him]101-willoughby]716-the family to whom accident had now introduced him . Of [their]717-their personal charms [he]101-willoughby had not required a second interview to be convinced .

[Miss Dashwood]79-miss dashwood had a delicate complexion , regular features , and a remarkably pretty figure . [Marianne]85-marianne was still handsomer . [Her]85-marianne form , though not so correct as [[her]85-marianne sister]301-her sister s , in having the advantage of height , was more striking ; and [her]85-marianne face was so lovely , that when in the common ca nt of praise , [she]85-marianne was called [a beautiful girl]719-a beautiful girl , truth was less violently outraged than usually happens . [Her]85-marianne skin was very brown , but , from its transparency , [her]85-marianne complexion was uncommonly brilliant ; [her]85-marianne features were all good ; [her]85-marianne smile was sweet and attractive ; and in [her]85-marianne eyes , which were very dark , there was a life , a spirit , an eagerness , which could hardly be seen without delight . From [Willoughby]101-willoughby [their]717-their expression was at first held back , by the embarrassment which the remembrance of [his]101-willoughby assistance created . But when this passed away , when [her]85-marianne spirits became collected , when [she]85-marianne saw that to the perfect good - breeding of [the gentleman]693-the gentleman , [he]693-the gentleman united frankness and vivacity , and above all , when [she]85-marianne heard [him]693-the gentleman declare , that of music and dancing [he]693-the gentleman was passionately fond , [she]85-marianne gave [him]693-the gentleman such a look of approbation as secured the largest share of [his]693-the gentleman discourse to [herself]85-marianne for the rest of [his]693-the gentleman stay .

It was only necessary to mention any favourite amusement to engage [her]85-marianne to talk . [She]85-marianne could not be silent when such points were introduced , and [she]85-marianne had neither shyness nor reserve in [their]717-their discussion . [They]717-their speedily discovered that [their]717-their enjoyment of dancing and music was mutual , and that it arose from a general conformity of judgment in all that related to either . Encouraged by this to a further examination of [his]693-the gentleman opinions , [she]85-marianne proceeded to question [him]693-the gentleman on the subject of books ; [[her]85-marianne favourite authors]721-her favourite authors were brought forward and dwelt upon with so rapturous a delight , that [any young man of five and twenty]722-any young man of five and twenty must have been insensible indeed , not to become an immediate convert to the excellence of such works , however disregarded before . [Their]717-their taste was strikingly alike . The same books , the same passages were idolized by each or if any difference appeared , any objection arose , it lasted no longer than till the force of [her]85-marianne arguments and the brightness of [her]85-marianne eyes could be displayed . [He]693-the gentleman acquiesced in all [her]85-marianne decisions , caught all [her]85-marianne enthusiasm ; and long before [his]693-the gentleman visit concluded , [they]717-their conversed with the familiarity of [a long - established acquaintance]723-a long - established acquaintance .

" Well , [Marianne]85-marianne , "[84-elinor] said [Elinor]84-elinor , as soon as [he]693-the gentleman had left [them]717-their , " for _ one _ morning [I]84-elinor think [you]85-marianne have done pretty well . [You]85-marianne have already ascertained [Mr. Willoughby]101-willoughby s opinion in almost every matter of importance . [You]85-marianne know what [he]101-willoughby thinks of [Cowper]92-cowper and [Scott]103-scott ; [you]85-marianne are certain of [his]101-willoughby estimating [their]717-their beauties as [he]101-willoughby ought , and [you]85-marianne have received every assurance of [his]101-willoughby admiring Pope no more than is proper . But how is [your]85-marianne acquaintance to be long supported , under such extraordinary despatch of every subject for discourse ? [You]85-marianne will soon have exhausted each favourite topic . Another meeting will suffice to explain [his]101-willoughby sentiments on picturesque beauty , and second marriages , and then [you]85-marianne can have nothing farther to ask . "[84-elinor]

" [Elinor]84-elinor , "[85-marianne] cried [Marianne]85-marianne , " is this fair ? is this just ? are [my]85-marianne ideas so scanty ? But [I]85-marianne see what [you]84-elinor mean . [I]85-marianne have been too much at [my]85-marianne ease , too happy , too frank . [I]85-marianne have erred against every common - place notion of decorum ; [I]85-marianne have been open and sincere where [I]85-marianne ought to have been reserved , spiritless , dull , and deceitful had [I]85-marianne talked only of the weather and [the roads]2830-the roads , and had [I]85-marianne spoken only once in ten minutes , this reproach would have been spared . "[85-marianne]

" [[My]296-her mother love]2700-my love , "[296-her mother] said [[her]85-marianne mother]296-her mother , " [you]2700-my love must not be offended with [Elinor]84-elinor [she]84-elinor was only in jest . [I]296-her mother should scold [her]84-elinor [myself]296-her mother , if [she]84-elinor were capable of wishing to check the delight of [your]2700-my love conversation with [[our]725-they new friend]2832-our new friend . "[296-her mother] [Marianne]85-marianne was softened in a moment .

[Willoughby]101-willoughby , on [his]101-willoughby side , gave every proof of [his]101-willoughby pleasure in [their]725-they acquaintance , which an evident wish of improving it could offer . [He]101-willoughby came to [them]725-they every day . To enquire after [Marianne]85-marianne was at first [his]101-willoughby excuse ; but the encouragement of [his]101-willoughby reception , to which every day gave greater kindness , made such an excuse unnecessary before it had ceased to be possible , by [Marianne]85-marianne s perfect recovery . [She]85-marianne was confined for some days to [the house]281-the house ; but never had any confinement been less irksome . [Willoughby]101-willoughby was [a young man of good abilities , quick imagination , lively spirits , and open , affectionate manners]727-a young man of good abilities , quick imagination , lively spirits , and open , affectionate manners . [He]101-willoughby was exactly formed to engage [Marianne]85-marianne s heart , for with all this , [he]101-willoughby joined not only [a captivating person]728-a captivating person , but a natural ardour of mind which was now roused and increased by the example of [her]85-marianne own , and which recommended [him]101-willoughby to [her]85-marianne affection beyond every thing else .

[His]101-willoughby society became gradually [her]85-marianne most exquisite enjoyment . [They]725-they read , [they]725-they talked , [they]725-they sang together ; [his]101-willoughby musical talents were considerable ; and [he]101-willoughby read with all the sensibility and spirit which [Edward]89-edward had unfortunately wanted .

In [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood s estimation [he]101-willoughby was as faultless as in [Marianne]85-marianne s ; and [Elinor]84-elinor saw nothing to censure in [him]101-willoughby but a propensity , in which [he]101-willoughby strongly resembled and peculiarly delighted [[her]84-elinor sister]301-her sister , of saying too much what [he]101-willoughby thought on every occasion , without attention to [persons]730-persons or circumstances . In hastily forming and giving [his]101-willoughby opinion of [other people]287-other people , in sacrificing general politeness to the enjoyment of undivided attention where [his]101-willoughby heart was engaged , and in slighting too easily the forms of worldly propriety , [he]101-willoughby displayed a want of caution which [Elinor]84-elinor could not approve , in spite of all that [he]101-willoughby and [Marianne]85-marianne could say in its support .

[Marianne]85-marianne began now to perceive that the desperation which had seized [her]85-marianne at sixteen and a half , of ever seeing [a man who could satisfy [her]85-marianne ideas of perfection]732-a man who could satisfy her ideas of perfection , had been rash and unjustifiable . [Willoughby]101-willoughby was all that [her]85-marianne fancy had delineated in that unhappy hour and in every brighter period , as capable of attaching [her]85-marianne ; and [his]101-willoughby behaviour declared [his]101-willoughby wishes to be in that respect as earnest , as [his]101-willoughby abilities were strong .

[[Her]85-marianne mother]296-her mother too , in whose mind not one speculative thought of [their]734-their marriage had been raised , by [his]101-willoughby prospect of riches , was led before the end of a week to hope and expect it ; and secretly to congratulate [herself]296-her mother on having gained [two such sons - in - law]735-two such sons - in - law as [Edward]89-edward and [Willoughby]101-willoughby .

[Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon s partiality for [Marianne]85-marianne , which had so early been discovered by [[his]99-colonel brandon friends]2784-his friends , now first became perceptible to [Elinor]84-elinor , when it ceased to be noticed by [them]2784-his friends . [Their]2784-his friends attention and wit were drawn off to [[his]99-colonel brandon more fortunate rival]737-his more fortunate rival ; and the raillery which [the other]738-the other had incurred before any partiality arose , was removed when [his]99-colonel brandon feelings began really to call for the ridicule so justly annexed to sensibility . [Elinor]84-elinor was obliged , though unwillingly , to believe that the sentiments which [Mrs. Jennings]98-mrs. jennings had assigned [him]101-willoughby for [her]98-mrs. jennings own satisfaction , were now actually excited by [[her]98-mrs. jennings sister]301-her sister ; and that however a general resemblance of disposition between the parties might forward the affection of [Mr. Willoughby]101-willoughby , an equally striking opposition of character was no hindrance to the regard of [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon . [She]84-elinor saw it with concern ; for what could [a silent man of five and thirty hope , when opposed to a very lively one of five and twenty]740-a silent man of five and thirty hope , when opposed to a very lively one of five and twenty ? and as [she]84-elinor could not even wish [him]101-willoughby successful , [she]84-elinor heartily wished [him]101-willoughby indifferent . [She]84-elinor liked [him]101-willoughby in spite of [his]101-willoughby gravity and reserve , [she]84-elinor beheld in [him]101-willoughby an object of interest . [His]101-willoughby manners , though serious , were mild ; and [his]101-willoughby reserve appeared rather the result of some oppression of spirits than of any natural gloominess of temper . [Sir John]94-sir john had dropped hints of past injuries and disappointments , which justified [her]84-elinor belief of [his]101-willoughby being [an unfortunate man]741-an unfortunate man , and [she]84-elinor regarded [him]101-willoughby with respect and compassion .

Perhaps [she]84-elinor pitied and esteemed [him]101-willoughby the more because [he]101-willoughby was slighted by [Willoughby]101-willoughby and [Marianne]85-marianne , who , prejudiced against [him]101-willoughby for being neither lively nor young , seemed resolved to undervalue [his]101-willoughby merits .

" [Brandon]99-colonel brandon is just [the kind of man]2833-the kind of man , "[101-willoughby] said [Willoughby]101-willoughby one day , when [they]742-they were talking of [him]101-willoughby together , " whom every body speaks well of , and [nobody]2834-nobody cares about ; whom [all]2835-all are delighted to see , and [nobody]2834-nobody remembers to talk to . "[101-willoughby]

" That is exactly what [I]85-marianne think of [him]101-willoughby , "[85-marianne] cried [Marianne]85-marianne .

" Do not boast of it , however , "[84-elinor] said [Elinor]84-elinor , " for it is injustice in both of [you]742-they . [He]101-willoughby is highly esteemed by [all [the family]267-the family at [the park]533-the park]2837-all the family at the park , and [I]84-elinor never see [him]101-willoughby [myself]84-elinor without taking pains to converse with [him]101-willoughby . "[84-elinor]

" That [he]101-willoughby is patronised by _ [you]85-marianne _ , "[101-willoughby] replied [Willoughby]101-willoughby , " is certainly in [his]101-willoughby favour ; but as for the esteem of [the others]505-the others , it is a reproach in itself . Who would submit to the indignity of being approved by [such a woman]434-such a woman as [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton and [Mrs. Jennings]98-mrs. jennings , that could command the indifference of [any body else]2842-any body else ? "[101-willoughby]

" But perhaps the abuse of [such people]2843-such people as [yourself]85-marianne and [Marianne]85-marianne will make amends for the regard of [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton and [[her]95-lady middleton mother]296-her mother . If [their]2843-such people praise is censure , [your]85-marianne censure may be praise , for [they]2843-such people are not more undiscerning , than [you]85-marianne are prejudiced and unjust . "[101-willoughby]

" In defence of [your]85-marianne _ prot g _ [you]85-marianne can even be saucy . "[101-willoughby]

" [My]101-willoughby _ prot g _ , as [you]85-marianne call [him]101-willoughby , is [a sensible man]2845-a sensible man ; and sense will always have attractions for [me]101-willoughby . Yes , [Marianne]85-marianne , even in [a man between thirty and forty]2846-a man between thirty and forty . [He]101-willoughby has seen a great deal of [the world]2697-the world ; has been abroad , has read , and has a thinking mind . [I]101-willoughby have found [him]101-willoughby capable of giving [me]101-willoughby much information on various subjects ; and [he]101-willoughby has always answered [my]101-willoughby inquiries with readiness of good - breeding and good nature . "[101-willoughby]

" That is to say , "[85-marianne] cried [Marianne]85-marianne contemptuously , " [he]101-willoughby has told [you]85-marianne , that in [the East Indies]15-the east indies the climate is hot , and the mosquitoes are troublesome . "[85-marianne]

" [He]101-willoughby _ would _ have told [me]101-willoughby so , [I]101-willoughby doubt not , had [I]101-willoughby made any such inquiries , but they happened to be points on which [I]101-willoughby had been previously informed . "[101-willoughby]

" Perhaps , "[101-willoughby] said [Willoughby]101-willoughby , " [his]101-willoughby observations may have extended to the existence of nabobs , gold mohrs , and [palanquins]2848-palanquins . "[101-willoughby]

" [I]101-willoughby may venture to say that _ [his]101-willoughby _ observations have stretched much further than _ [your]85-marianne _ candour . But why should [you]85-marianne dislike [him]101-willoughby ? "[101-willoughby]

" [I]101-willoughby do not dislike [him]101-willoughby . [I]101-willoughby consider [him]101-willoughby , on the contrary , as [a very respectable man , who has every body s good word , and nobody s notice]2849-a very respectable man , who has every body s good word , and nobody s notice ; who has more money than [he]101-willoughby can spend , more time than [he]101-willoughby knows how to employ , and two new coats every year . "[101-willoughby]

" Add to which , "[85-marianne] cried [Marianne]85-marianne , " that [he]101-willoughby has neither genius , taste , nor spirit . That [his]101-willoughby understanding has no brilliancy , [his]101-willoughby feelings no ardour , and [his]101-willoughby voice no expression . "[85-marianne]

" [You]85-marianne decide on [his]101-willoughby imperfections so much in the mass , "[84-elinor] replied [Elinor]84-elinor , " and so much on the strength of [your]85-marianne own imagination , that the commendation _ [I]84-elinor _ am able to give of [him]101-willoughby is comparatively cold and insipid . [I]84-elinor can only pronounce [him]101-willoughby to be [a sensible man , well - bred , well - informed , of gentle address]2850-a sensible man , well - bred , well - informed , of gentle address , and , [I]84-elinor believe , possessing an amiable heart . "[84-elinor]

" [Miss Dashwood]79-miss dashwood , "[101-willoughby] cried [Willoughby]101-willoughby , " [you]79-miss dashwood are now using [me]101-willoughby unkindly . [You]79-miss dashwood are endeavouring to disarm [me]101-willoughby by reason , and to convince [me]101-willoughby against [my]101-willoughby will . But it will not do . [You]79-miss dashwood shall find [me]101-willoughby as stubborn as [you]79-miss dashwood can be artful . [I]101-willoughby have three unanswerable reasons for disliking [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon ; [he]101-willoughby threatened [me]101-willoughby with rain when [I]101-willoughby wanted it to be fine ; [he]101-willoughby has found fault with the hanging of [my]101-willoughby curricle , and [I]101-willoughby can not persuade [him]101-willoughby to buy [my]101-willoughby brown mare . If it will be any satisfaction to [you]79-miss dashwood , however , to be told , that [I]101-willoughby believe [his]101-willoughby character to be in other respects irreproachable , [I]101-willoughby am ready to confess it . And in return for an acknowledgment , which must give [me]101-willoughby some pain , [you]79-miss dashwood can not deny [me]101-willoughby the privilege of disliking [him]101-willoughby as much as ever . "[101-willoughby]

CHAPTER XI .

[Little]104-little had [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood or [[her]83-mrs. dashwood daughters]258-her daughters imagined when [they]744-they first came into [Devonshire]5-devonshire , that so many engagements would arise to occupy [their]744-they time as shortly presented [themselves]744-they , or that [they]744-they should have such frequent invitations and such constant visitors as to leave [them]744-they little leisure for serious employment . Yet such was the case . When [Marianne]85-marianne was recovered , the schemes of amusement at [home]525-home and abroad , which [Sir John]94-sir john had been previously forming , were put into execution . The private balls at [the park]533-the park then began ; and parties on the water were made and accomplished as often as a showery October would allow . In every meeting of the kind [Willoughby]101-willoughby was included ; and the ease and familiarity which naturally attended these parties were exactly calculated to give increasing intimacy to [his]101-willoughby acquaintance with [the Dashwoods]87-the miss dashwoods , to afford [him]101-willoughby opportunity of witnessing the excellencies of [Marianne]85-marianne , of marking [his]101-willoughby animated admiration of [her]85-marianne , and of receiving , in [her]85-marianne behaviour to [himself]101-willoughby , the most pointed assurance of [her]85-marianne affection .

[Elinor]84-elinor could not be surprised at [their]747-their attachment . [She]84-elinor only wished that it were less openly shown ; and once or twice did venture to suggest the propriety of some self - command to [Marianne]85-marianne . But [Marianne]85-marianne abhorred all concealment where no real disgrace could attend unreserve ; and to aim at the restraint of sentiments which were not in themselves illaudable , appeared to [her]84-elinor not merely an unnecessary effort , but a disgraceful subjection of reason to common - place and mistaken notions . [Willoughby]101-willoughby thought the same ; and [their]747-their behaviour at all times , was an illustration of [their]747-their opinions .

When [he]101-willoughby was present [she]84-elinor had no eyes for [any one else]748-any one else . Every thing [he]101-willoughby did , was right . Every thing [he]101-willoughby said , was clever . If [their]747-their evenings at [the park]533-the park were concluded with cards , [he]101-willoughby cheated [himself]101-willoughby and all the rest of [the party]544-the party to get [her]84-elinor a good hand . If dancing formed the amusement of the night , [they]747-their were [partners]751-partners for half the time ; and when obliged to separate for a couple of dances , were careful to stand together and scarcely spoke a word to [any body else]2842-any body else . Such conduct made [them]747-their of course most exceedingly laughed at ; but ridicule could not shame , and seemed hardly to provoke [them]747-their .

[Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood entered into all [their]747-their feelings with a warmth which left [her]83-mrs. dashwood no inclination for checking this excessive display of them . To [her]83-mrs. dashwood it was but the natural consequence of a strong affection in [a young and ardent mind]753-a young and ardent mind .

This was the season of happiness to [Marianne]85-marianne . [Her]83-mrs. dashwood heart was devoted to [Willoughby]101-willoughby , and the fond attachment to [Norland]3-norland , which [she]83-mrs. dashwood brought with [her]83-mrs. dashwood from [Sussex]1-sussex , was more likely to be softened than [she]83-mrs. dashwood had thought it possible before , by the charms which [[his]101-willoughby society]754-his society bestowed on [[her]83-mrs. dashwood present home]755-her present home .

[Elinor]84-elinor s happiness was not so great . [Her]84-elinor heart was not so much at ease , nor [her]84-elinor satisfaction in [their]747-their amusements so pure . [They]747-their afforded [her]84-elinor no companion that could make amends for what [she]84-elinor had left behind , nor that could teach [her]84-elinor to think of [Norland]3-norland with less regret than ever . Neither [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton nor [Mrs. Jennings]98-mrs. jennings could supply to [her]84-elinor the conversation [she]84-elinor missed ; although the latter was [an everlasting talker]756-an everlasting talker , and from the first had regarded [her]84-elinor with a kindness which ensured [her]84-elinor a large share of [her]84-elinor discourse . [She]84-elinor had already repeated [her]84-elinor own history to [Elinor]84-elinor three or four times ; and had [Elinor]84-elinor s memory been equal to [her]84-elinor means of improvement , [she]84-elinor might have known very early in [their]747-their acquaintance all the particulars of [Mr. Jennings]105-mr. jennings s last illness , and what [he]105-mr. jennings said to [[his]105-mr. jennings wife]245-his wife a few minutes before [he]105-mr. jennings died . [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton was more agreeable than [[her]84-elinor mother]296-her mother only in being more silent . [Elinor]84-elinor needed little observation to perceive that [her]84-elinor reserve was a mere calmness of manner with which sense had nothing to do . Towards [[her]84-elinor husband]282-her husband and [mother]254-mother [she]84-elinor was the same as to [them]747-their ; and intimacy was therefore neither to be looked for nor desired . [She]84-elinor had nothing to say one day that [she]84-elinor had not said the day before . [Her]84-elinor insipidity was invariable , for even [her]84-elinor spirits were always the same ; and though [she]84-elinor did not oppose the parties arranged by [[her]84-elinor husband]282-her husband , provided every thing were conducted in style and [[her]84-elinor two eldest children]762-her two eldest children attended [her]84-elinor , [she]84-elinor never appeared to receive more enjoyment from [them]747-their than [she]84-elinor might have experienced in sitting at [home]525-home ; and so little did [her]84-elinor presence add to the pleasure of [the others]505-the others , by any share in [their]505-the others conversation , that [they]505-the others were sometimes only reminded of [her]84-elinor being amongst [them]505-the others by [her]84-elinor solicitude about [[her]84-elinor troublesome boys]765-her troublesome boys .

In [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon alone , of all [[her]84-elinor new acquaintance]766-her new acquaintance , did [Elinor]84-elinor find [a person who could in any degree claim the respect of abilities , excite the interest of friendship , or give pleasure as a companion]767-a person who could in any degree claim the respect of abilities , excite the interest of friendship , or give pleasure as a companion . [Willoughby]101-willoughby was out of the question . [Her]84-elinor admiration and regard , even [her]84-elinor sisterly regard , was all [his]99-colonel brandon own ; but [he]99-colonel brandon was [a lover]2736-a lover ; [his]99-colonel brandon attentions were wholly [Marianne]85-marianne s , and [a far less agreeable man]769-a far less agreeable man might have been more generally pleasing . [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon , unfortunately for [himself]99-colonel brandon , had no such encouragement to think only of [Marianne]85-marianne , and in conversing with [Elinor]84-elinor [he]99-colonel brandon found the greatest consolation for the indifference of [[her]84-elinor sister]301-her sister .

[Elinor]84-elinor s compassion for [him]99-colonel brandon increased , as [she]84-elinor had reason to suspect that the misery of disappointed love had already been known to [him]99-colonel brandon . This suspicion was given by some words which accidentally dropped from [him]99-colonel brandon one evening at [the park]533-the park , when [they]772-they were sitting down together by mutual consent , while [the others]505-the others were dancing . [His]99-colonel brandon eyes were fixed on [Marianne]85-marianne , and , after a silence of some minutes , [he]99-colonel brandon said , with a faint smile , " [[Your]84-elinor sister]2730-your sister , [I]99-colonel brandon understand , does not approve of second attachments . "[99-colonel brandon]

" No , "[84-elinor] replied [Elinor]84-elinor , " [her]2730-your sister opinions are all romantic . "[84-elinor]

" Or rather , as [I]99-colonel brandon believe , [she]2730-your sister considers them impossible to exist . "[99-colonel brandon]

" [I]84-elinor believe [she]2730-your sister does . But how [she]2730-your sister contrives it without reflecting on the character of [[her]2730-your sister own father]2852-her own father , who had [[himself]2852-her own father two wives]2853-himself two wives , [I]84-elinor know not . A few years however will settle [her]2730-your sister opinions on the reasonable basis of common sense and observation ; and then they may be more easy to define and to justify than they now are , by any body but [herself]2730-your sister . "[84-elinor]

" This will probably be the case , "[99-colonel brandon] [he]99-colonel brandon replied ; " and yet there is something so amiable in the prejudices of [a young mind]2854-a young mind , that [one]2680-one is sorry to see [them]2856-them give way to the reception of more general opinions . "[99-colonel brandon]

" [I]84-elinor can not agree with [you]99-colonel brandon there , "[84-elinor] said [Elinor]84-elinor . " There are inconveniences attending such feelings as [Marianne]85-marianne s , which all the charms of enthusiasm and ignorance of [the world]2697-the world can not atone for . [Her]2730-your sister systems have all the unfortunate tendency of setting propriety at nought ; and a better acquaintance with [the world]2697-the world is what [I]84-elinor look forward to as [her]2730-your sister greatest possible advantage . "[84-elinor]

After a short pause [he]99-colonel brandon resumed the conversation by saying ,

" Does [[your]84-elinor sister]2730-your sister make no distinction in [her]2730-your sister objections against a second attachment ? or is it equally criminal in every body ? Are those who have been disappointed in [their]2860-their first choice , whether from the inconstancy of its object , or the perverseness of circumstances , to be equally indifferent during the rest of [their]2860-their lives ? "[99-colonel brandon]

" Upon [my]99-colonel brandon word , [I]99-colonel brandon am not acquainted with the minutiae of [her]2730-your sister principles . [I]99-colonel brandon only know that [I]99-colonel brandon never yet heard [her]2730-your sister admit any instance of a second attachment s being pardonable . "[99-colonel brandon]

" This , "[99-colonel brandon] said [he]99-colonel brandon , " can not hold ; but a change , a total change of sentiments No , no , do not desire it ; for when the romantic refinements of a young mind are obliged to give way , how frequently are [they]2861-they succeeded by such opinions as are but too common , and too dangerous ! [I]99-colonel brandon speak from experience . [I]99-colonel brandon once knew [a lady who in temper and mind greatly resembled [[your]99-colonel brandon sister]2730-your sister , who thought and judged like [her]336-the lady , but [who from an enforced change from a series of unfortunate circumstances]2864-who from an enforced change from a series of unfortunate circumstances]2862-a lady who in temper and mind greatly resembled your sister , who thought and judged like her , but who from an enforced change from a series of unfortunate circumstances "[99-colonel brandon] Here [he]99-colonel brandon stopt suddenly ; appeared to think that [he]99-colonel brandon had said too much , and by [his]99-colonel brandon countenance gave rise to conjectures , which might not otherwise have entered [Elinor]84-elinor s head . [The lady]336-the lady would probably have passed without suspicion , had [he]99-colonel brandon not convinced [Miss Dashwood]79-miss dashwood that what concerned [her]336-the lady ought not to escape [his]99-colonel brandon lips . As it was , it required but a slight effort of fancy to connect [his]99-colonel brandon emotion with the tender recollection of past regard . [Elinor]84-elinor attempted no more . But [Marianne]85-marianne , in [her]85-marianne place , would not have done so little . The whole story would have been speedily formed under [her]84-elinor active imagination ; and every thing established in the most melancholy order of disastrous love .

CHAPTER XII .

As [Elinor]84-elinor and [Marianne]85-marianne were walking together the next morning [the latter]289-the latter communicated a piece of news to [[her]84-elinor sister]301-her sister , which in spite of all that [she]84-elinor knew before of [Marianne]85-marianne s imprudence and want of thought , surprised [her]84-elinor by its extravagant testimony of both . [Marianne]85-marianne told [her]84-elinor , with the greatest delight , that [Willoughby]101-willoughby had given [her]84-elinor a horse , one that [he]101-willoughby had bred [himself]101-willoughby on [[his]101-willoughby estate in [Somersetshire]14-somersetshire]777-his estate in somersetshire , and which was exactly calculated to carry [a woman]778-a woman . Without considering that it was not in [[her]84-elinor mother]296-her mother s plan to keep any horse , that if [she]84-elinor were to alter [her]84-elinor resolution in favour of this gift , [she]84-elinor must buy another for [the servant]780-the servant , and keep [a servant to ride it]781-a servant to ride it , and after all , build [a stable to receive]782-a stable to receive [them]783-them , [she]84-elinor had accepted the present without hesitation , and told [[her]84-elinor sister]301-her sister of it in raptures .

" [He]101-willoughby intends to send [[his]101-willoughby groom]2865-his groom into [Somersetshire]14-somersetshire immediately for it , "[84-elinor] [she]84-elinor added , " and when it arrives [we]2866-we will ride every day . [You]301-her sister shall share its use with [me]84-elinor . Imagine to [yourself]301-her sister , [[my]84-elinor dear]2669-my dear [Elinor]84-elinor , the delight of a gallop on [some of [these downs]2869-these downs]2868-some of these downs . "[84-elinor]

Most unwilling was [she]84-elinor to awaken from such a dream of felicity to comprehend all the unhappy truths which attended the affair ; and for some time [she]84-elinor refused to submit to them . As to [an additional servant]785-an additional servant , the expense would be a trifle ; [Mama]90-mama [she]90-mama was sure would never object to it ; and any horse would do for _ [him]786-him ; _ [he]786-him might always get one at [the park]533-the park ; as to [a stable]788-a stable , the merest shed would be sufficient . [Elinor]84-elinor then ventured to doubt the propriety of [her]84-elinor receiving such a present from [a man so little]789-a man so little , or at least so lately known to [her]84-elinor . This was too much .

" [You]301-her sister are mistaken , [Elinor]84-elinor , "[84-elinor] said [she]84-elinor warmly , " in supposing [I]84-elinor know very little of [Willoughby]101-willoughby . [I]84-elinor have not known [him]101-willoughby long indeed , but [I]84-elinor am much better acquainted with [him]101-willoughby , than [I]84-elinor am with any other creature in [the world]2697-the world , except [yourself]301-her sister and [mama]2741-mama . It is not time or opportunity that is to determine intimacy ; it is disposition alone . Seven years would be insufficient to make [some people]2872-some people acquainted with [each other]303-each other , and seven days are more than enough for [others]2874-others . [I]84-elinor should hold [myself]84-elinor guilty of greater impropriety in accepting a horse from [[my]84-elinor brother]2875-my brother , than from [Willoughby]101-willoughby . Of [John]83-mrs. dashwood [I]84-elinor know very little , though [we]2876-we have lived together for years ; but of [Willoughby]101-willoughby [my]84-elinor judgment has long been formed . "[84-elinor]
