" Yes , a great while ; ever since [[my]1114-i sister]2733-my sister married . [He]99-colonel brandon was a particular friend of [Sir John]94-sir john s. [I]1114-i believe , "[1114-i] [she]1114-i added in a low voice , " [he]99-colonel brandon would have been very glad to have had [me]1114-i , if [he]99-colonel brandon could . [Sir John]94-sir john and [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton wished it very much . But [mama]2741-mama did not think the match good enough for [me]1114-i , otherwise [Sir John]94-sir john would have mentioned it to [the Colonel]635-the colonel , and [we]3238-we should have been married immediately . "[1114-i]

" Did not [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon know of [Sir John]94-sir john s proposal to [[your]1114-i mother]2698-your mother before it was made ? Had [he]99-colonel brandon never owned [his]99-colonel brandon affection to [yourself]1114-i ? "[120-mrs. palmer]

" Oh , no ; but if [mama]2741-mama had not objected to it , [I]1114-i dare say [he]99-colonel brandon would have liked it of all things . [He]99-colonel brandon had not seen [me]1114-i then above twice , for it was before [I]1114-i left [school]3241-school . However , [I]1114-i am much happier as [I]1114-i am . [Mr. Palmer]121-mr. palmer is [the kind of man [I]1114-i like]3242-the kind of man i like . "[1114-i]

CHAPTER XXI .

[The Palmers]118-the palmers returned to [Cleveland]28-cleveland the next day , and [the two families]1115-the two families at [Barton]8-barton were again left to entertain [each other]303-each other . But this did not last long ; [Elinor]84-elinor had hardly got [their]118-the palmers last visitors out of [her]84-elinor head , had hardly done wondering at [Charlotte]119-charlotte s being so happy without a cause , at [Mr. Palmer]121-mr. palmer s acting so simply , with good abilities , and at the strange unsuitableness which often existed between [husband]1117-husband and [wife]1118-wife , before [Sir John]94-sir john s and [Mrs. Jennings]98-mrs. jennings s active zeal in the cause of society , procured [her]84-elinor [some other new acquaintance to see and observe]1119-some other new acquaintance to see and observe .

In a morning s excursion to [Exeter]9-exeter , [they]118-the palmers had met with [two young ladies , whom [Mrs. Jennings]98-mrs. jennings had the satisfaction of discovering to be [[her]98-mrs. jennings relations]1121-her relations]1120-two young ladies , whom mrs. jennings had the satisfaction of discovering to be her relations , and this was enough for [Sir John]94-sir john to invite [them]118-the palmers directly to [the park]533-the park , as soon as [their]118-the palmers present engagements at [Exeter]9-exeter were over . [Their]118-the palmers engagements at [Exeter]9-exeter instantly gave way before such an invitation , and [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton was thrown into no little alarm on the return of [Sir John]94-sir john , by hearing that [she]95-lady middleton was very soon to receive a visit from [two girls whom [she]95-lady middleton had never seen in [her]95-lady middleton life]1123-two girls whom she had never seen in her life , and [of whose elegance , whose tolerable gentility even ,]1124-of whose elegance , whose tolerable gentility even , [she]95-lady middleton could have no proof ; for the assurances of [[her]95-lady middleton husband]282-her husband and [mother on that subject]1126-mother on that subject went for nothing at all . [Their]118-the palmers being [[her]95-lady middleton relations]1121-her relations too made it so much the worse ; and [Mrs. Jennings]98-mrs. jennings s attempts at consolation were therefore unfortunately founded , when [she]98-mrs. jennings advised [[her]98-mrs. jennings daughter]371-her daughter not to care about [their]118-the palmers being so fashionable ; because [they]118-the palmers were [all cousins]1129-all cousins and must put up with [one another]1049-one another . As it was impossible , however , now to prevent [their]118-the palmers coming , [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton resigned [herself]95-lady middleton to the idea of it , with all the philosophy of [a well - bred woman]1131-a well - bred woman , contenting [herself]95-lady middleton with merely giving [[her]95-lady middleton husband]282-her husband a gentle reprimand on the subject five or six times every day .

[The young ladies]597-the young ladies arrived : [their]597-the young ladies appearance was by no means ungenteel or unfashionable . [Their]597-the young ladies dress was very smart , [their]597-the young ladies manners very civil , [they]597-the young ladies were delighted with [the house]281-the house , and in raptures with the furniture , and [they]597-the young ladies happened to be so doatingly fond of [children]1135-children that [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton s good opinion was engaged in [their]597-the young ladies favour before [they]597-the young ladies had been an hour at [the Park]533-the park . [She]95-lady middleton declared [them]597-the young ladies to be [very agreeable girls]1137-very agreeable girls indeed , which for [her]95-lady middleton ladyship was enthusiastic admiration . [Sir John]94-sir john s confidence in [his]94-sir john own judgment rose with this animated praise , and [he]94-sir john set off directly for [the cottage]471-the cottage to tell [the Miss Dashwoods]87-the miss dashwoods of [the Miss Steeles]125-the miss steeles arrival , and to assure [them]597-the young ladies of [their]597-the young ladies being [the sweetest girls in [the world]2697-the world]1139-the sweetest girls in the world . From such commendation as this , however , there was not much to be learned ; [Elinor]84-elinor well knew that [the sweetest girls in [the world]2697-the world]1139-the sweetest girls in the world were to be met with in [every part of [England]12-england]1143-every part of england , under every possible variation of form , face , temper and understanding . [Sir John]94-sir john wanted [the whole family]978-the whole family to walk to [the Park]533-the park directly and look at [[his]94-sir john guests]1146-his guests . [Benevolent]1147-benevolent , [philanthropic man]1148-philanthropic man ! It was painful to [him]94-sir john even to keep [a third cousin]1149-a third cousin to [himself]94-sir john .

" Do come now , "[94-sir john] said [he]94-sir john " pray come [you]3243-you must come [I]94-sir john declare [you]3243-you shall come [You]3243-you can t think how [you]3243-you will like [them]1139-the sweetest girls in the world . [Lucy]93-lucy is monstrous pretty , and so good humoured and agreeable ! [The children]228-the children are all hanging about [her]93-lucy already , as if [she]93-lucy was [an old acquaintance]3245-an old acquaintance . And [they]228-the children both long to see [you]3243-you of all things , for [they]228-the children have heard at [Exeter]9-exeter that [you]3243-you are the most beautiful creatures in [the world]2697-the world ; and [I]94-sir john have told [them]228-the children it is all very true , and a great deal more . [You]3243-you will be delighted with [them]228-the children [I]94-sir john am sure . [They]228-the children have brought the whole coach full of playthings for [the children]228-the children . How can [you]3243-you be so cross as not to come ? Why [they]228-the children are [[your]3243-you cousins]3248-your cousins , [you]3243-you know , after a fashion . _ [You]3243-you _ are [[my]94-sir john cousins]3249-my cousins , and [they]228-the children are [[my]94-sir john wife]3250-my wife s , so [you]3243-you must be related . "[94-sir john]

But [Sir John]94-sir john could not prevail . [He]94-sir john could only obtain a promise of [their]1150-their calling at [the Park]533-the park within a day or two , and then left [them]1150-their in amazement at [their]1150-their indifference , to walk [home]525-home and boast anew of [their]1150-their attractions to [the Miss Steeles]125-the miss steeles , as [he]94-sir john had been already boasting of [the Miss Steeles]125-the miss steeles to [them]1150-their .

When [their]1150-their promised visit to [the Park]533-the park and consequent introduction to [these young ladies]1154-these young ladies took place , [they]1150-their found in the appearance of [the eldest]1155-the eldest , who was nearly thirty , with a very plain and not a sensible face , nothing to admire ; but in the other , who was [not more than two or three and twenty]1156-not more than two or three and twenty , [they]1150-their acknowledged considerable beauty ; [her]1157-her features were pretty , and [she]1157-her had a sharp quick eye , and a smartness of air , which though it did not give actual elegance or grace , gave distinction to [her]1157-her person . [Their]1150-their manners were particularly civil , and [Elinor]84-elinor soon allowed [them]1150-their credit for some kind of sense , when [she]84-elinor saw with what constant and judicious attention [they]1150-their were making [themselves]1150-their agreeable to [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton . With [[her]95-lady middleton children]459-her children [they]1150-their were in continual raptures , extolling [their]1150-their beauty , courting [their]1150-their notice , and humouring [their]1150-their whims ; and such of [their]1150-their time as could be spared from the importunate demands which this politeness made on it , was spent in admiration of whatever [[her]95-lady middleton ladyship]534-her ladyship was doing , if [she]534-her ladyship happened to be doing any thing , or in taking patterns of some elegant new dress , in which [her]534-her ladyship appearance the day before had thrown [them]1150-their into unceasing delight . Fortunately for those who pay [their]1150-their court through such foibles , [a fond mother]1160-a fond mother , though , in pursuit of praise for [[her]95-lady middleton children]459-her children , the most rapacious of [human beings]1162-human beings , is likewise the most credulous ; [her]95-lady middleton demands are exorbitant ; but [she]95-lady middleton will swallow any thing ; and the excessive affection and endurance of [the Miss Steeles]125-the miss steeles towards [[her]95-lady middleton offspring]1163-her offspring were viewed therefore by [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton without the smallest surprise or distrust . [She]95-lady middleton saw with maternal complacency all the impertinent encroachments and mischievous tricks to which [[her]95-lady middleton cousins]1164-her cousins submitted . [She]95-lady middleton saw [their]1164-her cousins sashes untied , [their]1164-her cousins hair pulled about [their]1164-her cousins ears , [their]1164-her cousins work - bags searched , and [their]1164-her cousins knives and scissors stolen away , and felt no doubt of its being a reciprocal enjoyment . It suggested no other surprise than that [Elinor]84-elinor and [Marianne]85-marianne should sit so composedly by , without claiming a share in what was passing .

" [John]94-sir john is in such spirits today ! "[95-lady middleton] said [she]95-lady middleton , on [his]1165-his taking [Miss Steeles]125-the miss steeles s pocket handkerchief , and throwing it out of window " [He]94-sir john is full of monkey tricks . "[95-lady middleton]

And soon afterwards , on [the second boy]1166-the second boy s violently pinching one of [the same lady]1167-the same lady s fingers , [she]95-lady middleton fondly observed , " How playful [William]126-william is ! "[95-lady middleton]

" And here is [my]95-lady middleton sweet little [Annamaria]127-annamaria , "[95-lady middleton] [she]95-lady middleton added , tenderly caressing [a little girl of three years old , who had not made a noise for the last two minutes]1168-a little girl of three years old , who had not made a noise for the last two minutes ; " And [she]127-annamaria is always so gentle and quiet Never was there such a quiet little thing ! "[95-lady middleton]

But unfortunately in bestowing these embraces , a pin in [her]95-lady middleton ladyship s head dress slightly scratching [the child]1169-the child s neck , produced from this pattern of gentleness such violent screams , as could hardly be outdone by any creature professedly noisy . [The mother]1170-the mother s consternation was excessive ; but it could not surpass the alarm of [the Miss Steeles]125-the miss steeles , and every thing was done by [all three]1171-all three , in so critical an emergency , which affection could suggest as likely to assuage the agonies of [the little sufferer]1172-the little sufferer . [She]1169-the child was seated in [[her]1169-the child mother]296-her mother s lap , covered with kisses , [her]1169-the child wound bathed with lavender - water , by one of [the Miss Steeles]125-the miss steeles , who was on [her]1169-the child knees to attend [her]1169-the child , and [her]1169-the child mouth stuffed with sugar plums by [the other]738-the other . With such a reward for [her]1169-the child tears , [the child]1169-the child was too wise to cease crying . [She]1169-the child still screamed and sobbed lustily , kicked [[her]1169-the child two brothers]1176-her two brothers for offering to touch [her]1169-the child , and all [their]1176-her two brothers united soothings were ineffectual till [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton luckily remembering that in a scene of similar distress last week , some apricot marmalade had been successfully applied for a bruised temple , the same remedy was eagerly proposed for this unfortunate scratch , and a slight intermission of screams in [the young lady on hearing it]1177-the young lady on hearing it , gave [them]1176-her two brothers reason to hope that it would not be rejected . [She]1169-the child was carried out of [the room]2756-the room therefore in [[her]1169-the child mother]296-her mother s arms , in quest of this medicine , and as [the two boys]1180-the two boys chose to follow , though earnestly entreated by [[their]1180-the two boys mother]239-their mother to stay behind , [the four young ladies]1182-the four young ladies were left in a quietness which [the room]2756-the room had not known for many hours .

" [Poor little creatures]3251-poor little creatures ! "[128-lucy] said [Miss Steele]128-lucy , as soon as [they]1182-the four young ladies were gone . " It might have been a very sad accident . "[128-lucy]

" Yet [I]85-marianne hardly know how , "[85-marianne] cried [Marianne]85-marianne , " unless it had been under totally different circumstances . But this is the usual way of heightening alarm , where there is nothing to be alarmed at in reality . "[85-marianne]

" What [a sweet woman]3252-a sweet woman [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton is ! "[128-lucy] said [Lucy Steele]128-lucy .

[Marianne]85-marianne was silent ; it was impossible for [her]85-marianne to say what [she]85-marianne did not feel , however trivial the occasion ; and upon [Elinor]84-elinor therefore the whole task of telling lies when politeness required it , always fell . [She]84-elinor did [her]84-elinor best when thus called on , by speaking of [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton with more warmth than [she]84-elinor felt , though with far less than [Miss Lucy]128-lucy .

" And [Sir John]94-sir john too , "[1184-the elder sister] cried [the elder sister]1184-the elder sister , " what [a charming man]3222-a charming man [he]94-sir john is ! "[1184-the elder sister]

Here too , [Miss Dashwood]79-miss dashwood s commendation , being only simple and just , came in without any eclat . [She]84-elinor merely observed that [he]1185-i was perfectly good humoured and friendly .

" And what [a charming little family]3254-a charming little family [they]3254-a charming little family have ! [I]1185-i never saw [such fine children]3255-such fine children in [my]1185-i life . [I]1185-i declare [I]1185-i quite doat upon [them]3254-a charming little family already , and indeed [I]1185-i am always distractedly fond of [children]1135-children . "[1185-i]

" [I]84-elinor should guess so , "[84-elinor] said [Elinor]84-elinor , with a smile , " from what [I]84-elinor have witnessed this morning . "[84-elinor]

" [I]128-lucy have a notion , "[128-lucy] said [Lucy]128-lucy , " [you]84-elinor think [the little Middletons]3257-the little middletons rather too much indulged ; perhaps [they]3257-the little middletons may be the outside of enough ; but it is so natural in [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton ; and for [my]128-lucy part , [I]128-lucy love to see [children full of life and spirits]3258-children full of life and spirits ; [I]128-lucy can not bear [them]3258-children full of life and spirits if [they]3258-children full of life and spirits are tame and quiet . "[128-lucy]

" [I]84-elinor confess , "[84-elinor] replied [Elinor]84-elinor , " that while [I]84-elinor am at [Barton Park]6-barton park , [I]84-elinor never think of [tame and quiet children with any abhorrence]3259-tame and quiet children with any abhorrence . "[84-elinor]

A short pause succeeded this speech , which was first broken by [Miss Steele]128-lucy , who seemed very much disposed for conversation , and who now said rather abruptly , " And how do [you]84-elinor like [Devonshire]5-devonshire , [Miss Dashwood]79-miss dashwood ? [I]128-lucy suppose [you]84-elinor were very sorry to leave [Sussex]1-sussex . "[128-lucy]

In some surprise at the familiarity of this question , or at least of the manner in which it was spoken , [Elinor]84-elinor replied that [she]84-elinor was .

" [Norland]3-norland is [a prodigious beautiful place]3260-a prodigious beautiful place , is not [it]3-norland ? "[128-lucy] added [Miss Steele]128-lucy .

" [We]3261-we have heard [Sir John]94-sir john admire [it]3-norland excessively , "[128-lucy] said [Lucy]128-lucy , who seemed to think some apology necessary for the freedom of [[her]128-lucy sister]301-her sister .

" [I]84-elinor think [every one _]3262-every one _ must _ admire it , "[84-elinor] replied [Elinor]84-elinor , " who ever saw [the place]430-the place ; though it is not to be supposed that [any one]631-any one can estimate [its]430-the place beauties as [we]3261-we do . "[84-elinor]

" And had [you]84-elinor [a great many smart beaux]3265-a great many smart beaux [there]320-there ? [I]301-her sister suppose [you]84-elinor have not so many in [this part of [the world]2697-the world]3027-this part of the world ; for [my]301-her sister part , [I]301-her sister think they are a vast addition always . "[301-her sister]

" But why should [you]84-elinor think , "[128-lucy] said [Lucy]128-lucy , looking ashamed of [[her]128-lucy sister]301-her sister , " that there are not as many [genteel young men in [Devonshire]5-devonshire]3269-genteel young men in devonshire as [Sussex]1-sussex ? "[128-lucy]

" Nay , [[my]301-her sister dear]2669-my dear , [I]301-her sister m sure [I]301-her sister don t pretend to say that there an t. [I]301-her sister m sure there s [a vast many smart beaux]3271-a vast many smart beaux in [Exeter]9-exeter ; but [you]84-elinor know , how could [I]301-her sister tell what [smart beaux]3272-smart beaux there might be about [Norland]3-norland ; and [I]301-her sister was only afraid [the Miss Dashwoods]87-the miss dashwoods might find it dull at [Barton]8-barton , if [they]3273-they had not so many as [they]3273-they used to have . But perhaps [[you]84-elinor [young ladies]3275-young ladies]3274-you young ladies may not care about [the beaux]3276-the beaux , and had as lief be without [them]3276-the beaux as with [them]3276-the beaux . For [my]301-her sister part , [I]301-her sister think [they]3276-the beaux are vastly agreeable , provided [they]3276-the beaux dress smart and behave civil . But [I]301-her sister can t bear to see [them]3276-the beaux dirty and nasty . Now there s [Mr. Rose]129-mr. rose at [Exeter]9-exeter , [a prodigious smart young man]3277-a prodigious smart young man , quite [a beau]3278-a beau , clerk to [Mr. Simpson]130-mr. simpson , [you]84-elinor know , and yet if [you]84-elinor do but meet [him]129-mr. rose of a morning , [he]129-mr. rose is not fit to be seen . [I]301-her sister suppose [[your]84-elinor brother]3279-your brother was quite [a beau]3278-a beau , [Miss Dashwood]79-miss dashwood , before [he]3279-your brother married , as [he]3279-your brother was so rich ? "[301-her sister]

" Upon [my]84-elinor word , "[84-elinor] replied [Elinor]84-elinor , " [I]84-elinor can not tell [you]84-elinor , for [I]84-elinor do not perfectly comprehend the meaning of the word . But this [I]84-elinor can say , that if [he]3279-your brother ever was [a beau]3278-a beau before [he]3279-your brother married , [he]3279-your brother is one still for there is not the smallest alteration in [him]3279-your brother . "[84-elinor]

" Oh ! dear ! [one]2680-one never thinks of [married men s being beaux]3283-married men s being beaux [they]2680-one have something else to do . "[301-her sister]

" [Lord]3284-lord ! [Anne]131-nancy , "[301-her sister] cried [[her]84-elinor sister]301-her sister , " [you]131-nancy can talk of nothing but beaux ; [you]131-nancy will make [Miss Dashwood]79-miss dashwood believe [you]131-nancy think of nothing else . "[301-her sister] And then to turn the discourse , [she]301-her sister began admiring [the house]281-the house and the furniture .

This specimen of [the Miss Steeles]125-the miss steeles was enough . The vulgar freedom and folly of [the eldest]1155-the eldest left [her]301-her sister no recommendation , and as [Elinor]84-elinor was not blinded by the beauty , or the shrewd look of [the youngest]1191-the youngest , to [her]301-her sister want of real elegance and artlessness , [she]301-her sister left [the house]281-the house without any wish of knowing [them]1193-their better .

Not so [the Miss Steeles]125-the miss steeles . [They]1193-their came from [Exeter]9-exeter , well provided with admiration for the use of [Sir John Middleton]94-sir john , [[his]94-sir john family]531-his family , and [all [his]94-sir john relations]1195-all his relations , and no niggardly proportion was now dealt out to [[his]94-sir john fair cousins]1196-his fair cousins , whom [they]1193-their declared to be [the most beautiful , elegant , accomplished , and agreeable girls [they]1193-their had ever beheld , and with whom [they]1193-their were particularly anxious to be better acquainted]1197-the most beautiful , elegant , accomplished , and agreeable girls they had ever beheld , and with whom they were particularly anxious to be better acquainted . And to be better acquainted therefore , [Elinor]84-elinor soon found was [their]1193-their inevitable lot , for as [Sir John]94-sir john was entirely on the side of [the Miss Steeles]125-the miss steeles , [their]1193-their party would be too strong for opposition , and that kind of intimacy must be submitted to , which consists of sitting an hour or two together in [the same room]1198-the same room almost every day . [Sir John]94-sir john could do no more ; but [he]94-sir john did not know that any more was required : to be together was , in [his]94-sir john opinion , to be intimate , and while [his]94-sir john continual schemes for [their]1193-their meeting were effectual , [he]94-sir john had not a doubt of [their]1193-their being [established friends]1199-established friends .

To do [him]94-sir john justice , [he]94-sir john did every thing in [his]94-sir john power to promote [their]1193-their unreserve , by making [the Miss Steeles]125-the miss steeles acquainted with whatever [he]94-sir john knew or supposed of [[his]94-sir john cousins]586-his cousins situations in the most delicate particulars ; and [Elinor]84-elinor had not seen [them]1193-their more than twice , before [the eldest of [them]1193-their]1201-the eldest of them wished [her]84-elinor joy on [[her]84-elinor sister]301-her sister s having been so lucky as to make a conquest of [a very smart beau]1203-a very smart beau since [she]301-her sister came to [Barton]8-barton .

" Twill be a fine thing to have [her]301-her sister married so young to be sure , "[84-elinor] said [she]84-elinor , " and [I]84-elinor hear [he]1203-a very smart beau is quite [a beau]3278-a beau , and prodigious handsome . And [I]84-elinor hope [you]84-elinor may have as good luck [yourself]84-elinor soon , but perhaps [you]84-elinor may have [a friend in the corner]3286-a friend in the corner already . "[84-elinor]

[Elinor]84-elinor could not suppose that [Sir John]94-sir john would be more nice in proclaiming [his]94-sir john suspicions of [her]84-elinor regard for [Edward]89-edward , than [he]94-sir john had been with respect to [Marianne]85-marianne ; indeed it was rather [his]94-sir john favourite joke of [the two]1204-the two , as being somewhat newer and more conjectural ; and since [Edward]89-edward s visit , [they]1204-the two had never dined together without [his]94-sir john drinking to [her]84-elinor best affections with so much significancy and so many nods and winks , as to excite general attention . The letter F had been likewise invariably brought forward , and found productive of such countless jokes , that its character as the wittiest letter in the alphabet had been long established with [Elinor]84-elinor .

[The Miss Steeles]125-the miss steeles , as [she]84-elinor expected , had now all the benefit of these jokes , and in the eldest of [them]1204-the two [they]1204-the two raised a curiosity to know the name of [the gentleman alluded to]1205-the gentleman alluded to , which , though often impertinently expressed , was perfectly of a piece with [her]84-elinor general inquisitiveness into the concerns of [[their]1204-the two family]1206-their family . But [Sir John]94-sir john did not sport long with the curiosity which [he]94-sir john delighted to raise , for [he]94-sir john had at least as much pleasure in telling the name , as [Miss Steele]128-lucy had in hearing it .

" [His]1205-the gentleman alluded to name is [Ferrars]89-edward , "[94-sir john] said [he]94-sir john , in a very audible whisper ; " but pray do not tell it , for it s a great secret . "[94-sir john]

" [Ferrars]89-edward ! "[128-lucy] repeated [Miss Steele]128-lucy ; " [Mr. Ferrars]89-edward is [the happy man]3287-the happy man , is [he]89-edward ? What ! [[your]128-lucy sister - in - law s brother]3288-your sister - in - law s brother , [Miss Dashwood]79-miss dashwood ? [a very agreeable young man]3289-a very agreeable young man to be sure ; [I]128-lucy know [him]1205-the gentleman alluded to very well . "[128-lucy]

" How can [you]128-lucy say so , [Anne]131-nancy ? "[128-lucy] cried [Lucy]128-lucy , who generally made an amendment to all [[her]128-lucy sister]301-her sister s assertions . " Though [we]3290-we have seen [him]1205-the gentleman alluded to once or twice at [[my]128-lucy uncle s]3291-my uncle s , it is rather too much to pretend to know [him]1205-the gentleman alluded to very well . "[128-lucy]

[Elinor]84-elinor heard all this with attention and surprise . " And who was [this uncle]3292-this uncle ? Where did [he]1205-the gentleman alluded to live ? How came [they]3290-we acquainted ? "[84-elinor] [She]84-elinor wished very much to have the subject continued , though [she]84-elinor did not chuse to join in it [herself]84-elinor ; but nothing more of it was said , and for the first time in [her]84-elinor life , [she]84-elinor thought [Mrs. Jennings]98-mrs. jennings deficient either in curiosity after petty information , or in a disposition to communicate it . The manner in which [Miss Steele]128-lucy had spoken of [Edward]89-edward , increased [her]84-elinor curiosity ; for it struck [her]84-elinor as being rather ill - natured , and suggested the suspicion of [that lady]1208-that lady s knowing , or fancying [herself]84-elinor to know something to [his]89-edward disadvantage . But [her]84-elinor curiosity was unavailing , for no farther notice was taken of [Mr. Ferrars]89-edward s name by [Miss Steele]128-lucy when alluded to , or even openly mentioned by [Sir John]94-sir john .

CHAPTER XXII .

[Marianne , who had never much toleration for any thing like impertinence , vulgarity , inferiority of parts]1209-marianne , who had never much toleration for any thing like impertinence , vulgarity , inferiority of parts , or even difference of taste from [herself]1209-marianne , who had never much toleration for any thing like impertinence , vulgarity , inferiority of parts , was at this time particularly ill - disposed , from the state of [her]1209-marianne , who had never much toleration for any thing like impertinence , vulgarity , inferiority of parts spirits , to be pleased with [the Miss Steeles]125-the miss steeles , or to encourage [their]1210-their advances ; and to the invariable coldness of [her]1209-marianne , who had never much toleration for any thing like impertinence , vulgarity , inferiority of parts behaviour towards [them]1210-their , which checked every endeavour at intimacy on [their]1210-their side , [Elinor]84-elinor principally attributed that preference of [herself]84-elinor which soon became evident in the manners of both , but especially of [Lucy]128-lucy , who missed no opportunity of engaging [her]84-elinor in conversation , or of striving to improve [their]1210-their acquaintance by an easy and frank communication of [her]84-elinor sentiments .

[Lucy]128-lucy was naturally clever ; [her]128-lucy remarks were often just and amusing ; and as [a companion]1211-a companion for half an hour [Elinor]84-elinor frequently found [her]128-lucy agreeable ; but [her]128-lucy powers had received no aid from education : [she]128-lucy was ignorant and illiterate ; and [her]128-lucy deficiency of all mental improvement , [her]128-lucy want of information in the most common particulars , could not be concealed from [Miss Dashwood]79-miss dashwood , in spite of [her]128-lucy constant endeavour to appear to advantage . [Elinor]84-elinor saw , and pitied [her]128-lucy for , the neglect of abilities which education might have rendered so respectable ; but [she]84-elinor saw , with less tenderness of feeling , the thorough want of delicacy , of rectitude , and integrity of mind , which [her]128-lucy attentions , [her]128-lucy assiduities , [her]128-lucy flatteries at [the Park]533-the park betrayed ; and [she]84-elinor could have no lasting satisfaction in the company of [a person who joined insincerity with ignorance]1213-a person who joined insincerity with ignorance ; whose want of instruction prevented [their]1214-their meeting in conversation on terms of equality , and whose conduct toward [others]2874-others made every show of attention and deference towards [herself]128-lucy perfectly valueless .

" [You]84-elinor will think [my]128-lucy question an odd one , [I]128-lucy dare say , "[128-lucy] said [Lucy]128-lucy to [her]84-elinor one day , as [they]1214-their were walking together from [the park]533-the park to [the cottage]471-the cottage " but pray , are [you]84-elinor personally acquainted with [[your]84-elinor sister - in - law s mother]3293-your sister - in - law s mother , [Mrs. Ferrars]93-lucy ? "[128-lucy]

[Elinor]84-elinor _ did _ think the question a very odd one , and [her]84-elinor countenance expressed it , as [she]84-elinor answered that [she]84-elinor had never seen [Mrs. Ferrars]93-lucy .

" Indeed ! "[93-lucy] replied [Lucy]93-lucy ; " [I]93-lucy wonder at that , for [I]93-lucy thought [you]84-elinor must have seen [her]93-lucy at [Norland]3-norland sometimes . Then , perhaps , [you]84-elinor can not tell [me]93-lucy what sort of a woman [she]93-lucy is ? "[93-lucy]

" No , "[84-elinor] returned [Elinor]84-elinor , cautious of giving [her]84-elinor real opinion of [[Edward]89-edward s mother]1218-edward s mother , and not very desirous of satisfying what seemed impertinent curiosity ; " [I]93-lucy know nothing of [her]93-lucy . "[93-lucy]

" [I]93-lucy am sure [you]84-elinor think [me]93-lucy very strange , for enquiring about [her]93-lucy in such a way , "[93-lucy] said [Lucy]93-lucy , eyeing [Elinor]84-elinor attentively as [she]84-elinor spoke ; " but perhaps there may be reasons [I]93-lucy wish [I]93-lucy might venture ; but however [I]93-lucy hope [you]84-elinor will do [me]93-lucy the justice of believing that [I]93-lucy do not mean to be impertinent . "[93-lucy]

[Elinor]84-elinor made [her]93-lucy a civil reply , and [they]1219-they walked on for a few minutes in silence . It was broken by [Lucy]93-lucy , who renewed the subject again by saying , with some hesitation ,

" [I]93-lucy can not bear to have [you]84-elinor think [me]93-lucy impertinently curious . [I]93-lucy am sure [I]93-lucy would rather do any thing in [the world]2697-the world than be thought so by [a person whose good opinion is so well worth having as yours]3295-a person whose good opinion is so well worth having as yours . And [I]93-lucy am sure [I]93-lucy should not have the smallest fear of trusting _ [you]84-elinor ; _ indeed , [I]93-lucy should be very glad of [your]84-elinor advice how to manage in such an uncomfortable situation as [I]93-lucy am ; but , however , there is no occasion to trouble _ [you]84-elinor _ . [I]93-lucy am sorry [you]84-elinor do not happen to know [Mrs. Ferrars]93-lucy . "[93-lucy]

" [I]84-elinor am sorry [I]84-elinor do _ not _ , "[84-elinor] said [Elinor]84-elinor , in great astonishment , " if it could be of any use to [YOU]84-elinor to know [my]84-elinor opinion of [her]93-lucy . But really [I]84-elinor never understood that [you]84-elinor were at all connected with [that family]3296-that family , and therefore [I]84-elinor am a little surprised , [I]84-elinor confess , at so serious an inquiry into [her]93-lucy character . "[84-elinor]

" [I]1220-i dare say [you]84-elinor are , and [I]1220-i am sure [I]1220-i do not at all wonder at it . But if [I]1220-i dared tell [you]84-elinor all , [you]84-elinor would not be so much surprised . [Mrs. Ferrars]93-lucy is certainly nothing to [me]1220-i at present but the time _ may _ come how soon it will come must depend upon [herself]93-lucy when [we]3297-we may be very intimately connected . "[1220-i]

[She]1220-i looked down as [she]1220-i said this , amiably bashful , with only one side glance at [[her]1220-i companion]1221-her companion to observe its effect on [her]1220-i .

" Good heavens ! "[84-elinor] cried [Elinor]84-elinor , " what do [you]84-elinor mean ? Are [you]84-elinor acquainted with [Mr. Robert Ferrars]132-robert ? Can [you]84-elinor be ? "[84-elinor] And [she]84-elinor did not feel much delighted with the idea of [such a sister - in - law]1222-such a sister - in - law .

" No , "[93-lucy] replied [Lucy]93-lucy , " not to [Mr. _ Robert _ Ferrars]132-robert [I]93-lucy never saw [him]132-robert in [my]93-lucy life ; but , "[93-lucy] fixing [her]93-lucy eyes upon [Elinor]84-elinor , " to [[his]132-robert eldest brother]3298-his eldest brother . "[93-lucy]

What felt [Elinor]84-elinor at that moment ? Astonishment , that would have been as painful as it was strong , had not an immediate disbelief of the assertion attended it . [She]84-elinor turned towards [Lucy]93-lucy in silent amazement , unable to divine the reason or object of such a declaration ; and though [her]84-elinor complexion varied , [she]84-elinor stood firm in incredulity , and felt in no danger of an hysterical fit , or a swoon .

" [You]84-elinor may well be surprised , "[93-lucy] continued [Lucy]93-lucy ; " for to be sure [you]84-elinor could have had no idea of it before ; for [I]1223-i dare say [he]132-robert never dropped the smallest hint of it to [you]84-elinor or [any of [[your]84-elinor family]3062-your family]3299-any of your family ; because it was always meant to be a great secret , and [I]1223-i am sure has been faithfully kept so by [me]1223-i to this hour . Not [a soul of all [my]1223-i relations]3301-a soul of all my relations know of it but [Anne]131-nancy , and [I]1223-i never should have mentioned it to [you]84-elinor , if [I]1223-i had not felt the greatest dependence in [the world]2697-the world upon [your]84-elinor secrecy ; and [I]1223-i really thought [my]1223-i behaviour in asking so many questions about [Mrs. Ferrars]93-lucy must seem so odd , that it ought to be explained . And [I]1223-i do not think [Mr. Ferrars]132-robert can be displeased , when [he]132-robert knows [I]1223-i have trusted [you]84-elinor , because [I]1223-i know [he]132-robert has the highest opinion in [the world]2697-the world of all [[your]84-elinor family]3062-your family , and looks upon [yourself]84-elinor and the other [Miss Dashwoods]87-the miss dashwoods quite as [[his]132-robert own sisters]3305-his own sisters . "[1223-i] [She]1223-i paused .

[Elinor]84-elinor for a few moments remained silent . [Her]84-elinor astonishment at what [she]84-elinor heard was at first too great for words ; but at length forcing [herself]84-elinor to speak , and to speak cautiously , [she]84-elinor said , with calmness of manner , which tolerably well concealed [her]84-elinor surprise and solicitude " May [I]84-elinor ask if [your]84-elinor engagement is of long standing ? "[84-elinor]

" [We]3306-our have been engaged these four years . "[84-elinor]

" Four years ! "[84-elinor]

" Yes . "[84-elinor]

[Elinor]84-elinor , though greatly shocked , still felt unable to believe it .

" [I]84-elinor did not know , "[84-elinor] said [she]84-elinor , " that [you]84-elinor were even acquainted till the other day . "[84-elinor]

" [Our]3306-our acquaintance , however , is of many years date . [He]132-robert was under [[my]84-elinor uncle]3201-my uncle s care , [you]84-elinor know , a considerable while . "[84-elinor]

" [[Your]84-elinor uncle]3308-your uncle ! "[84-elinor]

" Yes ; [Mr. Pratt]133-mr. pratt . Did [you]84-elinor never hear [him]132-robert talk of [Mr. Pratt]133-mr. pratt ? "[84-elinor]

" [I]84-elinor think [I]84-elinor have , "[84-elinor] replied [Elinor]84-elinor , with an exertion of spirits , which increased with [her]84-elinor increase of emotion .

" [He]132-robert was four years with [[my]84-elinor uncle]3201-my uncle , who lives at [Longstaple]32-longstaple , near [Plymouth]22-plymouth . It was there [our]3306-our acquaintance begun , for [[my]84-elinor sister]2733-my sister and [me]84-elinor was often staying with [[my]84-elinor uncle]3201-my uncle , and it was there [our]3306-our engagement was formed , though not till a year after [he]132-robert had quitted as [a pupil]3312-a pupil ; but [he]132-robert was almost always with [us]3306-our afterwards . [I]84-elinor was very unwilling to enter into it , as [you]3313-you may imagine , without the knowledge and approbation of [[his]132-robert mother]234-his mother ; but [I]84-elinor was too young , and loved [him]132-robert too well , to be so prudent as [I]84-elinor ought to have been . Though [you]3313-you do not know [him]132-robert so well as [me]84-elinor , [Miss Dashwood]79-miss dashwood , [you]3313-you must have seen enough of [him]132-robert to be sensible [he]132-robert is very capable of making [a woman]778-a woman sincerely attached to [him]132-robert . "[84-elinor]

" Certainly , "[84-elinor] answered [Elinor]84-elinor , without knowing what [she]84-elinor said ; but after a moment s reflection , [she]84-elinor added , with revived security of [Edward]89-edward s honour and love , and [her]84-elinor companion s falsehood " Engaged to [Mr. Edward Ferrars]89-edward ! [I]84-elinor confess [myself]84-elinor so totally surprised at what [you]3313-you tell [me]84-elinor , that really [I]84-elinor beg [your]3313-you pardon ; but surely there must be some mistake of [person]3316-person or name . [We]3317-we can not mean the same [Mr. Ferrars]89-edward . "[84-elinor]

" [We]3317-we can mean [no other]2974-no other , "[93-lucy] cried [Lucy]93-lucy , smiling . " [Mr. Edward Ferrars]89-edward , [the eldest son of [Mrs. Ferrars]93-lucy]3319-the eldest son of mrs. ferrars , of [Park Street]33-park street , and [brother of [[your]3313-you sister - in - law]3321-your sister - in - law]3320-brother of your sister - in - law , [Mrs. John Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood , is [the person]3038-the person [I]93-lucy mean ; [you]3313-you must allow that [I]93-lucy am not likely to be deceived as to the name of [the man on who all [my]93-lucy happiness depends]3323-the man on who all my happiness depends . "[93-lucy]

" It is strange , "[84-elinor] replied [Elinor]84-elinor , in a most painful perplexity , " that [I]84-elinor should never have heard [him]89-edward even mention [your]84-elinor name . "[84-elinor]

" No ; considering [our]3324-our situation , it was not strange . [Our]3324-our first care has been to keep the matter secret . [You]3313-you knew nothing of [me]93-lucy , or [[my]93-lucy family]3134-my family , and , therefore , there could be no _ occasion _ for ever mentioning [my]93-lucy name to [you]3313-you ; and , as [he]89-edward was always particularly afraid of [[his]89-edward sister]215-his sister s suspecting any thing , _ that _ was reason enough for [his]89-edward not mentioning it . "[93-lucy]

[She]84-elinor was silent . [Elinor]84-elinor s security sunk ; but [her]84-elinor self - command did not sink with it .

" Four years [you]3313-you have been engaged , "[84-elinor] said [she]84-elinor with a firm voice .

" Yes ; and heaven knows how much longer [we]3324-our may have to wait . [Poor Edward]134-edward ! It puts [him]134-edward quite out of heart . "[84-elinor] Then taking a small miniature from [her]84-elinor pocket , [she]84-elinor added , " To prevent the possibility of mistake , be so good as to look at this face . It does not do [him]134-edward justice , to be sure , but yet [I]84-elinor think [you]3313-you can not be deceived as to the person it was drew for . [I]84-elinor have had it above these three years . "[84-elinor]

[She]84-elinor put it into [her]84-elinor hands as [she]84-elinor spoke ; and when [Elinor]84-elinor saw the painting , whatever other doubts [her]84-elinor fear of a too hasty decision , or [her]84-elinor wish of detecting falsehood might suffer to linger in [her]84-elinor mind , [she]84-elinor could have none of its being [Edward]134-edward s face . [She]84-elinor returned it almost instantly , acknowledging the likeness .

" [I]93-lucy have never been able , "[93-lucy] continued [Lucy]93-lucy , " to give [him]134-edward [my]93-lucy picture in return , which [I]93-lucy am very much vexed at , for [he]134-edward has been always so anxious to get it ! But [I]93-lucy am determined to set for it the very first opportunity . "[93-lucy]

" [You]84-elinor are quite in the right , "[84-elinor] replied [Elinor]84-elinor calmly . [They]1224-they then proceeded a few paces in silence . [Lucy]93-lucy spoke first .

" [I]84-elinor am sure , "[84-elinor] said [she]84-elinor , " [I]84-elinor have no doubt in [the world]2697-the world of [your]134-edward faithfully keeping this secret , because [you]134-edward must know of what importance it is to [us]1224-they , not to have it reach [[his]134-edward mother]234-his mother ; for [she]234-his mother would never approve of it , [I]84-elinor dare say . [I]84-elinor shall have no fortune , and [I]84-elinor fancy [she]234-his mother is [an exceeding proud woman]3329-an exceeding proud woman . "[84-elinor]

" [I]84-elinor certainly did not seek [your]134-edward confidence , "[84-elinor] said [Elinor]84-elinor ; " but [you]134-edward do [me]84-elinor no more than justice in imagining that [I]84-elinor may be depended on . [Your]134-edward secret is safe with [me]84-elinor ; but pardon [me]84-elinor if [I]84-elinor express some surprise at so unnecessary a communication . [You]134-edward must at least have felt that [my]84-elinor being acquainted with it could not add to its safety . "[84-elinor]

As [she]84-elinor said this , [she]84-elinor looked earnestly at [Lucy]93-lucy , hoping to discover something in [her]93-lucy countenance ; perhaps the falsehood of the greatest part of what [she]84-elinor had been saying ; but [Lucy]93-lucy s countenance suffered no change .

" [I]84-elinor was afraid [you]134-edward would think [I]84-elinor was taking a great liberty with [you]134-edward , "[84-elinor] said [she]84-elinor , " in telling [you]134-edward all this . [I]84-elinor have not known [you]134-edward long to be sure , personally at least , but [I]84-elinor have known [you]134-edward and all [[your]134-edward family]3062-your family by description a great while ; and as soon as [I]84-elinor saw [you]134-edward , [I]84-elinor felt almost as if [you]134-edward was [an old acquaintance]3245-an old acquaintance . Besides in the present case , [I]84-elinor really thought some explanation was due to [you]134-edward after [my]84-elinor making such particular inquiries about [[Edward]134-edward s mother]1218-edward s mother ; and [I]84-elinor am so unfortunate , that [I]84-elinor have not a creature whose advice [I]84-elinor can ask . [Anne]131-nancy is [the only person that knows of it]3333-the only person that knows of it , and [she]131-nancy has no judgment at all ; indeed , [she]131-nancy does [me]84-elinor a great deal more harm than good , for [I]84-elinor am in constant fear of [her]131-nancy betraying [me]84-elinor . [She]131-nancy does not know how to hold [her]131-nancy tongue , as [you]134-edward must perceive , and [I]84-elinor am sure [I]84-elinor was in the greatest fright in [the world]2697-the world t other day , when [Edward]134-edward s name was mentioned by [Sir John]94-sir john , lest [she]131-nancy should out with it all . [You]134-edward can t think how much [I]84-elinor go through in [my]84-elinor mind from it altogether . [I]84-elinor only wonder that [I]84-elinor am alive after what [I]84-elinor have suffered for [Edward]134-edward s sake these last four years . Every thing in such suspense and uncertainty ; and seeing [him]134-edward so seldom [we]3335-we can hardly meet above twice a - year . [I]84-elinor am sure [I]84-elinor wonder [my]84-elinor heart is not quite broke . "[84-elinor]

Here [she]1225-i took out [her]1225-i handkerchief ; but [Elinor]84-elinor did not feel very compassionate .

" Sometimes . "[93-lucy] continued [Lucy]93-lucy , after wiping [her]93-lucy eyes , " [I]93-lucy think whether it would not be better for [us]3335-we both to break off the matter entirely . "[93-lucy] As [she]1225-i said this , [she]1225-i looked directly at [[her]1225-i companion]1221-her companion . " But then at other times [I]1225-i have not resolution enough for it . [I]1225-i can not bear the thoughts of making [him]134-edward so miserable , as [I]1225-i know the very mention of such a thing would do . And on [my]1225-i own account too so dear as [he]134-edward is to [me]1225-i [I]1225-i don t think [I]1225-i could be equal to it . What would [you]93-lucy advise [me]1225-i to do in such a case , [Miss Dashwood]79-miss dashwood ? What would [you]93-lucy do [yourself]93-lucy ? "[1225-i]

" Pardon [me]84-elinor , "[84-elinor] replied [Elinor]84-elinor , startled by the question ; " but [I]84-elinor can give [you]93-lucy no advice under such circumstances . [Your]93-lucy own judgment must direct [you]93-lucy . "[84-elinor]

" To be sure , "[93-lucy] continued [Lucy]93-lucy , after a few minutes silence on both sides , " [[his]134-edward mother]234-his mother must provide for [him]134-edward sometime or other ; but poor [Edward]134-edward is so cast down by it ! Did [you]93-lucy not think [him]134-edward dreadful low - spirited when [he]134-edward was at [Barton]8-barton ? [He]134-edward was so miserable when [he]134-edward left [us]3337-us at [Longstaple]32-longstaple , to go to [you]93-lucy , that [I]93-lucy was afraid [you]93-lucy would think [him]134-edward quite ill . "[93-lucy]

" Did [he]134-edward come from [[your]93-lucy uncle]3308-your uncle s , then , when [he]134-edward visited [us]3337-us ? "[84-elinor]

" Oh , yes ; [he]134-edward had been staying a fortnight with [us]3337-us . Did [you]93-lucy think [he]134-edward came directly from [town]2896-town ? "[93-lucy]

" No , "[84-elinor] replied [Elinor]84-elinor , most feelingly sensible of every fresh circumstance in favour of [Lucy]93-lucy s veracity ; " [I]93-lucy remember [he]134-edward told [us]3337-us , that [he]134-edward had been staying a fortnight with [some friends near [Plymouth]22-plymouth]966-some friends near plymouth . "[93-lucy] [She]93-lucy remembered too , [her]93-lucy own surprise at the time , at [his]1227-his mentioning nothing farther of [those friends]1228-those friends , at [his]1227-his total silence with respect even to [their]1228-those friends names .

" Did not [you]93-lucy think [him]134-edward sadly out of spirits ? "[93-lucy] repeated [Lucy]93-lucy .

" [We]3337-us did , indeed , particularly so when [he]134-edward first arrived . "[93-lucy]

" [I]93-lucy begged [him]134-edward to exert [himself]134-edward for fear [you]93-lucy should suspect what was the matter ; but it made [him]134-edward so melancholy , not being able to stay more than a fortnight with [us]3337-us , and seeing [me]93-lucy so much affected . [Poor fellow]3194-poor fellow ! [I]93-lucy am afraid it is just the same with [him]134-edward now ; for [he]134-edward writes in wretched spirits . [I]93-lucy heard from [him]134-edward just before [I]93-lucy left [Exeter]9-exeter ; "[93-lucy] taking a letter from [her]93-lucy pocket and carelessly showing the direction to [Elinor]84-elinor . " [You]84-elinor know [his]134-edward hand , [I]93-lucy dare say , a charming one it is ; but that is not written so well as usual . [He]134-edward was tired , [I]93-lucy dare say , for [he]134-edward had just filled the sheet to [me]93-lucy as full as possible . "[93-lucy]

[Elinor]84-elinor saw that it _ was _ [his]1229-he hand , and [she]84-elinor could doubt no longer . This picture , [she]84-elinor had allowed [herself]84-elinor to believe , might have been accidentally obtained ; it might not have been [Edward]134-edward s gift ; but a correspondence between [them]1230-them by letter , could subsist only under a positive engagement , could be authorised by nothing else ; for a few moments , [she]84-elinor was almost overcome [her]84-elinor heart sunk within [her]84-elinor , and [she]84-elinor could hardly stand ; but exertion was indispensably necessary ; and [she]84-elinor struggled so resolutely against the oppression of [her]84-elinor feelings , that [her]84-elinor success was speedy , and for the time complete .

" Writing to [each other]303-each other , "[93-lucy] said [Lucy]93-lucy , returning the letter into [her]93-lucy pocket , " is the only comfort [we]1230-them have in such long separations . Yes , _ [I]93-lucy _ have one other comfort in [his]1229-he picture , but poor [Edward]134-edward has not even _ that _ . If [he]1229-he had but [my]93-lucy picture , [he]1229-he says [he]1229-he should be easy . [I]93-lucy gave [him]1229-he a lock of [my]93-lucy hair set in a ring when [he]1229-he was at Longstaple last , and that was some comfort to [him]1229-he , [he]1229-he said , but not equal to a picture . Perhaps [you]93-lucy might notice the ring when [you]93-lucy saw [him]1229-he ? "[93-lucy]

" [I]84-elinor did , "[84-elinor] said [Elinor]84-elinor , with a composure of voice , under which was concealed an emotion and distress beyond any thing [she]84-elinor had ever felt before . [She]84-elinor was mortified , shocked , confounded .

Fortunately for [her]84-elinor , [they]1231-their had now reached [the cottage]471-the cottage , and the conversation could be continued no farther . After sitting with [them]1231-their a few minutes , [the Miss Steeles]125-the miss steeles returned to [the Park]533-the park , and [Elinor]84-elinor was then at liberty to think and be wretched .

END OF [THE FIRST VOLUME

CHAPTER XXIII]1234-the first volume chapter xxiii .

However small [Elinor]84-elinor s general dependence on [Lucy]93-lucy s veracity might be , it was impossible for [her]84-elinor on serious reflection to suspect it in the present case , where no temptation could be answerable to the folly of inventing a falsehood of such a description . What [Lucy]93-lucy had asserted to be true , therefore , [Elinor]84-elinor could not , dared not longer doubt ; supported as it was too on every side by such probabilities and proofs , and contradicted by nothing but [her]84-elinor own wishes . [Their]1231-their opportunity of acquaintance in [the house of [Mr. Pratt]133-mr. pratt]1235-the house of mr. pratt was a foundation for the rest , at once indisputable and alarming ; and [Edward]134-edward s visit near [Plymouth]22-plymouth , [his]134-edward melancholy state of mind , [his]134-edward dissatisfaction at [his]134-edward own prospects , [his]134-edward uncertain behaviour towards [herself]84-elinor , the intimate knowledge of [the Miss Steeles]125-the miss steeles as to [Norland]3-norland and [their]1231-their family connections , which had often surprised [her]84-elinor , the picture , the letter , the ring , formed altogether such a body of evidence , as overcame every fear of condemning [him]134-edward unfairly , and established as a fact , which no partiality could set aside , [his]134-edward ill - treatment of [herself]84-elinor . [Her]84-elinor resentment of such behaviour , [her]84-elinor indignation at having been [its]1236-its dupe , for a short time made [her]84-elinor feel only for [herself]84-elinor ; but other ideas , other considerations , soon arose . Had [Edward]134-edward been intentionally deceiving [her]84-elinor ? Had [he]134-edward feigned a regard for [her]84-elinor which [he]134-edward did not feel ? Was [his]134-edward engagement to [Lucy]93-lucy an engagement of the heart ? No ; whatever it might once have been , [she]84-elinor could not believe it such at present . [His]134-edward affection was all [her]84-elinor own . [She]84-elinor could not be deceived in that . [[Her]84-elinor mother]296-her mother , [sisters]265-sisters , [Fanny]88-fanny , all had been conscious of [his]134-edward regard for [her]84-elinor at [Norland]3-norland ; it was not an illusion of [her]84-elinor own vanity . [He]134-edward certainly loved [her]84-elinor . What a softener of the heart was this persuasion ! How much could it not tempt [her]84-elinor to forgive ! [He]134-edward had been blamable , highly blamable , in remaining at [Norland]3-norland after [he]134-edward first felt [her]84-elinor influence over [him]134-edward to be more than it ought to be . In that , [he]134-edward could not be defended ; but if [he]134-edward had injured [her]84-elinor , how much more had [he]134-edward injured [himself]134-edward ; if [her]84-elinor case were pitiable , [his]134-edward was hopeless . [His]134-edward imprudence had made [her]84-elinor miserable for a while ; but it seemed to have deprived [himself]134-edward of all chance of ever being otherwise . [She]84-elinor might in time regain tranquillity ; but _ [he]134-edward _ , what had [he]134-edward to look forward to ? Could [he]134-edward ever be tolerably happy with [Lucy Steele]128-lucy ; could [he]134-edward , were [his]134-edward affection for [herself]128-lucy out of the question , with [his]134-edward integrity , [his]134-edward delicacy , and well - informed mind , be satisfied with [a wife like [her]128-lucy illiterate , artful , and selfish]1239-a wife like her illiterate , artful , and selfish ?

The youthful infatuation of nineteen would naturally blind [him]134-edward to every thing but [her]84-elinor beauty and good nature ; but the four succeeding years years , which if rationally spent , give such improvement to the understanding , must have opened [his]134-edward eyes to [her]84-elinor defects of education , while the same period of time , spent on [her]84-elinor side in inferior society and more frivolous pursuits , had perhaps robbed [her]84-elinor of that simplicity which might once have given an interesting character to [her]84-elinor beauty .

If in the supposition of [his]134-edward seeking to marry [herself]84-elinor , [his]134-edward difficulties from [[his]134-edward mother]234-his mother had seemed great , how much greater were [they]1241-they now likely to be , when the object of [his]134-edward engagement was undoubtedly inferior in connections , and probably inferior in fortune to [herself]84-elinor . These difficulties , indeed , with a heart so alienated from [Lucy]128-lucy , might not press very hard upon [his]134-edward patience ; but melancholy was the state of [the person by whom the expectation of family opposition and unkindness]1242-the person by whom the expectation of family opposition and unkindness , could be felt as a relief !

As these considerations occurred to [her]84-elinor in painful succession , [she]84-elinor wept for [him]134-edward , more than for [herself]84-elinor . Supported by the conviction of having done nothing to merit [her]84-elinor present unhappiness , and consoled by the belief that [Edward]134-edward had done nothing to forfeit [her]84-elinor esteem , [she]84-elinor thought [she]84-elinor could even now , under the first smart of the heavy blow , command [herself]84-elinor enough to guard every suspicion of the truth from [[her]84-elinor mother]296-her mother and [sisters]265-sisters . And so well was [she]84-elinor able to answer [her]84-elinor own expectations , that when [she]84-elinor joined [them]1245-their at dinner only two hours after [she]84-elinor had first suffered the extinction of all [her]84-elinor dearest hopes , [no one]280-no one would have supposed from the appearance of [the sisters]1247-the sisters , that [Elinor]84-elinor was mourning in secret over obstacles which must divide [her]84-elinor for ever from the object of [her]84-elinor love , and that [Marianne]85-marianne was internally dwelling on the perfections of [a man]463-a man , of whose whole heart [she]84-elinor felt thoroughly possessed , and whom [she]84-elinor expected to see in every carriage which drove near [[their]1245-their house]977-their house .

The necessity of concealing from [[her]84-elinor mother]296-her mother and [Marianne]85-marianne , what had been entrusted in confidence to [herself]84-elinor , though it obliged [her]84-elinor to unceasing exertion , was no aggravation of [Elinor]84-elinor s distress . On the contrary it was a relief to [her]84-elinor , to be spared the communication of what would give such affliction to [them]1245-their , and to be saved likewise from hearing that condemnation of [Edward]134-edward , which would probably flow from the excess of [their]1245-their partial affection for [herself]84-elinor , and which was more than [she]84-elinor felt equal to support .

From [their]1245-their counsel , or [their]1245-their conversation , [she]84-elinor knew [she]84-elinor could receive no assistance , [their]1245-their tenderness and sorrow must add to [her]84-elinor distress , while [her]84-elinor self - command would neither receive encouragement from [their]1245-their example nor from [their]1245-their praise . [She]84-elinor was stronger alone , and [her]84-elinor own good sense so well supported [her]84-elinor , that [her]84-elinor firmness was as unshaken , [her]84-elinor appearance of cheerfulness as invariable , as with regrets so poignant and so fresh , it was possible for [them]1245-their to be .

Much as [she]84-elinor had suffered from [her]84-elinor first conversation with [Lucy]128-lucy on the subject , [she]84-elinor soon felt an earnest wish of renewing it ; and this for more reasons than one . [She]84-elinor wanted to hear many particulars of [their]1245-their engagement repeated again , [she]84-elinor wanted more clearly to understand what [Lucy]128-lucy really felt for [Edward]134-edward , whether there were any sincerity in [her]128-lucy declaration of tender regard for [him]134-edward , and [she]84-elinor particularly wanted to convince [Lucy]128-lucy , by [her]128-lucy readiness to enter on the matter again , and [her]128-lucy calmness in conversing on it , that [she]128-lucy was no otherwise interested in it than as [a friend]1251-a friend , which [she]128-lucy very much feared [her]128-lucy involuntary agitation , in [their]1245-their morning discourse , must have left at least doubtful . That [Lucy]128-lucy was disposed to be jealous of [her]84-elinor appeared very probable : it was plain that [Edward]134-edward had always spoken highly in [her]84-elinor praise , not merely from [Lucy]128-lucy s assertion , but from [her]84-elinor venturing to trust [her]128-lucy on so short a personal acquaintance , with a secret so confessedly and evidently important . And even [Sir John]94-sir john s joking intelligence must have had some weight . But indeed , while [Elinor]84-elinor remained so well assured within [herself]84-elinor of being really beloved by [Edward]134-edward , it required no other consideration of probabilities to make it natural that [Lucy]128-lucy should be jealous ; and that [she]128-lucy was so , [her]128-lucy very confidence was a proof . What other reason for the disclosure of the affair could there be , but that [Elinor]84-elinor might be informed by it of [Lucy]128-lucy s superior claims on [Edward]134-edward , and be taught to avoid [him]134-edward in future ? [She]128-lucy had little difficulty in understanding thus much of [her]128-lucy rival s intentions , and while [she]128-lucy was firmly resolved to act by [her]128-lucy as every principle of honour and honesty directed , to combat [her]128-lucy own affection for [Edward]134-edward and to see [him]134-edward as little as possible ; [she]128-lucy could not deny [herself]128-lucy the comfort of endeavouring to convince [Lucy]128-lucy that [her]128-lucy heart was unwounded . And as [she]128-lucy could now have nothing more painful to hear on the subject than had already been told , [she]128-lucy did not mistrust [her]128-lucy own ability of going through a repetition of particulars with composure .

But it was not immediately that an opportunity of doing so could be commanded , though [Lucy]128-lucy was as well disposed as [herself]128-lucy to take advantage of any that occurred ; for the weather was not often fine enough to allow of [their]1252-they joining in a walk , where [they]1252-they might most easily separate [themselves]1252-they from [the others]505-the others ; and though [they]1252-they met at least every other evening either at [the park]533-the park or [cottage]1255-cottage , and chiefly at the former , [they]1252-they could not be supposed to meet for the sake of conversation . Such a thought would never enter either [Sir John]94-sir john or [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton s head ; and therefore very little leisure was ever given for a general chat , and none at all for particular discourse . [They]1252-they met for the sake of eating , drinking , and laughing together , playing at cards , or consequences , or any other game that was sufficiently noisy .

One or two meetings of this kind had taken place , without affording [Elinor]84-elinor any chance of engaging [Lucy]128-lucy in private , when [Sir John]94-sir john called at [the cottage]471-the cottage one morning , to beg , in the name of charity , that [they]1252-they would all dine with [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton that day , as [he]94-sir john was obliged to attend [the club at [Exeter]9-exeter]1257-the club at exeter , and [she]95-lady middleton would otherwise be quite alone , except [[her]84-elinor mother]296-her mother and the two [Miss Steeles]125-the miss steeles . [Elinor]84-elinor , who foresaw a fairer opening for the point [she]84-elinor had in view , in such a party as this was likely to be , more at liberty among [themselves]1252-they under the tranquil and well - bred direction of [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton than when [[her]95-lady middleton husband]282-her husband united [them]1252-they together in one noisy purpose , immediately accepted the invitation ; [Margaret]86-margaret , with [[her]86-margaret mother]296-her mother s permission , was equally compliant , and [Marianne]85-marianne , though always unwilling to join any of [their]1252-they parties , was persuaded by [[her]85-marianne mother]296-her mother , who could not bear to have [her]85-marianne seclude [herself]85-marianne from any chance of amusement , to go likewise .

[The young ladies]597-the young ladies went , and [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton was happily preserved from the frightful solitude which had threatened [her]95-lady middleton . The insipidity of the meeting was exactly such as [Elinor]84-elinor had expected ; it produced not one novelty of thought or expression , and nothing could be less interesting than the whole of [their]1252-they discourse both in [the dining parlour and [drawing room]1264-drawing room]1263-the dining parlour and drawing room : to the latter , [the children]228-the children accompanied [them]1252-they , and while [they]1252-they remained [there]320-there , [she]84-elinor was too well convinced of the impossibility of engaging [Lucy]128-lucy s attention to attempt it . [They]1252-they quitted it only with the removal of the tea - things . The card - table was then placed , and [Elinor]84-elinor began to wonder at [herself]84-elinor for having ever entertained a hope of finding time for conversation at [the park]533-the park . [They]1252-they all rose up in preparation for a round game .

" [I]95-lady middleton am glad , "[95-lady middleton] said [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton to [Lucy]128-lucy , " [you]128-lucy are not going to finish poor little Annamaria s basket this evening ; for [I]95-lady middleton am sure it must hurt [your]128-lucy eyes to work filigree by candlelight . And [we]1252-they will make [the dear little love]3343-the dear little love some amends for [her]3343-the dear little love disappointment to - morrow , and then [I]95-lady middleton hope [she]3343-the dear little love will not much mind it . "[95-lady middleton]

This hint was enough , [Lucy]128-lucy recollected [herself]128-lucy instantly and replied , " Indeed [you]95-lady middleton are very much mistaken , [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton ; [I]128-lucy am only waiting to know whether [you]95-lady middleton can make [your]95-lady middleton party without [me]128-lucy , or [I]128-lucy should have been at [my]128-lucy filigree already . [I]128-lucy would not disappoint [the little angel]3344-the little angel for [all the world]3345-all the world : and if [you]95-lady middleton want [me]128-lucy at the card - table now , [I]128-lucy am resolved to finish the basket after supper . "[128-lucy]

" [You]128-lucy are very good , [I]95-lady middleton hope it won t hurt [your]128-lucy eyes will [you]128-lucy ring the bell for some working candles ? [[My]95-lady middleton poor little girl]3346-my poor little girl would be sadly disappointed , [I]95-lady middleton know , if the basket was not finished tomorrow , for though [I]95-lady middleton told [her]3346-my poor little girl it certainly would not , [I]95-lady middleton am sure [she]3346-my poor little girl depends upon having it done . "[95-lady middleton]

[Lucy]128-lucy directly drew [her]128-lucy work table near [her]128-lucy and reseated [herself]128-lucy with an alacrity and cheerfulness which seemed to infer that [she]128-lucy could taste no greater delight than in making a filigree basket for [a spoilt child]1268-a spoilt child .

[Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton proposed a rubber of Casino to [the others]505-the others . [No one]280-no one made any objection but [Marianne]85-marianne , who with [her]85-marianne usual inattention to the forms of general civility , exclaimed , " [[Your]128-lucy Ladyship]3347-your ladyship will have the goodness to excuse _ [me]85-marianne _ [you]128-lucy know [I]85-marianne detest cards . [I]85-marianne shall go to the piano - forte ; [I]85-marianne have not touched it since it was tuned . "[85-marianne] And without farther ceremony , [she]85-marianne turned away and walked to the instrument .

[Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton looked as if [she]95-lady middleton thanked heaven that _ [she]95-lady middleton _ had never made so rude a speech .

" [Marianne]85-marianne can never keep long from that instrument [you]128-lucy know , [ma am]2887-ma am , "[84-elinor] said [Elinor]84-elinor , endeavouring to smooth away the offence ; " and [I]84-elinor do not much wonder at it ; for it is the very best toned piano - forte [I]84-elinor ever heard . "[84-elinor]

[The remaining five]1271-the remaining five were now to draw [their]1271-the remaining five cards .

" Perhaps , "[84-elinor] continued [Elinor]84-elinor , " if [I]84-elinor should happen to cut out , [I]84-elinor may be of some use to [Miss Lucy Steele]128-lucy , in rolling [her]128-lucy papers for [her]128-lucy ; and there is so much still to be done to the basket , that it must be impossible [I]84-elinor think for [her]128-lucy labour singly , to finish it this evening . [I]84-elinor should like the work exceedingly , if [she]128-lucy would allow [me]84-elinor a share in it . "[84-elinor]

" Indeed [I]128-lucy shall be very much obliged to [you]128-lucy for [your]128-lucy help , "[128-lucy] cried [Lucy]128-lucy , " for [I]128-lucy find there is more to be done to it than [I]128-lucy thought there was ; and it would be a shocking thing to disappoint [dear Annamaria]127-annamaria after all . "[128-lucy]

" Oh ! that would be terrible , indeed , "[128-lucy] said [Miss Steele]128-lucy . " [Dear little soul]3349-dear little soul , how [I]128-lucy do love [her]128-lucy ! "[128-lucy]

" [You]84-elinor are very kind , "[95-lady middleton] said [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton to [Elinor]84-elinor ; " and as [you]84-elinor really like the work , perhaps [you]84-elinor will be as well pleased not to cut in till another rubber , or will [you]84-elinor take [your]84-elinor chance now ? "[95-lady middleton]

[Elinor]84-elinor joyfully profited by the first of these proposals , and thus by a little of that address which [Marianne]85-marianne could never condescend to practise , gained [her]85-marianne own end , and pleased [Lady Middleton]95-lady middleton at the same time . [Lucy]128-lucy made room for [her]85-marianne with ready attention , and [the two fair rivals]1272-the two fair rivals were thus seated side by side at the same table , and , with the utmost harmony , engaged in forwarding the same work . The pianoforte at which [Marianne]85-marianne , wrapped up in [her]85-marianne own music and [her]85-marianne own thoughts , had by this time forgotten that any body was in [the room]2756-the room besides [herself]85-marianne , was luckily so near [them]1272-the two fair rivals that [Miss Dashwood]79-miss dashwood now judged [she]79-miss dashwood might safely , under the shelter of its noise , introduce the interesting subject , without any risk of being heard at the card - table .

CHAPTER XXIV .

In a firm , though cautious tone , [Elinor]84-elinor thus began .

" [I]84-elinor should be undeserving of the confidence [you]128-lucy have honoured [me]84-elinor with , if [I]84-elinor felt no desire for its continuance , or no farther curiosity on its subject . [I]84-elinor will not apologize therefore for bringing it forward again . "[84-elinor]

" Thank [you]128-lucy , "[128-lucy] cried [Lucy]128-lucy warmly , " for breaking the ice ; [you]128-lucy have set [my]128-lucy heart at ease by it ; for [I]128-lucy was somehow or other afraid [I]128-lucy had offended [you]128-lucy by what [I]128-lucy told [you]128-lucy that Monday . "[128-lucy]

" Offended [me]84-elinor ! How could [you]128-lucy suppose so ? Believe [me]84-elinor , "[84-elinor] and [Elinor]84-elinor spoke it with the truest sincerity , " nothing could be farther from [my]84-elinor intention than to give [you]128-lucy such an idea . Could [you]128-lucy have a motive for the trust , that was not honourable and flattering to [me]84-elinor ? "[84-elinor]

" And yet [I]128-lucy do assure [you]128-lucy , "[128-lucy] replied [Lucy]128-lucy , [her]128-lucy little sharp eyes full of meaning , " there seemed to [me]128-lucy to be a coldness and displeasure in [your]128-lucy manner that made [me]128-lucy quite uncomfortable . [I]128-lucy felt sure that [you]128-lucy was angry with [me]128-lucy ; and have been quarrelling with [myself]128-lucy ever since , for having took such a liberty as to trouble [you]128-lucy with [my]128-lucy affairs . But [I]128-lucy am very glad to find it was only [my]128-lucy own fancy , and that [you]128-lucy really do not blame [me]128-lucy . If [you]128-lucy knew what a consolation it was to [me]128-lucy to relieve [my]128-lucy heart speaking to [you]128-lucy of what [I]128-lucy am always thinking of every moment of [my]128-lucy life , [your]128-lucy compassion would make [you]128-lucy overlook every thing else [I]128-lucy am sure . "[128-lucy]

" Indeed , [I]84-elinor can easily believe that it was a very great relief to [you]128-lucy , to acknowledge [your]128-lucy situation to [me]84-elinor , and be assured that [you]128-lucy shall never have reason to repent it . [Your]128-lucy case is a very unfortunate one ; [you]128-lucy seem to [me]84-elinor to be surrounded with difficulties , and [you]128-lucy will have need of all [your]128-lucy mutual affection to support [you]128-lucy under [them]3350-them . [Mr. Ferrars]89-edward , [I]84-elinor believe , is entirely dependent on [[his]89-edward mother]234-his mother . "[84-elinor]

" [He]89-edward has only two thousand pounds of [his]89-edward own ; it would be madness to marry upon that , though for [my]128-lucy own part , [I]128-lucy could give up every prospect of more without a sigh . [I]128-lucy have been always used to a very small income , and could struggle with any poverty for [him]89-edward ; but [I]128-lucy love [him]89-edward too well to be the selfish means of robbing [him]89-edward , perhaps , of all that [[his]89-edward mother]234-his mother might give [him]89-edward if [he]89-edward married to please [her]234-his mother . [We]3353-we must wait , it may be for many years . With [almost every other man in [the world]2697-the world]3354-almost every other man in the world , it would be an alarming prospect ; but [Edward]89-edward s affection and constancy nothing can deprive [me]128-lucy of [I]128-lucy know . "[128-lucy]

" That conviction must be every thing to [you]84-elinor ; and [he]89-edward is undoubtedly supported by the same trust in [your]84-elinor s. If the strength of [your]84-elinor reciprocal attachment had failed , as between [many people]3115-many people , and under many circumstances it naturally would during a four years engagement , [your]84-elinor situation would have been pitiable , indeed . "[84-elinor]

[Lucy]128-lucy here looked up ; but [Elinor]84-elinor was careful in guarding [her]128-lucy countenance from every expression that could give [her]128-lucy words a suspicious tendency .

" [Edward]89-edward s love for [me]128-lucy , "[128-lucy] said [Lucy]128-lucy , " has been pretty well put to the test , by [our]3357-our long , very long absence since [we]3357-our were first engaged , and it has stood the trial so well , that [I]128-lucy should be unpardonable to doubt it now . [I]128-lucy can safely say that [he]89-edward has never gave [me]128-lucy one moment s alarm on that account from the first . "[128-lucy]

[Elinor]84-elinor hardly knew whether to smile or sigh at this assertion .

[Lucy]128-lucy went on . " [I]128-lucy am rather of a jealous temper too by nature , and from [our]3357-our different situations in life , from [his]89-edward being so much more in [the world]2697-the world than [me]128-lucy , and [our]3357-our continual separation , [I]128-lucy was enough inclined for suspicion , to have found out the truth in an instant , if there had been the slightest alteration in [his]89-edward behaviour to [me]128-lucy when [we]3357-our met , or any lowness of spirits that [I]128-lucy could not account for , or if [he]89-edward had talked more of [one lady]3359-one lady than another , or seemed in any respect less happy at [Longstaple]32-longstaple than [he]89-edward used to be . [I]128-lucy do not mean to say that [I]128-lucy am particularly observant or quick - sighted in general , but in such a case [I]128-lucy am sure [I]128-lucy could not be deceived . "[128-lucy]

" All this , "[84-elinor] thought [Elinor]84-elinor , " is very pretty ; but it can impose upon neither of [us]3357-our . "[84-elinor]

" But what , "[1274-she] said [she]1274-she after a short silence , " are [your]84-elinor views ? or have [you]84-elinor none but that of waiting for [Mrs. Ferrars]93-lucy s death , which is a melancholy and shocking extremity ? Is [[her]93-lucy son]442-her son determined to submit to this , and to all the tediousness of the many years of suspense in which it may involve [you]84-elinor , rather than run the risk of [her]93-lucy displeasure for a while by owning the truth ? "[1274-she]

" If [we]3357-our could be certain that it would be only for a while ! But [Mrs. Ferrars]93-lucy is [a very headstrong proud woman]3361-a very headstrong proud woman , and in [her]93-lucy first fit of anger upon hearing it , would very likely secure every thing to [Robert]132-robert , and the idea of that , for [Edward]89-edward s sake , frightens away all [my]84-elinor inclination for hasty measures . "[84-elinor]

" And for [your]84-elinor own sake too , or [you]84-elinor are carrying [your]84-elinor disinterestedness beyond reason . "[1274-she]

[Lucy]93-lucy looked at [Elinor]84-elinor again , and was silent .

" Do [you]84-elinor know [Mr. Robert Ferrars]132-robert ? "[84-elinor] asked [Elinor]84-elinor .

" Not at all [I]84-elinor never saw [him]132-robert ; but [I]84-elinor fancy [he]132-robert is very unlike [[his]132-robert brother]2957-his brother silly and [a great coxcomb]3363-a great coxcomb . "[84-elinor]

" [A great coxcomb]3363-a great coxcomb ! "[128-lucy] repeated [Miss Steele]128-lucy , whose ear had caught those words by a sudden pause in [Marianne]85-marianne s music . " Oh , [they]3365-they are talking of [[their]3365-they favourite beaux]3366-their favourite beaux , [I]128-lucy dare say . "[128-lucy]

" [No sister]3367-no sister , "[128-lucy] cried [Lucy]128-lucy , " [you]3367-no sister are mistaken there , [[our]3368-our favourite beaux]3369-our favourite beaux are _ not _ great coxcombs . "[128-lucy]

" [I]98-mrs. jennings can answer for it that [Miss Dashwood]79-miss dashwood s is not , "[98-mrs. jennings] said [Mrs. Jennings]98-mrs. jennings , laughing heartily ; " for [he]132-robert is [one of [the modestest , prettiest behaved young men [I]98-mrs. jennings ever saw]3371-the modestest , prettiest behaved young men i ever saw]3370-one of the modestest , prettiest behaved young men i ever saw ; but as for [Lucy]128-lucy , [she]128-lucy is such [a sly little creature]3372-a sly little creature , there is no finding out who _ [she]128-lucy _ likes . "[98-mrs. jennings]

" Oh , "[128-lucy] cried [Miss Steele]128-lucy , looking significantly round at [them]1275-them , " [I]128-lucy dare say [Lucy]128-lucy s beau is quite as modest and pretty behaved as [Miss Dashwood]79-miss dashwood s. "[128-lucy]

[Elinor]84-elinor blushed in spite of [herself]84-elinor . [Lucy]128-lucy bit [her]128-lucy lip , and looked angrily at [[her]128-lucy sister]301-her sister . A mutual silence took place for some time . [Lucy]128-lucy first put an end to it by saying in a lower tone , though [Marianne]85-marianne was then giving [them]1275-them the powerful protection of a very magnificent concerto ,
