But [he]89-edward was now married ; and [she]84-elinor condemned [her]84-elinor heart for the lurking flattery , which so much heightened the pain of the intelligence .

That [he]89-edward should be married soon , before ( as [she]84-elinor imagined ) [he]89-edward could be in orders , and consequently before [he]89-edward could be in possession of the living , surprised [her]84-elinor a little at first . But [she]84-elinor soon saw how likely it was that [Lucy]93-lucy , in [her]93-lucy self - provident care , in [her]93-lucy haste to secure [him]89-edward , should overlook every thing but the risk of delay . [They]2455-they were married , married in [town]2896-town , and now hastening down to [[her]84-elinor uncle]3663-her uncle s. What had [Edward]89-edward felt on being within four miles from [Barton]8-barton , on seeing [[her]84-elinor mother s servant]2458-her mother s servant , on hearing [Lucy]93-lucy s message !

[They]2455-they would soon , [she]84-elinor supposed , be settled at [Delaford]19-delaford . [Delaford]19-delaford , [that place in which so much conspired to give [her]84-elinor an interest ; which [she]84-elinor wished to be acquainted with , and yet desired to avoid]2459-that place in which so much conspired to give her an interest ; which she wished to be acquainted with , and yet desired to avoid . [She]84-elinor saw [them]2455-they in an instant in [[their]2455-they parsonage - house]2460-their parsonage - house ; saw in [Lucy]93-lucy , [the active , contriving manager]2461-the active , contriving manager , uniting at once a desire of smart appearance with the utmost frugality , and ashamed to be suspected of half [her]93-lucy economical practices ; pursuing [her]84-elinor own interest in every thought , courting the favour of [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon , of [Mrs. Jennings]98-mrs. jennings , and of [every wealthy friend]2462-every wealthy friend . In [Edward]89-edward [she]84-elinor knew not what [she]84-elinor saw , nor what [she]84-elinor wished to see ; happy or unhappy , nothing pleased [her]84-elinor ; [she]84-elinor turned away [her]84-elinor head from every sketch of [him]89-edward .

[Elinor]84-elinor flattered [herself]84-elinor that [some one of [[their]2455-they connections in [London]21-london]2464-their connections in london]2463-some one of their connections in london would write to [them]2455-they to announce the event , and give farther particulars , but day after day passed off , and brought no letter , no tidings . Though uncertain that [any one]631-any one were to blame , [she]84-elinor found fault with [every absent friend]2466-every absent friend . [They]2467-they were all thoughtless or indolent .

" When do [you]84-elinor write to [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon , [ma am]2887-ma am ? "[84-elinor] was an inquiry which sprung from the impatience of [her]84-elinor mind to have something going on .

" [I]84-elinor wrote to [him]99-colonel brandon , [[my]84-elinor love]2700-my love , last week , and rather expect to see , than to hear from [him]99-colonel brandon again . [I]84-elinor earnestly pressed [his]99-colonel brandon coming to [us]2469-us , and should not be surprised to see [him]99-colonel brandon walk in today or tomorrow , or any day . "[84-elinor]

This was gaining something , something to look forward to . [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon _ must _ have some information to give .

Scarcely had [she]84-elinor so determined it , when the figure of [a man on horseback]950-a man on horseback drew [her]84-elinor eyes to the window . [He]950-a man on horseback stopt at [their]2469-us gate . [It]950-a man on horseback was [a gentleman]951-a gentleman , it was [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon [himself]950-a man on horseback . Now [she]84-elinor could hear more ; and [she]84-elinor trembled in expectation of it . But it was _ not [_ Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon ; neither [his]950-a man on horseback air , nor [his]950-a man on horseback height . Were it possible , [she]84-elinor must say it must be [Edward]89-edward . [She]84-elinor looked again . [He]89-edward had just dismounted : [she]84-elinor could not be mistaken , it _ was _ [Edward]89-edward . [She]84-elinor moved away and sat down . " [He]89-edward comes from [Mr. Pratt]133-mr. pratt s purposely to see [us]4546-us . [I]84-elinor _ will _ be calm ; [I]84-elinor _ will _ be [mistress of [myself]84-elinor]4547-mistress of myself . "[84-elinor]

In a moment [she]84-elinor perceived that [the others]505-the others were likewise aware of the mistake . [She]84-elinor saw [[her]84-elinor mother]296-her mother and [Marianne]85-marianne change colour ; saw [them]505-the others look at [herself]84-elinor , and whisper a few sentences to [each other]303-each other . [She]84-elinor would have given [the world]2697-the world to be able to speak and to make [them]505-the others understand that [she]84-elinor hoped no coolness , no slight , would appear in [their]505-the others behaviour to [him]2475-he ; but [she]84-elinor had no utterance , and was obliged to leave all to [their]505-the others own discretion .

Not a syllable passed aloud . [They]505-the others all waited in silence for the appearance of [[their]505-the others visitor]970-their visitor . [His]2475-he footsteps were heard along [the gravel path]2477-the gravel path ; in a moment [he]2475-he was in [the passage]895-the passage , and in another [he]2475-he was before [them]505-the others .

[His]2475-he countenance , as [he]2475-he entered [the room]2756-the room , was not too happy , even for [Elinor]84-elinor . [His]2475-he complexion was white with agitation , and [he]2475-he looked as if fearful of [his]2475-he reception , and conscious that [he]2475-he merited [no kind one]2480-no kind one . [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood , however , conforming , as [she]83-mrs. dashwood trusted , to the wishes of [that daughter]2481-that daughter , by whom [she]83-mrs. dashwood then meant in the warmth of [her]83-mrs. dashwood heart to be guided in every thing , met [him]2475-he with a look of forced complacency , gave [him]2475-he [her]83-mrs. dashwood hand , and wished [him]2475-he joy .

[He]2475-he coloured , and stammered out an unintelligible reply . [Elinor]84-elinor s lips had moved with [[her]84-elinor mother]296-her mother s , and , when the moment of action was over , [she]84-elinor wished that [she]84-elinor had shaken hands with [him]2475-he too . But it was then too late , and with a countenance meaning to be open , [she]84-elinor sat down again and talked of the weather .

[Marianne]85-marianne had retreated as much as possible out of sight , to conceal [her]85-marianne distress ; and [Margaret]86-margaret , understanding some part , but not the whole of the case , thought it incumbent on [her]86-margaret to be dignified , and therefore took a seat as far from [him]2475-he as [she]86-margaret could , and maintained a strict silence .

When [Elinor]84-elinor had ceased to rejoice in the dryness of the season , a very awful pause took place . It was put an end to by [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood , who felt obliged to hope that [he]2475-he had left [Mrs. Ferrars]93-lucy very well . In a hurried manner , [he]2475-he replied in the affirmative .

Another pause .

[Elinor]84-elinor resolving to exert [herself]84-elinor , though fearing the sound of [her]84-elinor own voice , now said ,

" Is [Mrs. Ferrars]93-lucy at [Longstaple]32-longstaple ? "[84-elinor]

" At [Longstaple]32-longstaple ! "[2475-he] [he]2475-he replied , with an air of surprise . " No , [[my]2475-he mother]2691-my mother is in [town]2896-town . "[2475-he]

" [I]84-elinor meant , "[84-elinor] said [Elinor]84-elinor , taking up some work from the table , " to enquire for [Mrs. _ Edward _ Ferrars]202-edward . "[84-elinor]

[She]84-elinor dared not look up ; but [[her]84-elinor mother]296-her mother and [Marianne]85-marianne both turned [their]2484-their eyes on [him]2475-he . [He]2475-he coloured , seemed perplexed , looked doubtingly , and , after some hesitation , said ,

" Perhaps [you]296-her mother mean [[my]2475-he brother]2875-my brother [you]296-her mother mean [Mrs. Mrs. _ Robert _ Ferrars]203-robert . "[2475-he]

" [Mrs. Robert Ferrars]203-robert ! "[296-her mother] was repeated by [Marianne]85-marianne and [[her]85-marianne mother]296-her mother in an accent of the utmost amazement ; and though [Elinor]84-elinor could not speak , even _ [her]296-her mother _ eyes were fixed on [him]2475-he with the same impatient wonder . [He]2475-he rose from [his]2475-he seat , and walked to the window , apparently from not knowing what to do ; took up a pair of scissors that lay there , and while spoiling both them and [their]2486-their sheath by cutting the latter to pieces as [he]2475-he spoke , said , in a hurried voice ,

" Perhaps [you]296-her mother do not know : [you]296-her mother may not have heard that [[my]2475-he brother]2875-my brother is lately married to to [the youngest to [Miss Lucy Steele]128-lucy]4552-the youngest to miss lucy steele . "[2475-he]

[His]2475-he words were echoed with unspeakable astonishment by all but [Elinor]84-elinor , who sat with [her]84-elinor head leaning over [her]84-elinor work , in a state of such agitation as made [her]84-elinor hardly know where [she]84-elinor was .

" Yes , "[2475-he] said [he]2475-he , " [they]4553-they were married last week , and are now at [Dawlish]58-dawlish . "[2475-he]

[Elinor]84-elinor could sit it no longer . [She]84-elinor almost ran out of [the room]2756-the room , and as soon as the door was closed , burst into tears of joy , which at first [she]84-elinor thought would never cease . [Edward]202-edward , who had till then looked any where , rather than at [her]84-elinor , saw [her]84-elinor hurry away , and perhaps saw or even heard , [her]84-elinor emotion ; for immediately afterwards [he]2475-he fell into a reverie , which no remarks , no inquiries , no affectionate address of [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood could penetrate , and at last , without saying a word , quitted [the room]2756-the room , and walked out towards [the village]3105-the village leaving [the others]505-the others in the greatest astonishment and perplexity on a change in [his]2475-he situation , so wonderful and so sudden ; a perplexity which [they]505-the others had no means of lessening but by [their]505-the others own conjectures .

CHAPTER XLIX .

Unaccountable , however , as the circumstances of [his]2475-he release might appear to [the whole family]978-the whole family , it was certain that [Edward]202-edward was free ; and to what purpose that freedom would be employed was easily pre - determined by all ; for after experiencing the blessings of _ one _ imprudent engagement , contracted without [[his]2475-he mother]234-his mother s consent , as [he]2475-he had already done for more than four years , nothing less could be expected of [him]2475-he in the failure of _ that _ , than the immediate contraction of another .

[His]2475-he errand at [Barton]8-barton , in fact , was a simple one . It was only to ask [Elinor]84-elinor to marry [him]2475-he ; and considering that [he]2475-he was not altogether inexperienced in such a question , it might be strange that [he]2475-he should feel so uncomfortable in the present case as [he]2475-he really did , so much in need of encouragement and fresh air .

How soon [he]2475-he had walked [himself]2475-he into the proper resolution , however , how soon an opportunity of exercising it occurred , in what manner [he]2475-he expressed [himself]2475-he , and how [he]2475-he was received , need not be particularly told . This only need be said ; that when [they]2493-they all sat down to table at four o clock , about three hours after [his]2475-he arrival , [he]2475-he had secured [[his]2475-he lady]560-his lady , engaged [[her]560-his lady mother]296-her mother s consent , and was not only in the rapturous profession of [the lover]2496-the lover , but , in the reality of reason and truth , [one of the happiest of [men]2822-men]2497-one of the happiest of men . [His]2475-he situation indeed was more than commonly joyful . [He]2475-he had more than the ordinary triumph of accepted love to swell [his]2475-he heart , and raise [his]2475-he spirits . [He]2475-he was released without any reproach to [himself]2475-he , from an entanglement which had long formed [his]2475-he misery , from [a woman whom [he]2475-he had long ceased to love]2499-a woman whom he had long ceased to love ; and elevated at once to that security with another , which [he]2475-he must have thought of almost with despair , as soon as [he]2475-he had learnt to consider it with desire . [He]2475-he was brought , not from doubt or suspense , but from misery to happiness ; and the change was openly spoken in such a genuine , flowing , grateful cheerfulness , as [[his]2475-he friends]2784-his friends had never witnessed in [him]2475-he before .

[His]2475-he heart was now open to [Elinor]84-elinor , all its weaknesses , all its errors confessed , and [his]2475-he first boyish attachment to [Lucy]128-lucy treated with all the philosophic dignity of twenty - four .

" It was a foolish , idle inclination on [my]2475-he side , "[2475-he] said [he]2475-he , " the consequence of ignorance of [the world]2697-the world , and want of employment . Had [[my]2475-he mother]2691-my mother given [me]2475-he some active profession when [I]2475-he was removed at eighteen from the care of [Mr. Pratt]133-mr. pratt , [I]2475-he think , nay , [I]2475-he am sure , it would never have happened ; for though [I]2475-he left [Longstaple]32-longstaple with what [I]2475-he thought , at the time , a most unconquerable preference for [[his]32-longstaple niece]257-his niece , yet had [I]2475-he then had any pursuit , any object to engage [my]2475-he time and keep [me]2475-he at a distance from [her]257-his niece for a few months , [I]2475-he should very soon have outgrown the fancied attachment , especially by mixing more with [the world]2697-the world , as in such case [I]2475-he must have done . But instead of having any thing to do , instead of having any profession chosen for [me]2475-he , or being allowed to chuse any [myself]2475-he , [I]2475-he returned [home]525-home to be completely idle ; and for the first twelvemonth afterwards [I]2475-he had not even the nominal employment , which belonging to [the university]4559-the university would have given [me]2475-he ; for [I]2475-he was not entered at [Oxford]25-oxford till [I]2475-he was nineteen . [I]2475-he had therefore nothing in [the world]2697-the world to do , but to fancy [myself]2475-he in love ; and as [[my]2475-he mother]2691-my mother did not make [[my]2475-he home]4500-my home in every respect comfortable , as [I]2475-he had [no friend]4563-no friend , [no companion in [[my]2475-he brother]2875-my brother]4564-no companion in my brother , and disliked new acquaintance , it was not unnatural for [me]2475-he to be very often at [Longstaple]32-longstaple , where [I]2475-he always felt [myself]2475-he at [home]525-home , and was always sure of a welcome ; and accordingly [I]2475-he spent the greatest part of [my]2475-he time [there]320-there from eighteen to nineteen : [Lucy]128-lucy appeared everything that was amiable and obliging . [She]128-lucy was pretty too at least [I]2475-he thought so _ then ; _ and [I]2475-he had seen so little of [other women]4568-other women , that [I]2475-he could make no comparisons , and see no defects . Considering everything , therefore , [I]2475-he hope , foolish as [our]2503-our engagement was , foolish as it has since in every way been proved , it was not at the time an unnatural or an inexcusable piece of folly . "[2475-he]

The change which a few hours had wrought in the minds and the happiness of [the Dashwoods]87-the miss dashwoods , was such so great as promised [them]2501-them all , the satisfaction of a sleepless night . [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood , too happy to be comfortable , knew not how to love [Edward]202-edward , nor praise [Elinor]84-elinor enough , how to be enough thankful for [his]2502-his release without wounding [his]2502-his delicacy , nor how at once to give [them]2503-our leisure for unrestrained conversation together , and yet enjoy , as [she]83-mrs. dashwood wished , the sight and society of both .

[Marianne]85-marianne could speak _ [her]85-marianne _ happiness only by tears . Comparisons would occur regrets would arise ; and [her]85-marianne joy , though sincere as [her]85-marianne love for [[her]85-marianne sister]301-her sister , was of a kind to give [her]85-marianne neither spirits nor language .

But [Elinor]84-elinor how are _ [her]85-marianne _ feelings to be described ? From the moment of learning that [Lucy]128-lucy was married to [another]3727-another , that [Edward]202-edward was free , to the moment of [his]2502-his justifying the hopes which had so instantly followed , [she]128-lucy was every thing by turns but tranquil . But when the second moment had passed , when [she]83-mrs. dashwood found every doubt , every solicitude removed , compared [her]83-mrs. dashwood situation with what so lately it had been , saw [him]2502-his honourably released from [his]2502-his former engagement , saw [him]2502-his instantly profiting by the release , to address [herself]83-mrs. dashwood and declare an affection as tender , as constant as [she]83-mrs. dashwood had ever supposed it to be , [she]83-mrs. dashwood was oppressed , [she]83-mrs. dashwood was overcome by [her]83-mrs. dashwood own felicity ; and happily disposed as is [the human mind]2506-the human mind to be easily familiarized with any change for the better , it required several hours to give sedateness to [her]83-mrs. dashwood spirits , or any degree of tranquillity to [her]83-mrs. dashwood heart .

[Edward]202-edward was now fixed at [the cottage]471-the cottage at least for a week ; for whatever other claims might be made on [him]2502-his , it was impossible that less than a week should be given up to the enjoyment of [Elinor]84-elinor s company , or suffice to say half that was to be said of the past , the present , and the future ; for though a very few hours spent in the hard labor of incessant talking will despatch more subjects than can really be in common between [any two rational creatures]2508-any two rational creatures , yet with [lovers]613-lovers it is different . Between _ [them]613-lovers _ [no subject]2510-no subject is finished , no communication is even made , till it has been made at least twenty times over .

[Lucy]128-lucy s marriage , the unceasing and reasonable wonder among [them]613-lovers all , formed of course one of the earliest discussions of [the lovers]2511-the lovers ; and [Elinor]84-elinor s particular knowledge of [each party]2512-each party made it appear to [her]83-mrs. dashwood in every view , as one of the most extraordinary and unaccountable circumstances [she]83-mrs. dashwood had ever heard . How [they]613-lovers could be thrown together , and by what attraction [Robert]203-robert could be drawn on to marry [a girl]3559-a girl , of whose beauty [she]83-mrs. dashwood had [herself]83-mrs. dashwood heard [him]2502-his speak without any admiration , [a girl too already engaged to [[his]2502-his brother]2957-his brother , and on whose account [that brother]2079-that brother had been thrown off by [[his]2079-that brother family]531-his family]2514-a girl too already engaged to his brother , and on whose account that brother had been thrown off by his family it was beyond [her]83-mrs. dashwood comprehension to make out . To [her]83-mrs. dashwood own heart it was a delightful affair , to [her]83-mrs. dashwood imagination it was even a ridiculous one , but to [her]83-mrs. dashwood reason , [her]83-mrs. dashwood judgment , it was completely a puzzle .

[Edward]202-edward could only attempt an explanation by supposing , that , perhaps , at first accidentally meeting , the vanity of [the one]1905-the one had been so worked on by the flattery of [the other]738-the other , as to lead by degrees to all the rest . [Elinor]84-elinor remembered what [Robert]203-robert had told [her]84-elinor in [Harley Street]56-harley street , of [his]2502-his opinion of what [his]2502-his own mediation in [[his]2502-his brother]2957-his brother s affairs might have done , if applied to in time . [She]84-elinor repeated it to [Edward]202-edward .

" _ That _ was exactly like [Robert]203-robert , "[2502-his] was [his]2502-his immediate observation . " And _ that _ , "[2502-his] [he]2502-his presently added , " might perhaps be in _ [his]2502-his _ head when the acquaintance between [them]2521-them first began . And [Lucy]128-lucy perhaps at first might think only of procuring [his]2502-his good offices in [my]2502-his favour . Other designs might afterward arise . "[2502-his]

How long it had been carrying on between [them]2521-them , however , [he]2502-his was equally at a loss with [herself]84-elinor to make out ; for at [Oxford]25-oxford , where [he]2502-his had remained for choice ever since [his]2502-his quitting [London]21-london , [he]2502-his had had no means of hearing of [her]84-elinor but from [herself]84-elinor , and [her]84-elinor letters to the very last were neither less frequent , nor less affectionate than usual . Not the smallest suspicion , therefore , had ever occurred to prepare [him]2502-his for what followed ; and when at last it burst on [him]2502-his in a letter from [Lucy]128-lucy [herself]84-elinor , [he]2502-his had been for some time , [he]2502-his believed , half stupified between the wonder , the horror , and the joy of such a deliverance . [He]2502-his put the letter into [Elinor]84-elinor s hands .

" [DEAR SIR]4569-dear sir , "[2502-his] Being very sure [I]9-exeter have long lost [your]2502-his affections , [I]9-exeter have thought [myself]9-exeter at liberty to bestow [my]9-exeter own on [another]3727-another , and have no doubt of being as happy with [him]3727-another as [I]9-exeter once used to think [I]9-exeter might be with [you]2502-his ; but [I]9-exeter scorn to accept a hand while the heart was another s. Sincerely wish [you]2502-his happy in [your]2502-his choice , and it shall not be [my]9-exeter fault if [we]2523-we are not always [good friends]2524-good friends , as [our]2523-we near relationship now makes proper . [I]9-exeter can safely say [I]9-exeter owe [you]2502-his no ill - will , and am sure [you]2502-his will be too generous to do [us]2523-we any ill offices . [[Your]2502-his brother]3279-your brother has gained [my]9-exeter affections entirely , and as [we]2523-we could not live without [one another]1049-one another , [we]2523-we are just returned from the altar , and are now on [our]2523-we way to [Dawlish]58-dawlish for a few weeks , which place [[your]2502-his dear brother]2527-your dear brother has great curiosity to see , but thought [I]9-exeter would first trouble [you]2502-his with these few lines , and shall always remain ,

" [[Your]2502-his sincere well - wisher]4570-your sincere well - wisher , [friend]4571-friend , and [sister]405-sister , "[93-lucy] [LUCY FERRARS]93-lucy .

" [I]93-lucy have burnt all [your]2502-his letters , and will return [your]2502-his picture the first opportunity . Please to destroy [my]93-lucy scrawls but the ring with [my]93-lucy hair [you]2502-his are very welcome to keep . "[93-lucy]

[Elinor]84-elinor read and returned it without any comment .

" [I]202-edward will not ask [your]84-elinor opinion of it as a composition , "[202-edward] said [Edward]202-edward . " For worlds would not [I]202-edward have had a letter of [hers]405-sister seen by _ [you]2502-his _ in former days . In [a sister]3807-a sister it is bad enough , but in [a wife]2788-a wife ! how [I]202-edward have blushed over the pages of [her]405-sister writing ! and [I]202-edward believe [I]202-edward may say that since the first half year of [our]4575-our foolish business this is the only letter [I]202-edward ever received from [her]405-sister , of which the substance made [me]202-edward any amends for the defect of the style . "[202-edward]

" However it may have come about , "[84-elinor] said [Elinor]84-elinor , after a pause , " [they]4575-our are certainly married . And [[your]2502-his mother]2698-your mother has brought on [herself]2698-your mother a most appropriate punishment . The independence [she]2698-your mother settled on [Robert]203-robert , through resentment against [you]2502-his , has put it in [his]2502-his power to make [his]2502-his own choice ; and [she]2698-your mother has actually been bribing [one son]229-one son with a thousand a - year , to do the very deed which [she]2698-your mother disinherited the other for intending to do . [She]2698-your mother will hardly be less hurt , [I]84-elinor suppose , by [Robert]203-robert s marrying [Lucy]93-lucy , than [she]2698-your mother would have been by [your]2502-his marrying [her]2698-your mother . "[84-elinor]

" [She]2698-your mother will be more hurt by it , for [Robert]203-robert always was [her]2698-your mother favourite . [She]2698-your mother will be more hurt by it , and on the same principle will forgive [him]2530-he much sooner . "[2529-any of his family]

In what state the affair stood at present between [them]2528-them , [Edward]202-edward knew not , for no communication with [any of [[his]2530-he family]531-his family]2529-any of his family had yet been attempted by [him]2530-he . [He]2530-he had quitted [Oxford]25-oxford within four and twenty hours after [Lucy]93-lucy s letter arrived , and with only one object before [him]2530-he , [the nearest road to [Barton]8-barton]2532-the nearest road to barton , had had no leisure to form any scheme of conduct , with which [that road]2533-that road did not hold the most intimate connection . [He]2530-he could do nothing till [he]2530-he were assured of [his]2530-he fate with [Miss Dashwood]79-miss dashwood ; and by [his]2530-he rapidity in seeking _ that _ fate , it is to be supposed , in spite of the jealousy with which [he]2530-he had once thought of [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon , in spite of the modesty with which [he]2530-he rated [his]2530-he own deserts , and the politeness with which [he]2530-he talked of [his]2530-he doubts , [he]2530-he did not , upon the whole , expect a very cruel reception . It was [his]2530-he business , however , to say that [he]2530-he _ did _ , and [he]2530-he said it very prettily . What [he]2530-he might say on the subject a twelvemonth after , must be referred to the imagination of [husbands]614-husbands and [wives]2535-wives .

That [Lucy]93-lucy had certainly meant to deceive , to go off with a flourish of malice against [him]2530-he in [her]93-lucy message by [Thomas]169-thomas , was perfectly clear to [Elinor]84-elinor ; and [Edward]202-edward [himself]202-edward , now thoroughly enlightened on [her]84-elinor character , had no scruple in believing [her]84-elinor capable of the utmost meanness of wanton ill - nature . Though [his]2530-he eyes had been long opened , even before [his]2530-he acquaintance with [Elinor]84-elinor began , to [her]84-elinor ignorance and a want of liberality in some of [her]84-elinor opinions they had been equally imputed , by [him]2530-he , to [her]84-elinor want of education ; and till [her]84-elinor last letter reached [him]2530-he , [he]2530-he had always believed [her]84-elinor to be [a well - disposed , good - hearted girl]2536-a well - disposed , good - hearted girl , and thoroughly attached to [himself]2530-he . Nothing but such a persuasion could have prevented [his]2530-he putting an end to an engagement , which , long before the discovery of it laid [him]2530-he open to [[his]2530-he mother]234-his mother s anger , had been a continual source of disquiet and regret to [him]2530-he .

" [I]2530-he thought it [my]2530-he duty , "[2530-he] said [he]2530-he , " independent of [my]2530-he feelings , to give [her]84-elinor the option of continuing the engagement or not , when [I]2530-he was renounced by [[my]2530-he mother]2691-my mother , and stood to all appearance without [a friend in [the world]2697-the world]4579-a friend in the world to assist [me]2530-he . In such a situation as that , where there seemed nothing to tempt the avarice or the vanity of [any living creature]4581-any living creature , how could [I]2530-he suppose , when [she]84-elinor so earnestly , so warmly insisted on sharing [my]2530-he fate , whatever it might be , that any thing but the most disinterested affection was [her]84-elinor inducement ? And even now , [I]2530-he can not comprehend on what motive [she]84-elinor acted , or what fancied advantage it could be to [her]84-elinor , to be fettered to [a man for whom [she]84-elinor had not the smallest regard , and who had only two thousand pounds in [the world]2697-the world]4582-a man for whom she had not the smallest regard , and who had only two thousand pounds in the world . [She]84-elinor could not foresee that [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon would give [me]2530-he a living . "[2530-he]

" No ; but [she]84-elinor might suppose that something would occur in [your]2530-he favour ; that [[your]2530-he own family]4584-your own family might in time relent . And at any rate , [she]84-elinor lost nothing by continuing the engagement , for [she]84-elinor has proved that it fettered neither [her]84-elinor inclination nor [her]84-elinor actions . The connection was certainly a respectable one , and probably gained [her]84-elinor consideration among [[her]84-elinor friends]1607-her friends ; and , if nothing more advantageous occurred , it would be better for [her]84-elinor to marry _ [you]2530-he _ than be single . "[2538-his]

[Edward]202-edward was , of course , immediately convinced that nothing could have been more natural than [Lucy]93-lucy s conduct , nor more self - evident than the motive of it .

[Elinor]84-elinor scolded [him]2538-his , harshly as [ladies]3799-ladies always scold the imprudence which compliments [themselves]3799-ladies , for having spent so much time with [them]3799-ladies at [Norland]3-norland , when [he]2538-his must have felt [his]2538-his own inconstancy .

" [Your]2538-his behaviour was certainly very wrong , "[84-elinor] said [she]84-elinor ; " because to say nothing of [my]84-elinor own conviction , [our]4586-our relations were all led away by it to fancy and expect _ what _ , as [you]2538-his were _ then _ situated , could never be . "[84-elinor]

[He]2538-his could only plead an ignorance of [his]2538-his own heart , and a mistaken confidence in the force of [his]2538-his engagement .

" [I]84-elinor was simple enough to think , that because [my]84-elinor _ faith _ was plighted to another , there could be no danger in [my]84-elinor being with [you]2538-his ; and that the consciousness of [my]84-elinor engagement was to keep [my]84-elinor heart as safe and sacred as [my]84-elinor honour . [I]84-elinor felt that [I]84-elinor admired [you]2538-his , but [I]84-elinor told [myself]84-elinor it was only friendship ; and till [I]84-elinor began to make comparisons between [yourself]2538-his and [Lucy]93-lucy , [I]84-elinor did not know how far [I]84-elinor was got . After that , [I]84-elinor suppose , [I]84-elinor _ was _ wrong in remaining so much in [Sussex]1-sussex , and the arguments with which [I]84-elinor reconciled [myself]84-elinor to the expediency of it , were no better than these : The danger is [my]84-elinor own ; [I]84-elinor am doing no injury to [anybody]1700-anybody but [myself]84-elinor . "[84-elinor]

[Elinor]84-elinor smiled , and shook [her]84-elinor head .

[Edward]202-edward heard with pleasure of [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon s being expected at [the Cottage]471-the cottage , as [he]2541-he really wished not only to be better acquainted with [him]99-colonel brandon , but to have an opportunity of convincing [him]99-colonel brandon that [he]2541-he no longer resented [his]99-colonel brandon giving [him]99-colonel brandon the living of [Delaford]19-delaford " Which , at present , "[2541-he] said [he]2541-he , " after thanks so ungraciously delivered as [mine]2541-he were on the occasion , [he]99-colonel brandon must think [I]2541-he have never forgiven [him]99-colonel brandon for offering . "[2541-he]

_ Now _ [he]2541-he felt astonished [himself]2541-he that [he]2541-he had never yet been to [the place]430-the place . But so little interest had [he]2541-he taken in the matter , that [he]2541-he owed all [his]2541-he knowledge of [the house]281-the house , [garden]422-garden , and glebe , extent of [the parish]2890-the parish , condition of [the land]3822-the land , and rate of the tithes , to [Elinor]84-elinor [herself]84-elinor , who had heard so much of it from [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon , and heard it with so much attention , as to be entirely mistress of the subject .

One question after this only remained undecided , between [them]2547-their , one difficulty only was to be overcome . [They]2547-their were brought together by mutual affection , with the warmest approbation of [[their]2547-their real friends]2548-their real friends ; [their]2547-their intimate knowledge of each other seemed to make [their]2547-their happiness certain and [they]2547-their only wanted something to live upon . [Edward]202-edward had two thousand pounds , and [Elinor]84-elinor one , which , with [Delaford]19-delaford living , was all that [they]2547-their could call [their]2547-their own ; for it was impossible that [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood should advance anything ; and [they]2547-their were neither of [them]2547-their quite enough in love to think that three hundred and fifty pounds a - year would supply [them]2547-their with the comforts of life .

[Edward]202-edward was not entirely without hopes of some favourable change in [[his]2549-his mother]234-his mother towards [him]2549-his ; and on _ that _ [he]2549-his rested for the residue of [their]2547-their income . But [Elinor]84-elinor had no such dependence ; for since [Edward]202-edward would still be unable to marry [Miss Morton]165-miss morton , and [his]2549-his chusing [herself]165-miss morton had been spoken of in [Mrs. Ferrars]202-edward s flattering language as only a lesser evil than [his]2549-his chusing [Lucy Steele]128-lucy , [she]84-elinor feared that [Robert]203-robert s offence would serve no other purpose than to enrich [Fanny]88-fanny .

About four days after [Edward]202-edward s arrival [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon appeared , to complete [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood s satisfaction , and to give [her]83-mrs. dashwood the dignity of having , for the first time since [her]83-mrs. dashwood living at [Barton]8-barton , more company with [her]83-mrs. dashwood than [[her]83-mrs. dashwood house]2719-her house would hold . [Edward]202-edward was allowed to retain the privilege of [first comer]2552-first comer , and [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon therefore walked every night to [[his]99-colonel brandon old quarters at [the Park]533-the park]2553-his old quarters at the park ; from whence [he]99-colonel brandon usually returned in the morning , early enough to interrupt [the lovers]2511-the lovers first t te- -t te before breakfast .

A three weeks residence at [Delaford]19-delaford , where , in [his]99-colonel brandon evening hours at least , [he]99-colonel brandon had little to do but to calculate the disproportion between thirty - six and seventeen , brought [him]99-colonel brandon to [Barton]8-barton in a temper of mind which needed all the improvement in [Marianne]85-marianne s looks , all the kindness of [her]85-marianne welcome , and all the encouragement of [her]85-marianne mother s language , to make it cheerful . Among [such friends]3900-such friends , however , and such flattery , [he]99-colonel brandon did revive . No rumour of [Lucy]128-lucy s marriage had yet reached [him]99-colonel brandon : [he]99-colonel brandon knew nothing of what had passed ; and the first hours of [his]99-colonel brandon visit were consequently spent in hearing and in wondering . Every thing was explained to [him]99-colonel brandon by [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood , and [he]99-colonel brandon found fresh reason to rejoice in what [he]99-colonel brandon had done for [Mr. Ferrars]89-edward , since eventually it promoted the interest of [Elinor]84-elinor .

It would be needless to say , that [the gentlemen]1761-the gentlemen advanced in the good opinion of [each other]303-each other , as [they]1761-the gentlemen advanced in [each other]303-each other s acquaintance , for it could not be otherwise . [Their]1761-the gentlemen resemblance in good principles and good sense , in disposition and manner of thinking , would probably have been sufficient to unite [them]1761-the gentlemen in friendship , without any other attraction ; but [their]1761-the gentlemen being in love with [two sisters]2560-two sisters , and [two sisters]2560-two sisters fond of [each other]303-each other , made that mutual regard inevitable and immediate , which might otherwise have waited the effect of time and judgment .

The letters from [town]2896-town , which a few days before would have made every nerve in [Elinor]84-elinor s body thrill with transport , now arrived to be read with less emotion than mirth . [Mrs. Jennings]98-mrs. jennings wrote to tell the wonderful tale , to vent [her]98-mrs. jennings honest indignation against [the jilting girl]2564-the jilting girl , and pour forth [her]98-mrs. jennings compassion towards [poor Mr. Edward]89-edward , who , [she]98-mrs. jennings was sure , had quite doted upon [the worthless hussy]2565-the worthless hussy , and was now , by all accounts , almost broken - hearted , at [Oxford]25-oxford . " [I]98-mrs. jennings do think , "[98-mrs. jennings] [she]98-mrs. jennings continued , " nothing was ever carried on so sly ; for it was but two days before [Lucy]128-lucy called and sat a couple of hours with [me]98-mrs. jennings . [Not a soul]4588-not a soul suspected anything of the matter , not even [Nancy]131-nancy , who , [poor soul]3539-poor soul ! came crying to [me]98-mrs. jennings the day after , in a great fright for fear of [Mrs. Ferrars]202-edward , as well as not knowing how to get to [Plymouth]22-plymouth ; for [Lucy]128-lucy it seems borrowed all [her]128-lucy money before [she]128-lucy went off to be married , on purpose [we]4590-we suppose to make a show with , and poor [Nancy]131-nancy had not seven shillings in [the world]2697-the world ; so [I]98-mrs. jennings was very glad to give [her]128-lucy five guineas to take [her]128-lucy down to [Exeter]9-exeter , where [she]128-lucy thinks of staying three or four weeks with [Mrs. Burgess]205-mrs. burgess , in hopes , as [I]98-mrs. jennings tell [her]128-lucy , to fall in with [the Doctor]3761-the doctor again . And [I]98-mrs. jennings must say that [Lucy]128-lucy s crossness not to take [them]4593-them along with [them]4593-them in the chaise is worse than all . [Poor Mr. Edward]89-edward ! [I]98-mrs. jennings can not get [him]89-edward out of [my]98-mrs. jennings head , but [you]89-edward must send for [him]89-edward to [Barton]8-barton , and [Miss Marianne]85-marianne must try to comfort [him]89-edward . "[98-mrs. jennings]

[Mr. Dashwood]80-mr. dashwood s strains were more solemn . [Mrs. Ferrars]202-edward was the most unfortunate of women poor [Fanny]88-fanny had suffered agonies of sensibility and [he]80-mr. dashwood considered the existence of each , under such a blow , with grateful wonder . [Robert]203-robert s offence was unpardonable , but [Lucy]128-lucy s was infinitely worse . Neither of [them]2566-them were ever again to be mentioned to [Mrs. Ferrars]203-robert ; and even , if [she]203-robert might hereafter be induced to forgive [[her]203-robert son]442-her son , [[his]80-mr. dashwood wife]245-his wife should never be acknowledged as [[her]203-robert daughter]371-her daughter , nor be permitted to appear in [her]203-robert presence . The secrecy with which everything had been carried on between [them]2566-them , was rationally treated as enormously heightening the crime , because , had any suspicion of it occurred to [the others]505-the others , proper measures would have been taken to prevent the marriage ; and [he]80-mr. dashwood called on [Elinor]84-elinor to join with [him]80-mr. dashwood in regretting that [Lucy]128-lucy s engagement with [Edward]202-edward had not rather been fulfilled , than that [she]128-lucy should thus be the means of spreading misery farther in [the family]267-the family . [He]80-mr. dashwood thus continued :

" [Mrs. Ferrars]202-edward has never yet mentioned [Edward]202-edward s name , which does not surprise [us]4594-us ; but , to [our]4594-us great astonishment , not a line has been received from [him]80-mr. dashwood on the occasion . Perhaps , however , [he]80-mr. dashwood is kept silent by [his]80-mr. dashwood fear of offending , and [I]80-mr. dashwood shall , therefore , give [him]80-mr. dashwood a hint , by a line to [Oxford]25-oxford , that [[his]80-mr. dashwood sister]215-his sister and [I]80-mr. dashwood both think a letter of proper submission from [him]80-mr. dashwood , addressed perhaps to [Fanny]88-fanny , and by [her]88-fanny shown to [[her]88-fanny mother]296-her mother , might not be taken amiss ; for [we]2573-we all know the tenderness of [Mrs. Ferrars]202-edward s heart , and that [she]202-edward wishes for nothing so much as to be on good terms with [[her]202-edward children]459-her children . "[80-mr. dashwood]

This paragraph was of some importance to the prospects and conduct of [Edward]202-edward . It determined [him]2572-i to attempt a reconciliation , though not exactly in the manner pointed out by [[their]2573-we brother]293-their brother and [sister]405-sister .

" A letter of proper submission ! "[2572-i] repeated [he]2572-i ; " would [they]2573-we have [me]2572-i beg [[my]2572-i mother]2691-my mother s pardon for [Robert]203-robert s ingratitude to _ [her]2691-my mother _ , and breach of honour to _ [me]2572-i ? _ [I]2572-i can make no submission . [I]2572-i am grown neither humble nor penitent by what has passed . [I]2572-i am grown very happy ; but that would not interest . [I]2572-i know of no submission that _ is _ proper for [me]2572-i to make . "[2572-i]

" [You]2576-he may certainly ask to be forgiven , "[84-elinor] said [Elinor]84-elinor , " because [you]2576-he have offended ; and [I]84-elinor should think [you]2576-he might _ now _ venture so far as to profess some concern for having ever formed the engagement which drew on [you]2576-he [[your]2576-he mother]2698-your mother s anger . "[84-elinor]

[He]2576-he agreed that [he]2576-he might .

" And when [she]2698-your mother has forgiven [you]2576-he , perhaps a little humility may be convenient while acknowledging a second engagement , almost as imprudent in _ [her]2698-your mother _ eyes as the first . "[2572-i]

[He]2576-he had nothing to urge against it , but still resisted the idea of a letter of proper submission ; and therefore , to make it easier to [him]2576-he , as [he]2576-he declared a much greater willingness to make mean concessions by word of mouth than on paper , it was resolved that , instead of writing to [Fanny]88-fanny , [he]2576-he should go to [London]21-london , and personally intreat [her]88-fanny good offices in [his]2576-he favour . " And if [they]2150-the two gentlemen really _ do _ interest [themselves]2150-the two gentlemen , "[85-marianne] said [Marianne]85-marianne , in [her]85-marianne new character of candour , " in bringing about a reconciliation , [I]85-marianne shall think that even [John]83-mrs. dashwood and [Fanny]88-fanny are not entirely without merit . "[85-marianne]

After a visit on [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon s side of only three or four days , [the two gentlemen]2150-the two gentlemen quitted [Barton]6-barton park together . [They]2150-the two gentlemen were to go immediately to [Delaford]19-delaford , that [Edward]202-edward might have some personal knowledge of [[his]2576-he future home]2578-his future home , and assist [[his]2576-he patron]2579-his patron and [friend]4571-friend in deciding on what improvements were needed to it ; and from thence , after staying there a couple of nights , [he]2576-he was to proceed on [his]2576-he journey to [town]2896-town .

CHAPTER L.

After a proper resistance on the part of [Mrs. Ferrars]202-edward , just so violent and so steady as to preserve [her]202-edward from that reproach which [she]202-edward always seemed fearful of incurring , the reproach of being too amiable , [Edward]202-edward was admitted to [her]202-edward presence , and pronounced to be again [[her]202-edward son]442-her son .

[[Her]202-edward family]358-her family had of late been exceedingly fluctuating . For many years of [her]202-edward life [she]202-edward had had [two sons]2584-two sons ; but the crime and annihilation of [Edward]202-edward a few weeks ago , had robbed [her]202-edward of one ; the similar annihilation of [Robert]203-robert had left [her]202-edward for a fortnight without any ; and now , by the resuscitation of [Edward]202-edward , [she]202-edward had one again .

In spite of [his]2576-he being allowed once more to live , however , [he]2576-he did not feel the continuance of [his]2576-he existence secure , till [he]2576-he had revealed [his]2576-he present engagement ; for the publication of that circumstance , [he]2576-he feared , might give a sudden turn to [his]2576-he constitution , and carry [him]2576-he off as rapidly as before . With apprehensive caution therefore it was revealed , and [he]2576-he was listened to with unexpected calmness . [Mrs. Ferrars]202-edward at first reasonably endeavoured to dissuade [him]2576-he from marrying [Miss Dashwood]79-miss dashwood , by every argument in [her]202-edward power ; told [him]2576-he , that in [Miss Morton]165-miss morton [he]2576-he would have [a woman of higher rank and larger fortune]2585-a woman of higher rank and larger fortune ; and enforced the assertion , by observing that [Miss Morton]165-miss morton was [the daughter of [a nobleman with thirty thousand pounds]2587-a nobleman with thirty thousand pounds]2586-the daughter of a nobleman with thirty thousand pounds , while [Miss Dashwood]79-miss dashwood was only [the daughter of [a private gentleman with no more than _ three]2589-a private gentleman with no more than _ three]2588-the daughter of a private gentleman with no more than _ three ; _ but when [she]202-edward found that , though perfectly admitting the truth of [her]202-edward representation , [he]2576-he was by no means inclined to be guided by it , [she]202-edward judged it wisest , from the experience of the past , to submit and therefore , after such an ungracious delay as [she]202-edward owed to [her]202-edward own dignity , and as served to prevent every suspicion of good - will , [she]202-edward issued [her]202-edward decree of consent to the marriage of [Edward]202-edward and [Elinor]84-elinor .

What [she]202-edward would engage to do towards augmenting [their]2590-their income was next to be considered ; and here it plainly appeared , that though [Edward]202-edward was now [[her]202-edward only son]2591-her only son , [he]2591-her only son was by no means [[her]202-edward eldest]2592-her eldest ; for while [Robert]203-robert was inevitably endowed with a thousand pounds a - year , not the smallest objection was made against [Edward]202-edward s taking orders for the sake of two hundred and fifty at the utmost ; nor was anything promised either for the present or in future , beyond the ten thousand pounds , which had been given with [Fanny]88-fanny .

It was as much , however , as was desired , and more than was expected , by [Edward]202-edward and [Elinor]84-elinor ; and [Mrs. Ferrars]2593-mrs. ferrars [herself]2593-mrs. ferrars , by [her]2593-mrs. ferrars shuffling excuses , seemed [the only person]2594-the only person surprised at [her]2593-mrs. ferrars not giving more .

With an income quite sufficient to [their]2590-their wants thus secured to [them]2590-their , [they]2590-their had nothing to wait for after [Edward]202-edward was in possession of the living , but the readiness of [the house]281-the house , to which [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon , with an eager desire for the accommodation of [Elinor]84-elinor , was making considerable improvements ; and after waiting some time for [their]2590-their completion , after experiencing , as usual , a thousand disappointments and delays from the unaccountable dilatoriness of [the workmen]2596-the workmen , [Elinor]84-elinor , as usual , broke through the first positive resolution of not marrying till every thing was ready , and the ceremony took place in [Barton church]2597-barton church early in the autumn .

The first month after [their]2590-their marriage was spent with [[their]2590-their friend]1855-their friend at [the Mansion - house]4237-the mansion - house ; from whence [they]2590-their could superintend the progress of [the Parsonage]4236-the parsonage , and direct every thing as [they]2590-their liked on the spot ; could chuse papers , project shrubberies , and invent a sweep . [Mrs. Jennings]98-mrs. jennings s prophecies , though rather jumbled together , were chiefly fulfilled ; for [she]98-mrs. jennings was able to visit [Edward]202-edward and [[his]99-colonel brandon wife]245-his wife in [[their]2590-their Parsonage]2602-their parsonage by [Michaelmas]161-michaelmas , and [she]98-mrs. jennings found in [Elinor]84-elinor and [[her]84-elinor husband]282-her husband , as [she]98-mrs. jennings really believed , [one of [the happiest couples in [the world]2697-the world]2605-the happiest couples in the world]2604-one of the happiest couples in the world . [They]2590-their had in fact nothing to wish for , but the marriage of [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon and [Marianne]85-marianne , and rather better pasturage for [their]2590-their cows .

[They]2590-their were visited on [their]2590-their first settling by almost all [[their]2590-their relations]2607-their relations and [friends]3144-friends . [Mrs. Ferrars]202-edward came to inspect the happiness which [she]202-edward was almost ashamed of having authorised ; and even [the Dashwoods]87-the miss dashwoods were at the expense of a journey from [Sussex]1-sussex to do [them]2590-their honour .

" [I]83-mrs. dashwood will not say that [I]83-mrs. dashwood am disappointed , [[my]83-mrs. dashwood dear sister]3512-my dear sister , "[83-mrs. dashwood] said [John]83-mrs. dashwood , as [they]2590-their were walking together one morning before the gates of [Delaford House]76-delaford house , " _ that _ would be saying too much , for certainly [you]3512-my dear sister have been [one of [the most fortunate young women in [the world]2697-the world]4602-the most fortunate young women in the world]4601-one of the most fortunate young women in the world , as it is . But , [I]83-mrs. dashwood confess , it would give [me]83-mrs. dashwood great pleasure to call [[Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon brother]4604-colonel brandon brother . [[His]99-colonel brandon property here]4605-his property here , [[his]99-colonel brandon place]4606-his place , [[his]99-colonel brandon house]479-his house , every thing is in such respectable and excellent condition ! And [[his]99-colonel brandon woods]4608-his woods , [I]83-mrs. dashwood have not seen such timber any where in [Dorsetshire]45-dorsetshire , as there is now standing in [Delaford Hanger]77-delaford hanger ! And though , perhaps , [Marianne]85-marianne may not seem exactly the person to attract [him]99-colonel brandon , yet [I]83-mrs. dashwood think it would altogether be advisable for [you]4609-you to have [them]4610-them now frequently staying with [you]4609-you , for as [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon seems a great deal at [home]525-home , [nobody]2834-nobody can tell what may happen ; for , when [people]2690-people are much thrown together , and see little of [anybody else]4614-anybody else , and it will always be in [your]4609-you power to set [her]85-marianne off to advantage , and so forth . In short , [you]4609-you may as well give [her]85-marianne a chance : [you]4609-you understand [me]83-mrs. dashwood . "[83-mrs. dashwood]

But though [Mrs. Ferrars]202-edward _ did _ come to see [them]2609-them , and always treated [them]2609-them with the make - believe of decent affection , [they]2609-them were never insulted by [her]202-edward real favour and preference . _ That _ was due to the folly of [Robert]203-robert , and the cunning of [[his]2610-his wife]245-his wife ; and it was earned by [them]2609-them before many months had passed away . The selfish sagacity of [the latter]289-the latter , which had at first drawn [Robert]203-robert into the scrape , was the principal instrument of [his]2610-his deliverance from it ; for [her]202-edward respectful humility , assiduous attentions , and endless flatteries , as soon as the smallest opening was given for [their]2609-them exercise , reconciled [Mrs. Ferrars]203-robert to [his]2610-his choice , and re - established [him]2610-his completely in [her]202-edward favour .

The whole of [Lucy]128-lucy s behaviour in the affair , and the prosperity which crowned it , therefore , may be held forth as a most encouraging instance of what an earnest , an unceasing attention to self - interest , however its progress may be apparently obstructed , will do in securing every advantage of fortune , with no other sacrifice than that of time and conscience . When [Robert]203-robert first sought [her]128-lucy acquaintance , and privately visited [her]128-lucy in [Bartlett s Buildings]48-bartlett s buildings , it was only with the view imputed to [him]2610-his by [[his]2610-his brother]2957-his brother . [He]2610-his merely meant to persuade [her]128-lucy to give up the engagement ; and as there could be nothing to overcome but the affection of both , [he]2610-his naturally expected that one or two interviews would settle the matter . In that point , however , and that only , [he]2610-his erred ; for though [Lucy]128-lucy soon gave [him]2610-his hopes that [his]2610-his eloquence would convince [her]128-lucy in _ time _ , another visit , another conversation , was always wanted to produce this conviction . Some doubts always lingered in [her]128-lucy mind when [they]2614-they parted , which could only be removed by another half hour s discourse with [himself]203-robert . [His]2610-his attendance was by this means secured , and the rest followed in course . Instead of talking of [Edward]202-edward , [they]2614-they came gradually to talk only of [Robert]203-robert , a subject on which [he]2610-his had always more to say than on any other , and in which [she]128-lucy soon betrayed an interest even equal to [his]2610-his own ; and in short , it became speedily evident to [both]565-both , that [he]2610-his had entirely supplanted [[his]2610-his brother]2957-his brother . [He]2610-his was proud of [his]2610-his conquest , proud of tricking [Edward]202-edward , and very proud of marrying privately without [[his]2610-his mother]234-his mother s consent . What immediately followed is known . [They]2614-they passed some months in great happiness at [Dawlish]58-dawlish ; for [she]128-lucy had many relations and [old acquaintances]2618-old acquaintances to cut and [he]2610-his drew several plans for [magnificent cottages]2619-magnificent cottages ; and from thence returning to [town]2896-town , procured the forgiveness of [Mrs. Ferrars]202-edward , by the simple expedient of asking it , which , at [Lucy]128-lucy s instigation , was adopted . The forgiveness , at first , indeed , as was reasonable , comprehended only [Robert]203-robert ; and [Lucy]128-lucy , who had owed [[his]2610-his mother]234-his mother no duty and therefore could have transgressed none , still remained some weeks longer unpardoned . But perseverance in humility of conduct and messages , in self - condemnation for [Robert]203-robert s offence , and gratitude for the unkindness [she]128-lucy was treated with , procured [her]128-lucy in time the haughty notice which overcame [her]128-lucy by its graciousness , and led soon afterwards , by rapid degrees , to the highest state of affection and influence . [Lucy]128-lucy became as necessary to [Mrs. Ferrars]203-robert , as either [Robert]203-robert or [Fanny]88-fanny ; and while [Edward]202-edward was never cordially forgiven for having once intended to marry [her]128-lucy , and [Elinor]84-elinor , though superior to [her]128-lucy in fortune and birth , was spoken of as [an intruder]2622-an intruder , _ [she]128-lucy _ was in every thing considered , and always openly acknowledged , to be [a favourite child]2623-a favourite child . [They]2624-they settled in [town]2896-town , received very liberal assistance from [Mrs. Ferrars]202-edward , were on the best terms imaginable with [the Dashwoods]87-the miss dashwoods ; and setting aside the jealousies and ill - will continually subsisting between [Fanny]88-fanny and [Lucy]128-lucy , in which [[their]2624-they husbands]2626-their husbands of course took a part , as well as the frequent domestic disagreements between [Robert]203-robert and [Lucy]128-lucy [themselves]2624-they , nothing could exceed the harmony in which [they]2624-they all lived together .

What [Edward]202-edward had done to forfeit the right of [eldest son]2627-eldest son , might have puzzled [many people]3115-many people to find out ; and what [Robert]203-robert had done to succeed to it , might have puzzled [them]3115-many people still more . It was an arrangement , however , justified in its effects , if not in its cause ; for nothing ever appeared in [Robert]203-robert s style of living or of talking to give a suspicion of [his]2627-eldest son regretting the extent of [his]2627-eldest son income , as either leaving [[his]2627-eldest son brother]2957-his brother too little , or bringing [himself]2627-eldest son too much ; and if [Edward]202-edward might be judged from the ready discharge of [his]2627-eldest son duties in every particular , from an increasing attachment to [[his]2627-eldest son wife]245-his wife and [[his]2627-eldest son home]216-his home , and from the regular cheerfulness of [his]2627-eldest son spirits , [he]2627-eldest son might be supposed no less contented with [his]2627-eldest son lot , no less free from every wish of an exchange .

[Elinor]84-elinor s marriage divided [her]84-elinor as little from [[her]84-elinor family]358-her family as could well be contrived , without rendering [the cottage at [Barton]8-barton]2633-the cottage at barton entirely useless , for [[her]84-elinor mother]296-her mother and [sisters]265-sisters spent much more than half [their]2636-their time with [her]84-elinor . [Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood was acting on motives of policy as well as pleasure in the frequency of [her]84-elinor visits at [Delaford]19-delaford ; for [her]84-elinor wish of bringing [Marianne]85-marianne and [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon together was hardly less earnest , though rather more liberal than what [John]83-mrs. dashwood had expressed . It was now [her]84-elinor darling object . Precious as was the company of [[her]84-elinor daughter]371-her daughter to [her]84-elinor , [she]84-elinor desired nothing so much as to give up its constant enjoyment to [[her]84-elinor valued friend]2638-her valued friend ; and to see [Marianne]85-marianne settled at [the mansion - house]4237-the mansion - house was equally the wish of [Edward]202-edward and [Elinor]84-elinor . [They]2640-they each felt [his]2641-his sorrows , and [their]2640-they own obligations , and [Marianne]85-marianne , by general consent , was to be the reward of all .

With such a confederacy against [her]85-marianne with a knowledge so intimate of [his]2641-his goodness with a conviction of [his]2641-his fond attachment to [herself]85-marianne , which at last , though long after it was observable to [everybody else]1697-everybody else burst on [her]85-marianne what could [she]85-marianne do ?

[Marianne Dashwood]85-marianne was born to an extraordinary fate . [She]85-marianne was born to discover the falsehood of [her]85-marianne own opinions , and to counteract , by [her]85-marianne conduct , [her]85-marianne most favourite maxims . [She]85-marianne was born to overcome an affection formed so late in life as at seventeen , and with no sentiment superior to strong esteem and lively friendship , voluntarily to give [her]85-marianne hand to another ! and _ that _ other , [a man who had suffered no less than [herself]85-marianne under the event of a former attachment , whom , two years before , [she]85-marianne had considered too old to be married , and who still sought the constitutional safeguard of a flannel waistcoat]2643-a man who had suffered no less than herself under the event of a former attachment , whom , two years before , she had considered too old to be married , and who still sought the constitutional safeguard of a flannel waistcoat !

But so it was . Instead of falling a sacrifice to an irresistible passion , as once [she]85-marianne had fondly flattered [herself]85-marianne with expecting , instead of remaining even for ever with [[her]85-marianne mother]296-her mother , and finding [her]85-marianne only pleasures in retirement and study , as afterwards in [her]85-marianne more calm and sober judgment [she]85-marianne had determined on , [she]85-marianne found [herself]85-marianne at nineteen , submitting to new attachments , entering on new duties , placed in [a new home]2670-a new home , [a wife]2788-a wife , [the mistress of [a family]3071-a family]2647-the mistress of a family , and [the patroness of [a village]2650-a village]2649-the patroness of a village .

[Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon was now as happy , as [all those who best loved [him]99-colonel brandon]2651-all those who best loved him , believed [he]99-colonel brandon deserved to be ; in [Marianne]85-marianne [he]99-colonel brandon was consoled for every past affliction ; [her]85-marianne regard and [her]85-marianne society restored [his]99-colonel brandon mind to animation , and [his]99-colonel brandon spirits to cheerfulness ; and that [Marianne]85-marianne found [her]85-marianne own happiness in forming [his]99-colonel brandon , was equally the persuasion and delight of [each observing friend]2652-each observing friend . [Marianne]85-marianne could never love by halves ; and [her]85-marianne whole heart became , in time , as much devoted to [[her]85-marianne husband]282-her husband , as it had once been to [Willoughby]101-willoughby .

[Willoughby]101-willoughby could not hear of [her]85-marianne marriage without a pang ; and [his]101-willoughby punishment was soon afterwards complete in the voluntary forgiveness of [Mrs. Smith]113-mrs. smith , who , by stating [his]101-willoughby marriage with [a woman of character]2654-a woman of character , as the source of [her]113-mrs. smith clemency , gave [him]101-willoughby reason for believing that had [he]101-willoughby behaved with honour towards [Marianne]85-marianne , [he]101-willoughby might at once have been happy and rich . That [his]101-willoughby repentance of misconduct , which thus brought its own punishment , was sincere , need not be doubted ; nor that [he]101-willoughby long thought of [Colonel Brandon]99-colonel brandon with envy , and of [Marianne]85-marianne with regret . But that [he]101-willoughby was for ever inconsolable , that [he]101-willoughby fled from society , or contracted an habitual gloom of temper , or died of a broken heart , must not be depended on for [he]101-willoughby did neither . [He]101-willoughby lived to exert , and frequently to enjoy [himself]101-willoughby . [[His]101-willoughby wife]245-his wife was not always out of humour , nor [[his]101-willoughby home]216-his home always uncomfortable ; and in [his]101-willoughby breed of horses and dogs , and in sporting of every kind , [he]101-willoughby found no inconsiderable degree of domestic felicity .

For [Marianne]85-marianne , however , in spite of [his]101-willoughby incivility in surviving [her]85-marianne loss , [he]101-willoughby always retained that decided regard which interested [him]101-willoughby in every thing that befell [her]85-marianne , and made [her]85-marianne [his]101-willoughby secret standard of perfection in [woman]2657-woman ; and [many a rising beauty]2658-many a rising beauty would be slighted by [him]101-willoughby in after - days as bearing no comparison with [Mrs. Brandon]154-mrs. brandon .

[Mrs. Dashwood]83-mrs. dashwood was prudent enough to remain at [the cottage]471-the cottage , without attempting a removal to [Delaford]19-delaford ; and fortunately for [Sir John]94-sir john and [Mrs. Jennings]98-mrs. jennings , when [Marianne]85-marianne was taken from [them]2660-them , [Margaret]86-margaret had reached an age highly suitable for dancing , and not very ineligible for being supposed to have [a lover]2736-a lover .

Between [Barton]6-barton park and [Delaford]19-delaford , there was that constant communication which strong family affection would naturally dictate ; and among the merits and the happiness of [Elinor]84-elinor and [Marianne]85-marianne , let it not be ranked as the least considerable , that though [sisters]265-sisters , and living almost within sight of [each other]303-each other , [they]265-sisters could live without disagreement between [themselves]265-sisters , or producing coolness between [[their]265-sisters husbands]2626-their husbands .

THE END
